When will coronavirus end? We all know how this pandemic began. Originating from a Wuhan seafood market in China, the virus has now spread to almost every single country, locking down the whole world for a good six months now. But little do we know about how or when this pandemic will end. It is probably safe to say we are still nowhere near the end. Cases are still surging everywhere around the globe, countries breaking their own records every single day. Lockdowns, social distancing, wearing masks - nothing has really worked completely in containing the virus so far. Governments are being torn between saving lives or the economy, taking short sighted decisions, and making it even worse. Nothing concrete has been found yet to stop this virus. "We are still in the midst of an accelerating, intense, and very serious pandemic." – BBC quoted Dr Margaret Harris from the WHO in an article earlier this week. Although this is one single virus that caused the pandemic, there have been hundreds and thousands of theories and speculations. Its diversity in nature and effects within regions and countries can easily blind one to the reality beyond his/her own country. Historians believe a pandemic can have two types of epilogues – medical and social. Medical ending happens when a permanent remedy is discovered and the affected and death cases plummet down to zero. This is probably what everyone is waiting for. Another is social ending, when everyone fights down their fear of the disease and learns to live with it. The New York Times quoted Dr Jeremy Greene, a historian of medicine at Johns Hopkinssays - "When people ask, 'When will this end?' they are asking about the social ending". This pandemic may end socially before it ends medically. An epidemic of fear can have far worse consequences than the virus itself. People suffer more from this and eventually grow tired of the restrictions and the initial panic mode. That is when they eventually come out of their houses and learn to live with the virus following safety protocols - the new normal. And we are already seeing this happen in most of the countries. Think of Bangladesh for a moment. When the shutdown was first imposed in late March, the country suddenly stood still. People from all walks of life became restlessness among them, panic mode set in. The ever busy streets were suddenly empty, there was pin drop silence all around. Stepping out of home for nothing felt like a crime. And this did continue for a few months. However, over the last couple of months, people have begun to step out of their homes and carry on with their normal life. Offices, businesses, shops, restaurants, parks - almost everything has reopened, except for the educational institutions. The usual hustle and bustle of daily life is gradually coming back to life. This has recently been the case almost everywhere around the world. Fear and panic seems to have taken a back seat across the globe. Governments are trying hard to reopen important places and institutions to bring things back to normal, only to see a bigger surge in the coronavirus cases due to this. However, people are still trying to live their life, maintaining all safety protocols. Medical ending is actually the permanent solution, and a little bit complicated too. A working effective vaccine will destroy the virus and bring triumph over this pandemic, that is the common belief. Coming up with a proven working vaccine will not be that easy, and the current speculations regarding the virus only make it more complicated. So it is safe to say we are still far behind a permanent medical solution. Usually, it takes more than a year or two to develop a vaccine, depending on several issues. Based on that, we are nearly a good year away from getting a permanent working vaccine. It can get delayed for many reasons, and there are actually signs of conflicts here and there. The New York Times reported that on August 11, Russia has already approved a Gamaleya vaccine before Phase III testing. More than 165 vaccines are being developed against the coronavirus around the world, while 30 of them are in human trials. Human trials is the critical stage where it will determine whether the vaccine will actually work or not. Due to the mutations of the virus, it has only become more difficult. There are confusions and speculations, but it is widely hoped and expected that vaccines will be available in the later months of 2021. Some experts believe this pandemic will continue for at least two years with the vaccine being developed and distributed worldwide. Vivek Murthy, former US surgeon-general, has warned that the pandemic might not go away until the end of 2022. Microsoft co-founder, Bill Gates told Wired magazine on August 07, 2020- "For the rich world, we should largely be able to end this thing by the end of 2021, and for the world at large, by the end of 2022." While hopes are high and fingers are crossed for a safe and effective vaccine as early as possible, there are several issues that complicate the whole process. Any concrete proof of reinfection may well halt the whole effort of developing a vaccine. If that is the case, then vaccines might not even offer permanent immunity. We still do not know how long antibodies work against the virus. And if somehow the vaccines do not offer permanent immunity from the virus, people may need the vaccine every year or two later, to maintain immunity, just like flu shot. According to The Atlantic, if immunity lasts a few months, there could be a huge pandemic followed by small outbreaks every year. Immunity lasting closer to two years could see Covid-19 peaking every other year and cases rising and falling over time. Herd immunity – with or without vaccines – can be a solution, but that will take some time to drive away the pandemic as well. To achieve herd immunity, the virus needs to be transmitted to around 65-70 per cent of the people. Sweden has taken this road of achieving herd immunity without a vaccine, which has proved to be costly with a much higher rate of deaths than other affected countries. Covid-19 may end up being another virus ending as an endemic, even with the discovery of vaccines. Vaccines actually exist for more than a dozen of human viruses, but only smallpox has been eradicated, The Atlantic reports. The virus has locked the whole world down for quite some time now, and it is not going anywhere anytime soon. The sooner the vaccines are available, the better. We better not expect that the vaccines will have a Hollywood-esque arrival and fix the problem in a flash. Proper vaccination will still take a good year or two given it works effectively once discovered. Social distancing and other safety protocols still need to be maintained while stepping out of home. It should be kept in mind that the pandemic is not over just because we are over it. And the question might just change from "when" to "if" this virus will be disappear and the pandemic will ever come to an end.

Well in the present situation we can't eradicate the virus anytime soon. But any epidemic or pandemic can end in only two ways. Everyone will get infected gradually and will attain immunity against the novel virus and end this threat.So by everyone I don't mean that all of us will be suffering from it at the same time. Infact that's quite a thing we are trying to prevent. Because that will be catastrophic for our health care system and it may collapse causing surge in the mortality rate. Now this is the novel Corona virus. It being a new virus, no one has immunity against it and hence it can infect almost everyone. And the transmission is devastating. But as more and more people will get infected and recover from it, they will serve and the chain breakers. On an individual level, our bodies build up immunity by producing antibodies that recognize and fight off an infection from invading pathogens such as SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19. This is acquired immunity. The antibodies are like vaccines. They protect us against the reinfection and thus transmission. By vaccines we provide readymade antibodies to the susceptible people so that they get immune to the disease even without contracting it. This is called passive immunity. This is also the basis of plasma therapy. Wherein we infuse the antibodies from the plasma of recovered patients into those infected to kickstart their fight. This is much like passing on the sword. But this is under trails so let's not get into it. Let's make it a bit lucid. Scenario 1 Suppose A has the disease and he comes in contact with B C D E AND F. All these five people never had covid 19 and are susceptible to it. Hence all five will get infected, will manifest the disease in more or less severity depending on their comorbidities. But before and after manifesting the disease symptoms while they were carring the virus they will spread it to ’n' no of people who come in their contact and are susceptible too.  Scenario 2 Now T has the disease and T comes in contact with U, V ,B and D. But this time two of the four people have some immunity against the disease as they had contracted it. So they will not get the disease and hence will not spread forwards. So this time the spread is significantly reduced.   Now if in this way many others develop immunity we will be able to contain the spread. Because ultimately the infected person will be coming in contact with immune people who will break the chain and there will be no spread. This is called HERD IMMUNITY. For achieving herd immunity a huge chunk of people should be immune against the disease. This can be achieved by vaccination or infection. The vaccines are under trails and will require time to come into play. And if the herd immunity is to be achieved by infection, we have to take care that those getting the disease are in such controlled number which our health system can deal with. That's is what 'Flatten the curve' means. 2. Quarantine and isolation This we all are quite acquainted with by this time. If we successfully isolate ‘A' and ‘T’ and quarantine everyone who came into their contact we will be able to contain the transmission. This is the purpose of lockdown everywhere.

Understand that what is being done in a majority of countries is now assured to make any recovery from this take longer and longer. As much as 10 years. We are fully committed in the US to not being done with this for at least three or four years. You see, it ends when there is herd immunity. When the virus no longer is a threat to most people and stops being anywhere near as communicative. Could we achieve this with a vaccine? Maybe, but 90% of the people or more would have to take it. There is no way a “government” vaccine is going to be accepted by that much of the population. Then there is the cost. You didn’t think it would be free, did you? Even if it was, I can’t see more than 50–60% of the population taking a vaccine with virtually unknown side effects or long term effects. The fact is, not a lot of people die from this, compared to the number that contract it. Yes, it is terrible for those that do die. But it is equally terrible for many, many people to sit by and watch their entire life and livelihood evaporate. Instead of a quarantine of the sick, what we have tried to do is instill fear in the whole population and quarantine everyone. This works, after a fashion, but it doesn’t eliminate the threat, it just pushes it down the road. Now what we have are people running around trying to be “free” after a period of incarceration. We have people that are convinced that if they get this disease they will die horribly. And we have people with no understanding of how this disease is transmitted trying to tell everyone what they have to do. Sure, it will one day be over. But the only way it ends is after a very large percentage of the population (like 85–90%) either gets it and recovers or gets a very, very effective vaccine. Yes, we are going to see around 0.5% of the US population die from this - eventually. No vaccine is going to stop that.

Nobody can predict this, it will very much depend on the actions by each country. But the Epidemic is expected to end very soon (Within 1 year) if the following action taken and implemented effectively: A reliable vaccine. Now both China and United States vaccine is under the clinical trial stage[1].A specific medicine that can cure at least 90% of the affected people. As it is a Broad-spectrum antivirus medicine, we may pay close attention to the news about this.Citizen consciousness. As residents of cities, we need to try to do the following: Wash hands frequently or use hand sanitizer, never touch face, nose, mouth, ear without washing hands, stay far away from the crowd, avoid close contact with others, Cover coughs and sneezes, stay at home or wear a mask when you are sick, delay travel and party plans, for more you can read this.[3]Public area control: Government and companies can do a lot of things to prevent the spread of COV-19: Try to let employees work from home, if the jobs are not able to be done at home, let the employees sit at least 1.5 meters away. In 1920, a world wearied by the First World War and sickened by the 1918 flu pandemic desperately sought to move past the struggles and tragedies and start to rebuild lives. People were in search of a “return to normalcy,” as Warren G. Harding put it. Today, nearly every country finds itself in a similar position. About the authors More than eight months and 900,000 deaths into the COVID-19 pandemic, people around the world are longing for an end. In our view, there are two important definitions of “end,” each with a separate timeline: An epidemiological end point when herd immunity is achieved. One end point will occur when the proportion of society immune to COVID-19 is sufficient to prevent widespread, ongoing transmission. Many countries are hoping that a vaccine will do the bulk of the work needed to achieve herd immunity. When this end point is reached, the public-health-emergency interventions deployed in 2020 will no longer be needed. While regular revaccinations may be needed, perhaps similar to annual flu shots, the threat of widespread transmission will be gone.A transition to a form of normalcy. A second (and likely, earlier) end point will occur when almost all aspects of social and economic life can resume without fear of ongoing mortality (when a mortality rate is no longer higher than a country’s historical average) or long-term health consequences related to COVID-19. The process will be enabled by tools such as vaccination of the highest-risk populations; rapid, accurate testing; improved therapeutics; and continued strengthening of public-health responses. The next normal won’t look exactly like the old it might be different in surprising ways, with unexpected contours, and getting there will be gradual but the transition will enable many familiar scenes, such as air travel, bustling shops, humming factories, full restaurants, and gyms operating at capacity, to resume.The two ends are related, of course, but not linearly. At the latest, the transition to normal will come when herd immunity is reached. But in regions with strong public-health responses, normalcy can likely come significantly before the epidemiological end of the pandemic. The timeline to achieve the ends will vary by location. In this article, we’ll explain the criteria that will be key factors in determining when each is reached. In the United States and most other developed economies, the epidemiological end point is most likely to be achieved in the third or fourth quarter of 2021, with the potential to transition to normalcy sooner, possibly in the first or second quarter of 2021. Every day matters. Beyond the impatience that most feel to resume normal life, the longer it takes to remove the constraints on our economies, the greater will be the economic damage. I don’t think that anybody knows that for certain. There are about 325 million people in the US, and close to 8 million confirmed cases. What we don’t know is how many people have had asymptomatic cases, and that number could be as high 131 million. I’m getting that by taking 40% of people positive who didn’t know that they’d had it as there were in a study in New York. So adding the confirmed cases and the asymptomatic cases together is about 140 million, if I’m at all accurate. That’s 43% of our population. At one point, the experts were saying that herd immunity happens at 70–75%. So, if that’s right, that would happen when 30% more of us will have had it which would be 97,500 of us, with 39,000 of us without any symptoms. So that’s 58,500 who would have some symptoms although not necessarily becoming ver sick. If 8% of the symptomatic people die (which I think is high but it’s an average of the past two weeks according to the CDC), that would be 4,680. If any of this is right, that will give a mortality total of about 215,000 people who will die in the US from Covid. My numbers would certainly be wrong somewhere along the line since I’m not a statistician, but that’s far below the 2 million or thereabouts that they were predicting at the beginning. And, if you take into account that 5 million people are in nursing homes or assisted living situations undoubtedly with comorbidities, I think we’ve done pretty darn well given the hype about this. Of course, if you or a loved one is the one who dies of it, your morbidity would be 100% so this is just looking at numbers, and not necessarily very accurate ones. What this comes down to for me is that when we get to that 215,000 death total, this thing should be ending on its own. While cases are going up, the death rate is going down substantially which is great. Unless we get a huge spike in deaths over the fall and winter, we’re more than halfway to herd immunity without a vaccine. With an effective and safe vaccine, we might be pretty darn close right now. If my numbers are wrong, I would be happy to know.

[1] Consider this unfortunately familiar scenario.  Several months ago a highly infectious,sometimes deadly respiratory virus infected humans for the first time. It then proliferated faster than public health measures could contain it. Now the World Health Organization (WHO)has declared a pandemic, meaning that it’s spreading worldwide. The death toll is starting to rise and everyone is asking the same question: when will the pandemic end? The WHO will likely declare the pandemic over once the infection is mostly contained and rates of transmission drop significantly throughout the world. But exactly when that happens depends onwhat global governments choose to do next. They have three main options: Race through it, Delay and Vaccinate, or Coordinate and Crush. One is widely considered best, and it may not be the one you think. In the first, governments and communities do nothing to halt the spread and instead allow people to be exposed as quickly as possible. Without time to study the virus, doctors know little about how to save their patients, and hospitals reach peak capacity almost immediately. Somewhere in the range of millions to hundreds of millions of people die, either from the virus or the collapse of health care systems. Soon the majority of people have been infected and either perished or survivedby building up their immune responses. Around this point herd immunity kicks in, where the virus can no longerfind new hosts. So the pandemic fizzles out a short time after it began. But there’s another way to create herd immunity without such a high cost of life. Let’s reset the clock to the moment the WHO declared the pandemic. This time, governments and communitiesaround the world slow the spread of the virus to give research facilities time to produce a vaccine. They buy this crucial time through tacticsthat may include widespread testing to identify carriers, quarantining the infected and people they’ve interacted with, and physical distancing. Even with these measures in place, the virus slowly spreads, causing up to hundreds of thousands of deaths. Some cities get the outbreak under controland go back to business as usual, only to have a resurgence and return to physical distancing when a new case passes through. Within the next several years, one or possibly several vaccines become widely, and hopefully freely, available thanks to a worldwide effort. Once 40-90% of the population has received it— the precise amount varying based on the virus— herd immunity kicks in, and the pandemic fizzles out. Let’s rewind the clock one more time, to consider the final strategy: Coordinate and Crush. The idea here is to simultaneously starvethe virus, everywhere, through a combination of quarantine, social distancing, and restricting travel. The critical factor is to synchronize responses. In a typical pandemic, when one country is peaking, another may be getting its first cases. Instead of every leader responding to what’s happening in their jurisdiction, here everyone must treat the world as the giant interconnected system it is. If coordinated properly, this could end a pandemic in just a few months, with low loss of life. But unless the virus is completely eradicated— which is highly unlikely— there will be risks of it escalating to pandemic levels once again. And factors like animals carrying and transmitting the virus might undermine our best efforts altogether. So which strategy is best for this deadly,infectious respiratory virus? Racing through it is a quick fix, but would be a global catastrophe, and may not work at all if people can be reinfected. Crushing the virus through Coordination alone is also enticing for its speed, but only reliable with true and nearly impossible global cooperation. That’s why vaccination, assisted by as much global coordination as possible, is generally considered to be the winner; it’s the slow, steady, and proven option in the race. Even if the pandemic officially ends before a vaccine is ready, the virus may reappear seasonally, so vaccines will continue to protect people. And although it may take years to create, disruptions to most people’s lives won’t necessarily last the full duration. Breakthroughs in treatment and prevention of symptoms can make viruses much less dangerous, and therefore require less extreme containment measures. Take heart: the pandemic will end. Its legacy will be long-lasting,but not all bad; the breakthroughs, social services, and systems we develop can be used to the betterment of everyone. And if we take inspiration from the successes and lessons from the failures, we can keep the next potential pandemic so contained that our children’s children won’t even know its name. One possibility, historians say, is that the coronavirus pandemic could end socially before it ends medically.  Agencies According to historians, pandemics typically have two types of endings: the medical, which occurs when the incidence and death rates plummet, and the social, when the epidemic of fear about the disease wanes. “When people ask, ‘When will this end?,’ they are asking about the social ending,” said Dr. Jeremy Greene, a historian of medicine at Johns Hopkins. In other words, an end can occur not because a disease has been vanquished but because people grow tired of panic mode and learn to live with a disease. Allan Brandt, a Harvard historian, said something similar was happening with Covid-19: “As we have seen in the debate about opening the economy, many questions about the so-called end are determined not by medical and public health data but by sociopolitical processes.” Endings “are very, very messy,” said Dora Vargha, a historian at the University of Exeter. “Looking back, we have a weak narrative. For whom does the epidemic end, and who gets to say?” In the Path of Fear An epidemic of fear can occur even without an epidemic of illness. Dr. Susan Murray, of the Royal College of Surgeons in Dublin, saw that firsthand in 2014 when she was a fellow at a rural hospital in Ireland. In the preceding months, more than 11,000 people in West Africa had died from Ebola, a terrifying viral disease that was highly infectious and often fatal. The epidemic seemed to be waning, and no cases had occurred in Ireland, but the public fear was palpable. Murray wrote, “If we are not prepared to fight fear and ignorance as actively and as thoughtfully as we fight any other virus, it is possible that fear can do terrible harm to vulnerable people, even in places that never see a single case of infection during an outbreak. And a fear epidemic can have far worse consequences when complicated by issues of race, privilege and language.”  Black Death and Dark MemoriesBubonic plague has struck several times in the past 2,000 years, killing millions of people and altering the course of history. Each epidemic amplified the fear that came with the next outbreak. The disease is caused by a strain of bacteria, Yersinia pestis, that lives on fleas that live on rats. But bubonic plague, which became known as the Black Death, also can be passed from infected person to infected person through respiratory droplets, so it cannot be eradicated simply by killing rats. Historians describe three great waves of plague, said Mary Fissell, a historian at Johns Hopkins: the Plague of Justinian, in the sixth century; the medieval epidemic, in the 14th century; and a pandemic that struck in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The medieval pandemic began in 1331 in China. The illness, along with a civil war that was raging at the time, killed half the population of China. From there, the plague moved along trade routes to Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. In the years between 1347 and 1351, it killed at least one-third of the European population. Half the population of Siena, Italy, died. “It is impossible for the human tongue to recount the awful truth,” wrote 14th-century chronicler Agnolo di Tura. “Indeed, one who did not see such horribleness can be called blessed.” The infected, he wrote, “swell beneath the armpits and in their groins and fall over while talking.” The dead were buried in pits, in piles. In Florence, Italy, wrote Giovanni Boccaccio, “No more respect was accorded to dead people than would nowadays be accorded to dead goats.” Some hid in their homes. Others refused to accept the threat. Their way of coping, Boccaccio wrote, was to “drink heavily, enjoy life to the full, go round singing and merrymaking, and gratify all of one’s cravings when the opportunity emerged, and shrug the whole thing off as one enormous joke.” That pandemic ended, but the plague recurred. One of the worst outbreaks began in China in 1855 and spread worldwide, killing more than 12 million in India alone. Health authorities in Mumbai, India, burned whole neighborhoods trying to rid them of the plague. “Nobody knew if it made a difference,” Yale historian Frank Snowden said. It is not clear what made the bubonic plague die down. Some scholars have argued that cold weather killed the disease-carrying fleas, but that would not have interrupted the spread by the respiratory route, Snowden noted. Or perhaps it was a change in the rats. By the 19th century, the plague was being carried not by black rats but by brown rats, which are stronger, more vicious and more likely to live apart from humans. “You certainly wouldn’t want one for a pet,” Snowden said. Another hypothesis is that the bacterium evolved to be less deadly. Or maybe actions by humans, such as the burning of villages, helped quell the epidemic. The plague never really went away. In the United States, infections are endemic among prairie dogs in the Southwest and can be transmitted to people. Snowden said that one of his friends became infected after a stay at a hotel in New Mexico. The previous occupant of his room had a dog, which had fleas that carried the microbe. Such cases are rare and can now be successfully treated with antibiotics, but any report of a case of the plague stirs up fear. How Will COVID-19 End? People may grow so tired of the restrictions that they declare the pandemic over, even as the virus continues to smolder in the population and before a vaccine or effective treatment is found. “I think there is this sort of social psychological issue of exhaustion and frustration,” Yale historian Naomi Rogers said. “We may be in a moment when people are just saying, ‘That’s enough. I deserve to be able to return to my regular life.’” It is happening already; in some states, governors have lifted restrictions, allowing hair salons, nail salons and gyms to reopen, in defiance of warnings by public health officials that such steps are premature. As the economic catastrophe wreaked by the lockdowns grows, more and more people may be ready to say “enough.” “There is this sort of conflict now,” Rogers said. Public health officials have a medical end in sight, but some members of the public see a social end. “Who gets to claim the end?” Rogers said. “If you push back against the notion of its ending, what are you pushing back against? What are you claiming when you say, ‘No, it is not ending.’” The challenge, Brandt said, is that there will be no sudden victory. Trying to define the end of the pandemic “will be a long and difficult process.” Hope this helps😊 [1] Footnotes[1] When will the coronavirus pandemic end, and how?

A few years at best and more like a few decades and at worst, well how good is your imagination. Zombies, collapse of the world’s economies. The best scenario is based on, if people, all suddenly smarten up and all keep their faces covered by a mask when shopping for food or medication only and when close to strangers, keep away from strangers, like two meters and wash their hands after touching a commonly touched surface. And otherwise, stay home as long as possible. If just that is done for four or five years then, and only then, will we get out of this pandemic in reasonable shape, meaning somewhat the same as before the pandemic started. The more likely scenario is that people who, consider themselves better than others, who will continue in not doing those basic four points and gather in large groups close together, and therefore keep spreading the virus but, with implementation of stronger and stronger and harsher and harsher controls and penalties then, a lesser and lesser rate of contagion will ensue until it becomes a barely noticeable background story that keeps popping up of, small groups getting infected. If too many get ever more nervous, just because they are not getting out as much as they would like then, there will continue to be large pockets of contagion that will just keep the contagion curve up too high to control, even when very strict controls and very high level penalties are used. There might be a levelling off, of the contagion curve, at a too high a level that, gets pushed up from one side by those who just have to take their masks off too often, get out too often where there are too many others and pushed down on the other side, by ever more information bites being put out by authorities, by ever tighter controls and increasing greater and heavier penalties. That high curve will, just by being high, force more and more people to get more desperate, ending in increasing suicide rates, besides the death rate from being infected. That is the worse or worst way that it will all go. It might be even worse, so that more and more people will just give up on trying and just go out, and the devil take the hindmost. That attitude is also possible. So take your pick. Either act responsibly and it should all get a bit better as time goes by. Or do not act responsibly and it will not get better. That choice is not just about making choices, but also about inner strength and how much one is willing to put up with short term but increasingly worsening lack of a decent life style. Four years of doing those four points is a long time, like being in jail for no good reason. The other side in this is, to consider that there are places in the world where people live like this all their life because of poverty and other forces beyond their control. Right now that is beginning to apply to more and more of us. That also can be a learning experience, to teach us that life is not always about a good time, progress, a good career or doing whatever one wants. So reality sometimes sucks. What can be done about it? We know what to do, so do it.

How and when will this pandemic end? We asked a virologist We may be approaching a saturation point in terms of coronavirus infections in some of the worst-hit countries. Eventually, the virus will run out of people to infect.But there are still many unknowns when it comes to this virus. We spoke to Belgian virologist Guido Vanham, the former head of virology at the Institute for Tropical Medicine in Antwerp, Belgium, and asked him: how will this pandemic end? And on which factors might that depend? More than one-third of the world's population is now in lockdown as the world battles the COVID-19 coronavirus pandemic. How will this pandemic end? Guido Vanham (GV): It will probably never end, in the sense that this virus is clearly here to stay unless we eradicate it. And the only way to eradicate such a virus would be with a very effective vaccine that is delivered to every human being. We have done that with smallpox, but that's the only example - and that has taken many years. So it will most probably stay. It belongs to a family of viruses that we know - the coronaviruses - and one of the questions now is whether it will behave like those other viruses. It may reappear seasonally - more in the winter, spring and autumn and less in the early summer. So we will see whether that will have an impact. But at some point in this epidemic - and certainly in the countries that are most affected, like Italy and Spain - there will be saturation, because according to predictions, up to 40% percent of the Spanish and 26% of the Italian population are or have been infected already. And, of course, when you go over 50% or so, even without doing anything else, the virus just has fewer people to infect - and so the epidemic will come down naturally. And that's what happened in in all the previous epidemics when we didn't have any [treatments]. The rate of infection and the number of those susceptible will determine when that happens. What are some of the factors at play? What do we know, and what don't we know? GV: The first thing we know, of course, is that it's a very infectious virus - that's probably something that every inhabitant of the world knows. But what is not known is the infectious dose - how many viruses you need to produce an infection - and that will be very difficult to know unless we perform experimental infections. And we know people develop antibodies. That has been clearly shown in China, but we are not yet sure how protective these antibodies are. There is no convincing evidence yet that people who have recovered get ill again after a few days or weeks - so most probably, the antibodies are at least partially protective. But how long will that protection last for - is it a matter of months or years? The epidemiology in the future will depend on that - on the level of protective immunity that you get at the population level after this wave of infections, which we cannot really stop. We can mitigate it, we can flatten the curve, but we cannot really stop it because at some point we will have to come out of our houses again and go to work and school. Nobody really knows when that will be. The virus will take its course and there will be a certain level of immunity - but the answer to how long that will last will determine the periodicity and the amplitude of the epidemics to come. Unless, of course, we find a way to block it in a year or so from now with an effective vaccine. The number of new cases outside China appears to be on the wane (Image: Worldometer) There is also an unresolved question about what determines an individual's susceptibility to this disease. Of course there is age, but that’s not so surprising. People’s immune systems weaken with age. But then there is this concept of co-morbidities, which means that some people, even younger people, get ill because they have other diseases. It's logical that when you have cancer or diabetes, that you are more susceptible to infections. But what is remarkable - what we do not really understand - is that people with simple hypertension are also very vulnerable to developing this disease. So that's one of the unresolved questions. And it will be interesting to see what the profile is of people who are infected but do not get ill. We will know in a few months - that question is already being addressed in China. Then you can go back and test for antibodies, because it looks as though everyone who has gone through the infection will develop antibodies - and that those will remain for a while. There are people that have antibodies and have not presented to to the medical services and claim that they have been healthy all the time. What's the genetic profile of those people as compared with the people who went to the medical wards? That is an interesting question. One hint has already been discovered in China; your blood group could be important. It’s very preliminary data, but in a year or so from now we will have a lot of data on that as well. This is one virologist’s view of how the pandemic could end

Barring some heretofore unknown treatments, COVID-19 is likely here to stay, at least in some form. Coronaviruses, like the ones that can cause the common cold, generally grant immunity somewhere between six months to a year. Since SARS-CoV-2 (AKA COVID-19) is a novel virus, it is possible the outcome might be different than with other coronaviruses. I really hope so. But in cases like this it’s best to plan for the worst and hope for the best. I suspect for the foreseeable future this will be like a global game of whack-a-mole - the virus will pop up somewhere, the local government will use lockdown to get it under control there, and then it will pop up somewhere else. I think a lot of people are pinning their hopes on a vaccine coming along and ending the COVID-19 problem in its tracks; I hate to tell people not to be hopeful, but… I would tell such people to temper their optimism slightly. First, no vaccine has ever been developed against any human coronavirus. Second, one also has to be aware that a vaccine for COVID-19 likely won’t be like a vaccine for, say, the measles, because of the aforementioned issues with coronavirus infection not conferring lifetime immunity. The first generation of vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 will likely not prevent infection entirely by inducing “sterilising immunity.” It’s more likely they will reduce one’s likelihood of catching the virus somewhat, and reduce symptoms if one does. But in that case, one could still spread the illness to others. And every time the virus jumps to another host, the capacity for mutation is there. The D614G mutation has already occurred, for example. The good news is, as we learn more about the virus, the we are better at treating it, at identifying risk factors within individuals, and at identifying hotspots and cordoning them off before the spread worsens. As I mentioned, this is a novel virus, there is so much we don’t know - but we’re learning more about it all of the time. That it can cause blood clots throughout the body, for example. That it has caused a rise in stillbirths. That individuals with Neanderthal DNA seem to be more at risk for severe COVID symptoms. Every day we learn more about this virus, and the more we learn, the better off we are. Meantime, our best bet at saving as many lives as possible and reducing the amount of infection as much as possible is through cooperation and sacrifice on the parts of individuals, organisations and governments. Wash your hands often, wear a mask when in public, practice social distancing as much as you are able, and listen to the advice of medical professionals and researchers - people with training and expertise. I frankly don’t expect SARS-CoV-2 to be entirely gone in my lifetime. But I live in hope :)

First, viruses do not go away. In that sense, it will not “end.” The current round of infection is already ending. Refer to the articles on the reopening of New York State appearing on May 12, 2020. On the CDC website is information that the 1918 flu virus (which killed over 2 million people) has mutated over time to being the H1N1 flu virus - still a stronger flu strain, but nothing like as strong as the original virus. Again on a link to the CDC site was the information that the COVID virus has already mutated at least once. This makes development of a vaccine more difficult, as the vaccine may not work equally well on every mutated viral strain. The same thing, by the way, applies to the flu viruses - which is why making a flu vaccine is a guess every year about which strains will show up. in 2019–2020, we had two different strains, the second one began in February/March - so this year the flu vaccine only worked 29% of the time. In 2017–2018 the flu vaccine only worked 19% of the time. 80,000 people died that year, more than COVID now. Odd that we pay no attention to these deaths. Two points about immunity: no one is explaining the importance of herd immunity. People who carry the virus but are not sick, people who have been sick and recovered are part of creating that immunity. It happens with every virus. It means that recurrence of the virus brings fewer illnesses and deaths (except in the frail elderly over 75 or those with underlying conditions). Vaccines don’t work well on people over 60 - any vaccine. I worked for the Visiting Nurse Association and had to take a Hepatitis Vaccine. There are people who are given the flue vaccine two and three times before the body responds with any antibodies at all. Science is not a magic wand we can wave over the natural world for control.

Covid 19 will not go away and become one of the many flu’s that you can catch. “Normal” flu is actually a set of different strains of flu. And all of them started out as a pandemic. Some more serious and some less so (varying degrees of infection rates, fatality scores, and so on). SARS and MERS didn’t go away, you’ve probably had it by now. As time goes by, more and more people catch it and become immune (meaning they can’t get it again or that any new infection will be milder) creating a natural barrier to transmission. This means hospitals aren’t overrun with millions of people needing medical care, the vulnerable are protected by herd immunity. Also, vaccines are developed and medicinal protocols are installed. And still “the normal flu” kills thousands of people every flu season. We’re used to that, it doesn’t even make the news. Why is COVID19 different? Well, in time it won’t be, but at the moment it’s a new disease, meaning no herd immunity. There are no vaccines to protect the people most likely to die from it. There are no medical protocols in place to treat, lower death rates or prevent. Meaning everybody is at risk. Also, it has a long asymptomatic period where people can infect others. It can spread through surface contamination. Someone sneezes, puts their hand on a railing and the virus is active hours later. And it’s mortality rate is relatively high compared to other epidemics. In time, procedures, vaccines, medicines will be in place. Herd immunity will taper down the amount of people that need emergency care from this flu. When that will be? Only time will tell. Vaccines and protocols could take 18 months to put in place and then they still need to be mass produced. I understand that everything is being done to upgrade research speed and that some vaccines - for SARS (which is much like this), for example - are being tested on volunteers. Knowing if those are effective and safe and then mass producing them will take a lot of time. I know there are some treatments - I read about drugs for TBC, AIDS, malaria - are being tested on volunteers as well. Some claim good results. We will need to see. That doesn’t mean the country will be in lockdown for 18 months. It means that for the next 1,5 years - based on the little knowledge we have and the best predictions out there - we will have to balance the daily life with trying not to overrun the medical system. So that everyone who needs treatment will be able to get treatment. Likely, when this flare-up tapers off due to social distancing, life becomes less restricted and we will need to focus on containing new outbreaks. Perhaps needing new periods of lock down to slow it down again. Like a new driver trying to maintain speed by accelerating and then pressing the brakes. But that’s just my guess, I’m not an expert. The other variant is letting the disease run rampant. 60–80% of people getting infected in a short time period. 10–15% of those needing specialist medical treatment. Only a small percentage of those severe cases actually getting the treatment they need to live. The rest being turned away. Millions of people dead. But we would be done with it in a few months. Do the numbers on that for your own country’s population, or even your own street. It’s staggering.

Let’s see how the current environment looks like. Here are some uncertainties that govern investors’ reactions over the past 50 days: Nobody knows how long will the pandemic last. Obviously, the longer the worse and there is no indication of slowing down.Nobody knows if people who get sick will have immunity over the next potential virus wave.Nobody knows how the transition period back to normal economic activity will be achieved and how long it will take.Nobody can estimate the real economic damage to the backbone of the economy → SMEsNobody can estimate the second derivative of the sell-off effects, i.e. what will happen with the fallen angels and lack of liquidity.A few facts about the virus: Death rate varies between 0.5% – 7%, depending on population age, ICU coverage and extent of population testing.Most of the patients do not present symptoms for many days, which makes the virus extremely effective in spreading.No vaccine is expected before the next 12–16 months.Now, a few economic facts and hard data: Almost 50% of US corporate debt is BBB rated now and with most of the world’s population being under lock-down, it is no rocket science that big part of them will fall below investment grade.Almost 3.3M Americans filed for jobless claims last week. This is 5x the previous record of 1982.The Fed’s balance sheet just exceeded $5 trillion for the first time.Markets are deep into bear market territories.What next for the global economy? Now, to answer the question, it must be clear that Covid-19 will not disappear overnight. It will be a long and gradual process lasting 3–6 months. I am afraid the worse is yet to come for markets across the world. The detrimental effects in the real economy are becoming more obvious day by day and translated into spikes in unemployment, mortgage payment delays, lack of liquidity and financing for SMEs, cuts in Capex and supplies, and lastly corporate and personal defaults. This is a self-feeding loop probably leading to what economists describe as secular stagnation. The Central Banks were not ready to face such a crisis. Rates were extremely low already and their balance sheets were already loaded with a lot of public and corporate debt. Another stimulus plan may be the only solution now, but it is not sustainable in the long run. My opinion is that markets will remain into bearish territory for many months after the “end of covid-19”. How investors should react? The important question is “What can ordinary investors do to prepare?” You cannot time the market. You never could and definitely cannot start now. So, instead of guessing whether stock markets are going to rise or fall further after Covid-19, adopt a longer horizon. Get some exposure in the stock market but do it for the long run. There is no point to pick the best mutual fund, as most of them underperform the markets. Go for a cheap ETF. Robinhood or Vanguard will probably do for most jurisdictions.Normal diversifiers like corporate bonds are always necessary for an all-weather portfolio. However, keep in mind that in every liquidity crunch most of the risky assets move together and move downwards.Safe havens, like government bonds (US, Germany, UK) still have their place in your portfolio.Look for long/short. This can be alternative types of exposure, investment styles, methods, etc. Look for market-neutral assets and funds. At the toughest periods, the market-neutral investments will keep your portfolio beating. It is true that market-neutral exposure is not the easiest thing to achieve as an ordinary investor, but there are a few apps that try to achieve that. I find Daedalus Investment Platform interesting, but I am sure there will be others as well for jurisdictions not covered.Keep some cash. Not only as a safe haven but to also exploit opportunities when you identify them.Summary These are hard times for the markets and events that are unprecedented for our generation. It is and will be tough, but the best we can do is be prepared both for the virus (social distancing & healthy routine) and for our long-run financial plan.

Good Evening 😌  It is safe to say that for the next year or so, life will not return to normal for the world. Even if the Indian epidemic peaks around May , as some experts are now predicting, it will take several months for the deaths to stop. And in the interim, and perhaps for months afterwards, it will still be considered dangerous to go to the cinema, to attend large weddings, to shake hands with strangers, etc. But eventually, the epidemic will have to end. It is sometimes hard to recognise this because things look so bleak right now. The truth is that all epidemics end sometime. And this not even the worst epidemic of the last century or so. Consider the Spanish Flu pandemic. It lasted from January 1918 to the end of 1920. Over half a billion people (yeah,billion – not million) were infected and over 50 million people died. You can argue about the number of infections. So, the number of deaths is often a slightly more accurate way of gauging the extent of a pandemic. In contrast, the Covid pandemic has been relatively mild. (As bizarre as this may sound.) According to official figures there have been 450 deaths in India so far. Even assuming that this an underestimate and that more will die in the weeks ahead, the total deaths will be under ten thousand (nearer 5,000 at the most, unless there is an unforeseen event). This sounds terrible. And yet, it is nothing compared to the Spanish Flu. One estimate has it that 5 percent of India’s population died --- around 17 million people. If five percent of our population died now, that would be several crores (around six or seven crores). When you see these figures, the havoc, death and devastation caused by Covid pales in comparison. And yet, as terrible as the Spanish Flu pandemic was, it did end. And it ended without a cure being found or without a vaccine being developed. In the 21st Century, we believed that pandemics could never happen because modern medicine has advanced to the level where any disease can be cured. That is why we look for miracle drugs or wait for a vaccine. But it seems unlikely that a Covid vaccine will be widely available over the next 12 months (at least). And yet, it seems probable that the scale of incidence of Covid will have reduced significantly even before scientists can find a cure. History shows us that this is likely. There are broadly, three ways, in which a pandemic ends. The first is herd immunity. This is probably how the Spanish Flu ended. Herd immunity means that a virus has spread so widely through a community (in the case of Spanish Flu, the whole world) that the people who have survived it have developed immunity. This is a risky strategy but there is no doubt that the UK government at least toyed with the idea in the early stages of the pandemic. The reasoning was that just as most Brits have immunity to measles and many strains of flu, the same immunity to Coronavirus could develop among the larger British population. It is a difficult strategy for the layman to understand. The reason we have immunity to measles is that most of us contracted it as children. With the flu, there is reason to believe that antibodies to flu, which are in the blood of anyone who has had a mild attack, will protect them from more virulent strains. But as Covid-19 is caused by a new virus which few of us have been exposed to, how would herd immunity develop? A more likely consequence is that the virus would kill off large sections of the population (starting with the elderly) before such immunity developed. Though the UK government denies this, critics argue that the reason the UK did not start on social distancing measures till it was almost too late was because it believed in herd immunity. If the government had acted promptly critics say, the UK would have not been so badly hit by the virus. Britain has had nearly 15,000 deaths, a lot more than India or even China, countries with much larger populations. Another approach, made possible by modern medicine, is to manufacture Covid antibodies in a lab and to give them to those at risk from the virus. So far, nobody has done this successfully but there are promising reports of such antibodies being created. Alternatively, you could invent a Covid vaccine and vaccinate the general population. Several groups of researchers are working on such a vaccine (which would make the body create its own antibodies) but the earliest we can expect one to be widely available is the second half of next year. Yet another solution would be to find drugs that can beat the virus. This is not as easy it sounds. Take, for instance, AIDS. We now have many drugs than can beat the symptoms and help the body fight the virus. Life expectancy after infection has increased so much that AIDS is no longer the death sentence it was in the 1980s. But no, we still don’t have a single drug that knocks out the virus. So it is with Covid. Even if the drugs that are much hyped (such as Hydroxychloroquine) do work – and there is no hard evidence that they do —they don’t knock out the virus but at best, help with the symptoms. That's why I think personally that an end to this virus is possible, though not completely but to some extent. Thank You 😊

I hear a lot of misconceptions about “the end” of an epidemic. It doesn’t mean “wiping out” an illness such that it disappears from the planet. The CDC has a formal definition for what constitutes the “start” and the “end” of an epidemic, and they maintain an online tracking that anyone can check at any time. From the US perspective (the CDC is a US centric organization), there are roughly 330 Million Americans. That’s a steady state between new births and deaths. Roughly 80,000 Americans die weekly … year in, year out. The CDC keeps tabulation on weekly death certificates where the cause is attributed to Pneumonia, Influenza, or Covid (PIC). The NORMAL proportion of PIC deaths varies seasonally from 6% of all deaths to 7.5% of all deaths. That’s several thousand weekly deaths attributed to PIC. It statistically varies all the time, just like a stock market going up or down daily. An epidemic threshold is set a couple percent above the normal PIC proportion, and when it is exceeded we are in epidemic territory. When it returns across that threshold we can describe the epidemic as over.  This shows 3 years. You can see the rather bad flu outbreak of 2 years ago (that cost more than 60,000 deaths). On the right you can see the COVID-19 outbreak. Note that while the proportion of PIC deaths was much higher than the flu of 2 years ago, it should be obvious that the proportion of PIC deaths has been dropping like a rock, and is down to just a couple percent of re-crossing the epidemic threshold back to normal. You can find this on the CDC website at: COVIDView, Key Updates for Week 31 It is updated only once a week. While the CDC tracks the proportion of US PIC deaths, the NYT maintains an online visualization of “excess deaths”. Based on country populations, there is a normal rate of deaths in various countries based upon that countries life expectancy (it varies from country to country). The NYT has seized upon the tracking of national death totals tracked relative to their normal death rate. They call the metric “excess deaths”. Thus epidemics can be observed to peak above normal death rates, and at some point return back to normal death rates.  While inherently different in method from the CDC, one can observe that the covid epidemic reached a peak of excess deaths, and has returned close to the historic rate. The NYT tracking is interesting because it depicts the cycle of the epidemic for a rich set of countries around the world: 161,000 Missing Deaths: Tracking the True Toll of the Coronavirus Outbreak Just like the CDC the NYT maintains this tracking and keeps it up to date. Also In both these visualizations (CDC vs NYT) it’s plainly visible that the epidemic is virtually over in the United States. No, that doesn’t mean COVID deaths have disappeared any more than Pneumonia, or Influenza. It simply means we’re just about back to normal mortality levels from before the epidemic. It’s fascinating to compare the NYT tracking of the COVID epidemic in other countries … the epidemic is OVER most everywhere in the world as the NYT tracking demonstrates. What’s fascinating is that the headlines from the NYT don’t seem to bear any relationship to the NYT’s own tracking, but the reasons for such a discrepancy have absolutely nothing to do with any tabulation or accounting.

When will the virus be exterminated? Probably never. There will likely be at least a few small reservoirs of the virus somewhere in the world. When will this pandemic end? Well…when the number of people who are susceptible to the infection drops so low that the virus fails to transmit effectively. This can occur in one of several ways: Tons of people die. The population is so small and isolated that transmission is unlikely. This scenario is not realistic. This virus is not deadly enough to cause this issue especially in the setting of modern medical care.Lots of people contract the disease. Some people die. But most people don't die. Antivirals are developed that help fewer people die. The many people that survive become immune. The virus doesn't mutate significantly so re-infection risk remains low. And those that are immune provide herd immunity to those who are not immune.A successful vaccine is developed. Mass vaccination leads to wide-spread immunity. We hope the virus doesn't mutate significantly so that the vaccine remains effective.I would like to note that social distancing is not going to stop this virus. It will help tremendously at slowing the rate of infection such that our healthcare resources are not overwhelmed by a sudden influx of infected patients. But it will not stop the virus because we will not, practically speaking, be in isolation long enough to completely eradicate it. Once people start going outside and interacting, the virus will spread again. We need immunity to effectively control this thing. That happens naturally with enough people getting sick and recovering and/or it happens artificially with a vaccine.

There can be three ways, 2 pretty straightforward, but the third one is a bit scary. Develop a vaccine, vaccinate everyone- While testing on humans has already started Coronavirus | China gives go-ahead for human trials of COVID-19 vaccine , it will still take time to perfect it and mass produce, so it’ll be months before this happens, but it sure will.Social Distancing- This is very essential to “Flatten the Curve”, i.e- Help reduce the load on the medical system, But it would still not put an end to COVID-19 as the general masses are still not immune to it.Herd Immunity, how any pandemic ends- The general population plays a significant role in spreading of the virus. You may be the healthiest person on earth, and the virus may not affect you, but you can effectively spread it to people who aren’t as healthy as you, and that’s how an outbreak starts. It’s the ability of the virus to transmit so far and wide that's scary, and not exactly the mortality rate. But what if, we could stop the transmission altogether?Enter Herd Immunity, when enough percentage of the population is resistant to a virus, its spread stops naturally because it cannot find enough people to hitchhike on. Thus, the “herd” is immune, even though many individuals are not, because there’s a lesser chance that someone will serve them the virus.  We have witnessed many such outbreaks which were later reduced to seasonal diseases, and herd immunity is the reason. Consider Zika virus, an epidemic in 2015. Within 2 years, there was nothing much to worry about, and the virus had fizzled out naturally. It was found that the blood samples of 63% of the population in Salvador had already been exposed to Zika and had grown immune to the virus. High Zika Virus Seroprevalence in Salvador, Northeastern Brazil Limits the Potential for Further OutbreaksThen there was the Swine Flu outbreak of 2009. Things were scary back then, but over the years, it has turned into seasonal flu. This is because a majority of the population is resistant to the Swine Fu virus and won’t carry the virus along with them.Vaccines can create herd immunity as well. That is how diseases like smallpox were eradicated and Polio is on the verge of eradication. Various vaccines are being tested for COVID 19, but they may be ready for more than a year. When do we reach immunity? There’s a mathematical relation between the herd immunity threshold and germ’s propensity to spread, expressed as the reproduction number(R0). The R0 for COVID-19 is between 2 to 2.5, meaning each person can pass on the infection to about 2 other people. The outbreak is snuffed out once the infection rate is less than 1. The pandemic flu of 1918 required about 50% of the population to be immune to have herd immunity, either from a vaccine or natural infection. The more infectious a virus is, the more people need to be immune for us to achieve herd immunity. Meases, for example, had an R0 of over 12, which turns out to be about 90% of people need to be resistant for unprotected people to get a free ride from the herd. That is why new outbreaks can start when even a small number of people out of the measles vaccine. Similarly, for COVID 19, around 66% of the people need to have immunity to reach herd immunity kicks in. “Suppressing transmission means that we won’t build up herd immunity,” says Azra Ghani, the lead epidemiologist on the new model of the outbreak from Imperial College London. The trade-off of success is “that we are driving it down to such a low level that we have to keep those [measures] in place.” We’re not going back to normal What is herd immunity and can it stop the coronavirus? Stay Safe KB

If you are living on the Northern hemisphere, my prediction is that you will be able to completely relax, even if you continue to follow the news, in August 2021! Here is my reasoning: For the next 9 month, we will see the humongous and awfully deadly winter wave of Covid-19 in the Northern part of the Northern hemisphere. Extrapolating from the first wave (shown below), and given the quite strict countermeasures every country will apply given this horrible carnage, we can predict that the deadliness of Covid will again fade out end of June 2021: Source: Coronavirus Pandemic Data Explorer. As the “winter/spring wave” of 2020/2021 will be more than 10 times larger* than the one from spring 2020 due to a hundred thousand fold higher number of “initial spreaders”, the tail of the chart, of course, will be longer, so I included July 2021 in my prediction of still very stressful months.*(10 times larger if we use the number of confirmed deaths; more than 50 times larger if we use the numbers of confirmed infections, as testing capacity was limited in spring 2020).Now to August 2021: In the meantime, the pharmaceutical industry and politicians have worked very hard to make mass vaccination possible. Given the current effort of finding a safe and effective vaccine, I am 100% positive that there will be one by early 2021. The biggest vaccination program in history will be ready and conducted in 2021.The seasonal effect of Covid would only able to turn on the “infectiousness” again from mid of September 2021, as we can extrapolate from the onset of the “winter wave” in 2020: Source: Coronavirus Pandemic Data Explorer. And Covid would only able to turn on the “kill switch” (=getting more deadly = increasing IFR) only in early/mid January 2022 again, as we can extrapolate from the behavior of the pandemic in the Southern part of the Southern hemisphere in the winter there in 2020 (if we shift the dates by 6 months): Source: Coronavirus Pandemic Data Explorer. However, both, the “switching on of infectiousness” in September 2021 as well as the “switching on of deadliness” in January 2022 won’t happen because, by this time, we will have escaped by using the vaccine. The pandemic will be over! There might be outbreaks like you know it from the flu, but it won’t be a stressful and all-consuming pandemic anymore.For more explanations on the seasonal effect of Covid, you can read: Florian Neubauer's answer to Will there be another COVID outbreak in December? Covid-19 is a respiratory illness that won’t go away, but it will be accepted that people will get it and then get over it like the common flu. There will be Covid-19 shots just like flu shots or a combo of flu/covid shots. There will be over the counter medication to treat Covid-19 symptoms. I think what you’re trying to say is, “When will the Covid-19 panic end?” Well, with any panic it will take some time for people not to be afraid of something. So, I would say after a safe, effective vaccine is made that shows considerable protection against the disease is when the panic will end. But if the WHO, CDC, and various other experts keep reporting about vaccine ineffectiveness and disease mutation, the panic will continue until enough people see that not so many people are getting infected, many hospitals are not overrun with Covid-19 patients, and that general life is being restricted unnecessarily. Then and only then will the panic end. Is there a definite timeline on that? Yes, I would say after the winter season most people will start to realize not a lot of people are getting infected or dying from the disease and therefore lockdown, masks wearing, and other restrictions will subside. But then, CNN is reporting about a bacterial infection in China that wasn’t reported on last year, so one panic might change to another “panic”. So it really depends on if people are skeptical of their government run media and experts who only show one point of view rather than all points of view is when this or any other “panic” will end. It takes people looking around to recognize they had been “had”. For what reason? I honestly don’t know.

Try to gain your immunity level as that is the most important thing to survive during COVID-19. Here are some tips to gain immunity: Don't smoke avoid tobacco.Eat a diet high in fruits(Rich of vitamin C) and vegetables.Go for the garlic and Ginger.Exercise regularly and drink water as much as you can.Drink and gargle with warm water.Get adequate sleep.Take steps to avoid infection, such as washing your hands for 20seconds. after an hour or frequently.Try to minimize stress by meditation and yoga.The only way to control the spread of this disease is to stay at your home and keep the distance from others. It will work only when we all understood this basic thing for some time as MODIJI said. Please follow him strictly. #STAYHOMESTAYSAFE #STAYHOMESAVELIVES 🙏🙏🙏🙏

It is still unclear, since how the pandemic unfolds in each country seems different, moreover there is great that as the virus mutates it can become more virulent, can cause more severe problems even for younger people who seem to be relatively unaffected so far. And if we want to talk about the wider implications of the pandemic that will go on much longer. The virus scare caused an unprecedented lockdown, shutdown all over the world, which in turn will cause irreversible damage, changes to our economic, financial, political and social system. But is this necessarily a bad thing?! After all our “old system” - which was already on life support before Covid-19 - was built on unnatural, excessive, destructive, explosive overproduction, overconsumption. Through this system we have been competitors, enemies to each other and to Nature, and as most people already accepted it, we were inevitably sleepwalking towards a goal calamity. In this respect we could even say that the virus outbreak is a relatively merciful, benevolent way Nature's system collapsed our Human paradigm, to give us the opportunity to rethink our values, priorities, how we want Human society to look, work, develop. The Coronavirus epidemic, the ensuing global crisis affecting all levels of Human activity, or other natural catastrophes if necessary will continue, repeat themselves until we will finally understand that in order to solve our problems, in order to safeguard our collective Human survival we have to make Human society compatible with Nature's fully integrated, interdependent system. “Coronavirus — A Blessing In Disguise?” (Thrive Global) | Laitman.com What Will Defeat The Coronavirus? | Laitman.com

It will, but not any time soon. I’m not an expert, but I have studied a bit of history, a reasonable amount of epidemiology, and quite a lot of microbiology. There are three ways that the pandemic ends. An effective vaccine is developed, manufactured, and distributed in sufficient quantities that viral spread is inhibited. This is the solution that the world is currently working towards.This route does have some complications:Developing an effective vaccine is painstaking work, if it is done correctly.Making enough of a vaccine will take a long time (think about how many people live in the world, seven to eight billion), and distribution will be tricky too, especially if the vaccine has a shelf life or needs special storage measures.Not all vaccines are equally effective in all people.Viruses mutate. A lot. It’s kind of their thing. This is why we get flu shots every year, instead of at a longer interval. If COVID-19 mutates into a form that the vaccine doesn’t work for, we’re gonna be set back a ways.Treatments improve to the point where COVID isn’t much of a concern anymore. COVID-19 has a pretty high survival rate already (thank God for modern medicine), and we are finding more and more ways of treating the virus and it’s symptoms as the pandemic continues. Recent studies with steroids (no, not that kind), have reduced mortality rate significantly, for example).In this scenario, the virus is still around, but we treat it like getting the flu. Effectively, it becomes part of the usual cocktail of sicknesses that we just know how to deal with.Again, there is still a possibility that the virus will mutate into a more deadly strain, and current treatment methods will no longer work, but I think that this option is the most likely to occur.The virus mutates into a non-infectious or non-lethal form. This is what happened to the 1918 Spanish Flu pandemic. This is possibly the most frightening, as there’s no way of knowing when or even if such an event would occur.There’s no way of knowing, for sure, when the pandemic will be over. That’s one of the things that makes them so disruptive. Most pandemics take at least a year to tackle. We’ve been at it for six months so far. I think that a realistic date, at a minimum, is the middle of next year. I don’t think that current restrictions will be in place for as long as the whole pandemic, but’s that’s mostly due to how politics works.

The question of when Covid-19 is going to end is being asked hundreds (if not thousands) of times here on Quora. One lengthy answer in my feed included graphs, a lot of talk about things like peaks, troughs, infection rates, etc. in an effort to arrive at some kind of reliable prediction. It had been written about a week earlier, and despite the writer's attempts to be scientific and balanced in all that he said, his overall answers were already well off the mark. Much the same is happening with even the most professional attempts at "modelling". But here is the real point that needs to be made with regard to all of these predictions: None of it... Yes, I said "none of it" is of any use in predicting when it is going to end. What is going to happen in each situation will depend entirely on WHAT WE DO... to contain it, to isolate and treat victims, to track contacts, to practice social distancing, to find a vaccine, etc. All of those factors are too numerous to include on charts from which we try to make our predictions. At the moment, things are looking much better than expected... but it has taken almost global lockdown to do it. We do, however, know that doing this is flattening the curve. That basically means we are extending the date at which we may be able to go back to normal, and the benefit of doing that is that we may be able to keep the infection rate within manageable bounds. So it’s not just how quickly we can end it, but how we can end it with minimal damage. On top of all that, there is still a lot of worry over what will happen if/when we relax the present isolation restrictions. It could flare up all over again. So basically, what people are asking for with a question like this is a supernatural prediction... like pointing to a cow in the distance and predicting whether it will turn left or right, and when. No one knows. Well, almost... See, if you look at my credentials, you will notice that I am a student of Bible prophecy. We humans are free to make our own decisions, but I believe that God knows what those collective decisions will amount to, and so I have just released a video (this week) that combines Bible prophecy with a bit of common sense and various long range observations, to give a picture of where all of this is leading... at least as *I* understand it. Here is a link to that video: Covid-19...What Comes Next? If we are seriously interested in predicting the future, prophecy is one way to approach it.

With 30–40 million(reported) deaths worldwide just from the virus ending with an overall average worldwide mortality rate of about 2%. So if you do the math that means 1.5–2 billion people would eventually get the virus(Covid-19), with the timeframe being between 18–36 months to take to get back to like pre-coronavirus time such as the end of 2019 as I would say we are currently on Month 3. The bad news is that Clovid-19 is very contagious and with the good news being that it’s mortality rate is fairly low, but that means the virus would never disappear on its own unless we build up an immunity(potentially a long time), create a cure(1+ years), or have a proper, long term, 100% effective quarantine worldwide(60–90 day minimum, as incubation can be up to 30+ days as well as the actual illness being another 30+) Coronavirus is more than one type of virus with 7 different types of coronavirus that can infect people such as SARS and MERS, currently we’re dealing with a new strain called Covid-19. The possibility that SARS and MERS being around before we identified them is real but let’s say they were new when we discovered them, that means coronavirus family has technically mutated 3 times since 2003. The possibility that it could mutate again within the next few years is real, for better or worse. Ultimately the government should inform the public and take a worse case scenario perspective during a pandemic so it’s citizens don’t have to and aren’t left hanging when it comes to their stability of health. Imagine the world having a huge band-aid on it with each country ripping it off in different directions with different speeds, that does not work with a fresh wound. This will be a lesson that will hurt like hell for the world but in the end it will drastically change the way we do things when it come to stability/health of the world.

Estimates for when the number of cases will peak in the USA include anywhere from mid-April (April 15 being the earliest, and the date predicted by the Gates Foundation epidemic model we are now using) to late May, but based on the success of this type of prediction so far, I estimate it will probably be July that we will see the blunted peak of active cases (many, many more than predicted, and many times more than Italy), with the peak of deaths coming a month later in August. Predictions are a fool’s errand, and I feel bad for the people who are held accountable for creating them, but they are the best we can do when considering the future. All models are wrong - some are useful. Italy is seeing a peak in their new cases centered around March 25, but the number of active cases there has not yet peaked. Some say we’re about two weeks behind Italy, but I expect that to grow to 4 or even 8 weeks because our population is so spread out across the country (even though the cities are having it first). Social distancing measures are only a temporary measure to slow the growth of cases; eventually everyone will need to catch this disease and overcome it as individuals, at least until a vaccine is available. Experts are predicting that there will be a worldwide resurgence in new cases beginning in September with the start of the flu season. But I don’t think it will “go away” at any time this year - we’ll just get better at treating it until a vaccine becomes available and can be distributed, or until enough people have had it that herd immunity can be built, after the wave of re-infections and false-negatives turning positive again has subsided. (The BBC once estimated the re-infection rate at around 14% so this will not prevent herd immunity, it will just slow down its arrival.) The biggest problem is that this virus grows so slowly at first, and is well tolerated by the immune system so that it takes a very long time for viral particles in someone’s system to fall to a background non-infectious, non-contagious level. It never truly ‘goes away,’ just remains at a concentration and rate of tissue damage such that a systemic immune reaction is not activated, as long as the antibodies persist. (This disease will remain a big problem for the immunocompromised population such as organ transplant recipients.) Also, for that reason, as soon as social distancing rules are relaxed, we can expect to see a resurgence. Remember: NO CURE - NO VACCINE - NO ONE IS IMMUNE. That is why you need to stay home, stay indoors, and avoid other people. We will eventually have a vaccine, but not before just about everyone on earth has had a chance to get this disease. 2020 will go down in history as the year that was cancelled.
