Prof Levitt said: "In Europe, I don't think that anything actually stopped the virus other than some kind of burnout," he added. "There's a huge number of people who are asymptomatic so I would seriously imagine that by the time lockdown was finally introduced in the UK the virus was already widely spread. They could have just stayed open like Sweden by that stage and nothing would have happened." If governments had jingle jangled and delayed before introducing lockdown, then as many people would have been infected because of the delay and lockdown would not have been necessary. "I think that the real virus was the panic virus," Prof Levitt told the Telegraph. "For reasons that were not clear to me, I think the leaders panicked and the people panicked and I think there was a huge lack of discussion." The answer to that has to be open-ended. We have no idea. It could be (a) this year as the curves peak, flatten, then decline (b) this year/next year if lockdowns and distancing are removed too early and a second recurrence hits and we go through it all again or (c) never. Our knowledge of this virus is still very incomplete. There now seem to be three related strains - A, B & C. We also know that humans can pass it to cats (but not dogs). It now also seems likely that domestic food animals such cattle, sheep, goats and pigs & even pigeons may well be receptive to it (Pasteur Institute). (This because these animals have the same protein receptor - ACE2 - through which Covid-19 enters human cells and takes over a cell’s function to make copies of itself that, in turn, infect other cells.) That then gives the virus a repository, in which it can mutate and from which it can periodically re-emerge. We don’t know how easily or how significantly it can or will mutate, on top of which there are question marks over whether or not catching Covid-19 gives a person sufficient immunity to protect them against catching it again. We have yet to produce a vaccine and we don’t know whether such a vaccine, when it arrives, will have to be periodically altered (as annual flu ones are). There are further question marks over the best treatment. Ventilators may actually makes things worse. Ventilators are used to treat pneumonia. Why? Because pneumonia is utterly exhausting and the muscles become too tired so the ventilator takes over from the muscles. I had pneumonia when I was a teenager and was bed-ridden for three weeks, delirious for some of that time; they were reduced to trying to feed me with jars of baby food and the first time I tried to shave when I was getting better, it took me over half an hour because I was so weak. But between 60% and 80% of Covid patients put on ventilators die as opposed to 40-50% of those with pneumonia. Covid-19 is not pneumonia. For a start, it hits both lungs simultaneously (which is why it is so hard to breathe) whereas pneumonia normally affects only one. Many Covid-19 patients have very low oxygen levels when they arrive at hospitals yet behave normally in a state of “happy oxygen starvation” then suddenly deteriorate and collapse. Covid creates a mucous barrier in the lungs, through which oxygen can barely penetrate no matter how hard the ventilator pushes it into the lungs. And the harder the pressure, the more the liklihood of damaging the lungs. Increasingly doctors are turning to CPAP machines (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) delivering fast-flow oxygen through a mask to saturate the body with oxygen. Also putting patients on their sides seems to help considerably. Covid increasing appears akin to high altitude sickness with the body being starved of oxygen. So we are only in the very early stages of understanding this virus, how to treat it, let alone prevent and eliminate it - if we can.

I have some acquaintance with a simulation code for 10 million people, that I prepared for some colleagues. With “optimistic” Wuhan/Northern-Italy parameters (= infected people double in about 3 days, the pessimistic version is two days only, and a death percentage near 1 %). If you do nothing and wait for nature do its will, something like 1 % of people has died and the epidemic is over within 6 months. It ends because everybody is now immune, assuming that nobody was at the beginning. But much more probably after a month and a half the deaths will surface and oblige you do do something. That is to slow down infection rates (either because your government imposes curfew, or because you become very scared and very careful). The number of infected will begin decreasing, may be slowly may be quickly. Much depends on when you begin applying care. But qualitatively what happens are a few important things: The numbers of sick people and of daily dead people decrease and progressively become much smaller, but do not end within six months. It is a much longer story.When a final trend is reached towards stability, a large fraction of the population is not immune yet.If you completely stop care, one left infected person is enough to restart everything.How much “everything” is a repetition of the previous movie depends on the number of immune people after the first wave.Some comments on this game. (1) some people are surely immune from the very beginning, so things could be over something sooner within any scenario. (2) Viruses mutate, so herd immunity is a big step but things are never really over. In conclusion: you can do much to slow down the process, but “slow down” means that it becomes a slow process. With fewer deaths, but distributed over a longer time, perhaps much longer.

We are not even close to a stop in surge of infections. Infact according to WHO data shows that not even 10% of the global population has been infected by the coronavirus. A lot of people are yet to be infected. But the bad thing is that we also have people arranging Covid parties in these difficult times. A Covid party is basically a party that is organized with the intention of catching coronavirus. Those who mostly organize these parties do it with the intention of passing the message that the virus is a well orchestrated hoax. A very perfect example of this is of a recent case of a 30 year old man in Texas who died after being infected with the virus at a Covid party. I thought this virus was a hoax but it's not.” It's unfortunate that people usually try to downplay crises the moment they occur. It's infact a well known thing that all human beings have normalcy bias that causes them to be accustomed to the normal and continue flouting social distancing guidelines and wearing of face masks even when there is imminent danger. With such kind of collective failure , it doesn't seem as though the end of Covid 19 is anything to expect. The truth is that the coronavirus is going to be endemic very soon.

How does the Covid-19 outbreak end? It depends. Best case scenario. City wide containment and quarantines works. People are unhappy but understanding that Chinese draconian quarantine measures are needed for the good of mankind. Such measures include the acceptance of a quarantine period of 30 days that the Chinese are currently imposing on their citizens as Chinese doctors have detected incubation periods as long as 27 days. 14 days quarantine that was used by the world was not enough. Summer comes, the virus dies down globally. The vaccine is produced by June, far faster than anyone could have predicted. This was the result of the world coming together to combine the scientific might of humanity into this one effort and a big helping of luck. As an unnamed researcher said, “It was as if the hand of God guided me. Every test worked on the first try. I have never seen such a thing in all of my career.” When it came to cost of the vaccine, the world as one says the vaccine will be free, a joint effort by nations across the planet and the billionaires of the world will shoulder the $3bn cost. When asked why? They said because it was the right thing to do. However cynical analysts point out that most world leaders and billionaires are old. The covid19 outbreak has a mortality rate of 10–15% for people over the age of 65. Thus this outburst of altruism was simply the OLD who are rich and powerful protecting themselves. But no matter the reason, everyone gets vaccinated. The covid19 pandemic ends, thanks to a global cooperation not seen since WW2 and the defeat of smallpox. The 2020 global recession begins. It is severe but we get through it. If humanity can work together once, we can all work together again. Worse case scenario Containment fails. Quarantines are unsuccessful as citizens of the world reject the Chinese draconian measures used. We would rather die free than live under the rule of an authoritarian government. Not that quarantine measures would have worked, as global health official rejected the reports coming out of china. The chinese are obviously mistaken, they claim. What we are seeing are people being reinfected by the virus a second time. Not a 27 day incubation. However they also ignore the case of a 15 day incubation period in the US. Summer comes to the northern hemisphere. But Covid19 has spread so far that it escapes into the winter world of the southern hemisphere. There it continues to infect the populations of South America, South Africa and Australia and New Zealand. Covid19 as a RNA type virus continues to mutate at a rapid pace. Vaccine development stall. It is August. The most promising vaccine target, triggers a cytokine storm where the immune system becomes hyper-stimulated to the point it attacks its own cells. All human test subjects die from multiple organ failure. This comes as a shock to western doctors and researchers but not to Chinese doctors who note that among young people who die from Covid19, some do so from multiple organ failure rather than respiratory failure. Nor is it a surprise to one Indian research group. Who noted that the covid19 has viral surface proteins with molecular changes that could allow it to bind to cells of the immune system. Controversially they ascribed such changes to biowarfare development but could provide no proof for such a claim. First rule of science don’t speculate unless you have proof. Just report what you see. The controversy they ignited delayed further investigation and validation of their first observation. The 12–18 month time line is beyond optimistic. Unnamed sources admits a 2–5 year development route is closer to reality. The vaccine is not ready and won’t be ready for years to come. Winter returns to Northern hemisphere and with it come Covid19 with a vengeance. The time spent on three different continents has allowed the covid19 virus to diverge into 3 different serotypes. Immunity to one serotype does not confer immunity to the other 2 or to the original covid19 strain. People get infected multiple times. So the world is beset by Covid19, Covid19.1, Covid19.2, Covid19.3. Each viral strain has developed its own unique characteristics. What they are is lost in the ensuring chaos. What we do know is that global leaders, both nations and institutions become infected. Being older than general population, the coronavirus strains goes through the leadership of humanity like a scythe though wheat. Initial reports of the Covid19 parent strain from China tell us why. The average mortality rate for covid19 in China was 2%. However upon dissection of these numbers, we find that the mortality rate of young healthy adult to be 0.2%, no worse than a flu. However for senior citizens over the age of 65, the mortality rate climbs to 10%-15%. It does not help that there are 4 coronavius strains and an ongoing H1N1 pandemic that media has ignored, each taking a turn. Organizational chaos ensures, as leaders die. Hospital fill with the ill. There are not enough beds. Not that it mattered as they are not enough supplies. Nations close their boarders in the attempt to stop spread of the virus. Nations horde supplies rather than trading it with nations who need them, allowing the virus to spread until it overflows into surrounding nations. It also means no one nation has all the supplies it needs to combat the virus effectively. International trade falters, and there is a supply shortage. People are not working, factories are idle. Companies are unable to pay their employees who in turn cannot pay for goods and services. The US economy that is based (70%) on the consumer falters. This is not helped as the US economy is already in a bubble. The global economy implodes , making the 2020 Great Recession, the biggest depression in history. The death rate climbs, as medical services can no longer be provided. People start dying NOT from Coronavirus but from other causes simply because they cannot get medical supplies. Food shortages begin as international trade falters. The death toll is unknown, estimates go as high as billions. A quarter of a billion people die from Covid19 alone. More die from everything else. 100% of the human population are eventually infected by Covid19 and its descendants. Just like the 1918 Spanish flu and its descendants like the H1N1, it become parts of the local flu scene. . Reality? We all go back to work. Factories stay open. China admits it was being foolish and a soft socialist for not using its hardcore ‘I treat my citizens as ablative meat shields’ street cred. Western nation show the way as they ignore the pandemic and have people continue working to avoid an economical collapse. 2% mortality rate is acceptable, especially when 80% of the dead are unproductive 65year olds. US also finds its solution to its overburden social security and medicare/medicaid system. In the US, ~6 million Boomers are dead. Leadership protects itself with medical might of a fully functional economy. To prevent the medical system from being overwhelmed. People are advised to stay home. An unusually number of people died in their beds surrounded by family. It isn’t so bad, there are worse ways to go. A quarter of a billion people die from Covid19. The vaccine is developed in time… for the next covid19 outbreak. Most of the human population are eventually infected by Covid19 and its descendants, just like the 1918 Spanish flu and its descendants such as H1N1. We don’t blink an eye when H1N1 killed over half a million people in 2009. It is not even news worthy as the 2020 H1NI outbreak sweeps its away across the globe. Life goes on. In 100 year people will talk about the 2019 Coronavirus the same way we talk about the 2009 North American flu (infected 1.4bn people), perhaps only remembered as the cause for fights over toilet paper.

COVID-19 will be history in less than two years through: a vaccine, which will take around a year to have ready for public use; orbringing the numbers of those with the virus down drastically and then hunting down every single person affected and isolating them.However, two years is a long time. People are panicking. Business owners know they can’t survive for long like this, consumers are hoarding, stock markets are crashing. But I’m not panicking, I’m buying no more than my regular groceries and I’m buying stocks, not selling. Why? On my Facebook page yesterday, I explain exactly why: “In China lockdowns started on 23 January. Daily deaths started falling less than a month later. Another month later it was down to less than 10 a day. In Italy, lockdowns started just over a month ago, and the number of deaths has recently fallen two days in a row. What seems to be clear is this. Without a lockdown, this virus spreads uncontrollably - within a few months virtually 100% of the population would get it. With a lockdown, it's under control within a month. Two months later it's as good as gone. The bad news is that the slower governments enforce a lockdown, the greater the loss in lives, and those numbers will be significant - for example, the UK and US will see tens of thousand deaths between them, possibly hundreds of thousands, because of their governments' slow actions. The good news is that every government in the world will eventually be FORCED to enforce lockdowns once their own death numbers shoot up. The UK did it yesterday. And 2 months later life will be pretty much be back to normal, with people having to take minor precautions. We're going to get over this a lot quicker than most think. The real question is how many more unnecessary deaths will we see due to governments failing to act fast?”  COVID-19 may take two years at most to completely eradicate, but its impact on the economy will be for much shorter than the media makes out and the markets have projected. We’ll all be back to work fairly soon.

Eradication of Covid-19 pandemic necessitates the need for a combined effort by all the countries across the globe. PM Modi’s decision to lockdown the entire country came at the right time and will be largely instrumental in bringing down the spread of COVID-19 cases. He needs all appreciation and accolades for acting very swiftly and decisively in his will for containing the spread. Dr. Bruce Aylward has almost 30 years experience in fighting polio, Ebola and other diseases, and now, he’s turned his attention to stopping the spread of COVID-19. The doctor, who led a joint WHO mission to China in February to study the effectiveness of the coronavirus response in the country, has seen firsthand the measures Beijing took to fight the virus. Now he’s sharing what he learned with governments and communicating with the WHO response teams working to fight COVID-19 in virus epicenters around the globe. When you look around the world in Europe, North America, the Middle East, you can see that we’re really at the period of exponential growth, we’re still seeing the virus going up very, very rapidly, even in hard hit places like Italy, for example. These countries still have months of this challenge in front of them. What it looks like is that we’re going to have a substantial wave of this disease right through basically the globe unless something very different happens in the southern hemisphere. And the question then is: What’s going to happen? Is this going to disappear completely? Are we going to get into a period of cyclical waves? Or are we going to end up with low level endemic disease that we have to deal with? Most people believe that that first scenario where this might disappear completely is very, very unlikely, it just transmits too easily in the human population, so more likely waves or low level disease. A lot of that is going to depend on what we as countries, as societies, do. If we do the testing of every single case, rapid isolation of the cases, you should be able to keep cases down low. If you simply rely on the big shut down measures without finding every case, then every time you take the brakes off, it could come back in waves. So that future frankly, may be determined by us and our response as much as the virus.

The novel coronavirus or COVID-19 infection has taken a huge toll on a global scale, with most countries on lockdown with strict measures to extinguish the pandemic. The coronavirus disease progression is rather tricky. It could take anywhere between 1-14 days from the time of exposure to development of symptoms. Symptoms like high fever, dry cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, headache are indicative of a possible infection. Sneezing is not a symptom attributed to the disease. However, variations in symptoms and their severity have been noted. There have been reports of patients developing wet cough, associated cold and body aches and some patients have experienced severe breathlessness even within a week of exposure, needing oxygen support to be able to speak and some needing ventilatory support in critical conditions. Although the virus seems to largely cause severe or fatal infection in higher risk patients including individuals with comorbidities like diabetes, respiratory conditions, the elderly and the immunocompromised, even young people have the propensity of developing severe infection. Dr. Tedros from WHO has remarked in reference to younger people saying “You are not invincible”. Once the symptoms arrive, the disease can progress to several directions. One can have mild flu-like symptoms that may subside within a week, while some may experience a slightly more severe infection with shortness of breath and heaviness of the chest for about 1 week-10 days before they recover. However, if the breathlessness gets severe that it may need hospital isolation and oxygen support- it may take upto 3 weeks from the time of symptom onset for recovery of the damaged epithelium in the lungs caused by the infection. Critical cases might prolong upto over a month and since there are no specific antiviral medicines yet, there is no telling how long it might take for a recovery. Recovery from the infection is not just the end of symptoms. Viral shedding can occur within 48 hours of exposure- which means those who are asymptomatic can also spread the infection, which is why social distancing is important. The shedding graduates to an all time high during the symptomatic phase, and can continue to upto 2 weeks after recovery, which is why discharged patients are asked to quarantine themselves for an additional 2 weeks to be on a safer side, even if their tests come out negative twice between a 24 hour period. Possibly never. Whether there will be a vaccination at some point, not clear, for many other types of these viruses there is no vaccination either - even though research has been going on for many years. Other triggers of epidemics, such as the Ebola virus, even appear again and again. As suspected in the case of the coronavirus, Ebola has confirmed that the transmission, a so-called spillover, was probably caused by humans eating wild animals, e.g. monkey meat - these animals themselves had already contracted the virus, so the virus was transmitted to humans. And anyone who thinks that Ebola is a one-off is wrong - there have been outbreaks time and again. The epidemic in 2014 was only the one we heard most about. The first confirmed outbreak of Ebola took place in 1976. Another piece of bad news is that new pandemics can occur again and again due to the transmission from animals to humans. And at the moment we are doing a lot to make sure that this happens again - whether it is by eating exotic animals or by destroying the natural balance for biodiversity in nature. There is a good book on this subject, which was published in 2013 and has as its thesis that there will soon be a new pandemic due to spillover. I have written a summary of the book: How Animal Infections Could Cause the Next Pandemic

The question the whole world is asking. And the answer is right in front of us. We decide when Covid-19 will end. Wait. Let me explain.  Nature is a closed system. It operates according to the law of homeostasis and must always maintain balance. Nature behaves toward humanity objectively. Meaning if we promote homeostasis, then we receive pleasant living conditions from nature. If we disrupt this homeostasis, then nature responds in ways to return to balance, often making our lives more “difficult” through natural disasters, such as fires, earthquakes — and new, unpredictable viruses. But don’t take it personally. Nature merely operates according to its program. It’s similar to a mother’s approach to an unruly child. Although she might have to be tough from time to time, it’s only to ensure the continued development of the child. So the recent discovery of COVID-19 is in order to show us that a change is needed. Think about it. We're being forced to distance ourselves from each other in order to prevent the virus from spreading. But this virus is merely a symbol of the root cause of the problem. We need to stop the true virus — our negative attitude toward each other — from spreading. This destructive inclination to build ourselves on the ruin of others (and on the ruin of our planet) has led humanity to the brink of the point of no return. Many experts believed we were headed for World War III before COVID-19 hit. Fortunately, nature has hit the reset button and given us a chance to slow things down and think about what our next move is. If we choose correctly, this virus will no longer be a cause for concern. If not, an even greater threat may appear. Let's choose homeostasis, between each other and with nature. By this, we won't need these external pressures and will instead ensure our continued development in a positive way. It’s in our hands. Together may we succeed!

The pandemic of Coronavirus is on the rampage and has been contnuously causing devastation not because it is deadly, but it is insidiously crafty as well. Those who are infected by the virus pay no heed to the government’s warning and venture out for their daily work without knowing that they are transmitting the virus to others. Under such a situation it is important to encourage people to stay at a distance from one another and people who are at high risk be advised to limit themselves to their houses. In spite of that, cases begin to rise then restrictions should be tightened only to carry out countrywide test in the population so as to check everybody with symptoms. By conducting such tests those found infected should be put in isolation for further medical care.  Besides, everyone they came into contact with, including their family, while they were serving as virus-carriers can be tracked down and tested to avoid its spread. Another test that we are being told about through electronic and print media that doctors and virologists are looking for antibodies in those patients, who have already defeated the disease, and are not expected to get infected again. If this test somehow becomes widely available then it might allow people, who test positive for antibodies, to move about freely. In Pakistan, there is a unanimous consensus that the pandemic can only be controlled and brought to an end with the establishment of crowd immunity. This feat can only be achieved when enough people are protected from microorganism, which causes disease, doesn’t take hold and dies down. This is high time that those, who matter, will have to come out with a vaccine to fight against the virus effectively. Though the world’s known pharmaceutical companies and universities are working very hard to develop its vaccine, but it is difficult to predict that they will come out with a victory. We know that development of a vaccine generally takes long and arduous procedure comprising of years of research and testing to ensure safe and effective trials. In the same vein claims are being made to deliver a vaccine inside a period not more than 12 to 18 months.  However, the WHO, epidemiologists and virologists are applying new technologies involving human cells with viral genetic material to make proteins that encourage an immune response. It is not clear if the methods will work or will they be able to manufacture enough shots. If one peeps around the pages of history, he will get to know that there have been far more dreadful and sinister pandemics or plagues over the centuries, mankind has encountered, that brought distress, pain and death in millions. The present day Coronavirus, no doubt, has caused unprecedented catastrophe worldwide. I have no intention to belittle or lessen the impact of morbid Covid-19, but we will have to admit this truth also that the number of lives lost in Coronavirus is in thousands which is not less than just peanuts in contrast to the major pandemics and plagues human-race has lived through in the past. In those days, vaccines would play no part and would make appearance lacking confidence.  Today the world’s super powers claim to have made huge advances in scientific technology as well as in medical science but despite that the pandemics continue to hit mankind after every interval. As a matter of fact, Covid-19 has not only exposed the so called super powers, it has also brought all the developed nations to their knees. The disastrous affects of the virus has deprived them of strength, brain and courage to deal effectively with Covid-19, but sadly it seems to me as though these developed nations are waiting for a miracle or divine intervention. Anyways, as the luck would have it, the virus could fade away with the begining of scorching summer in the country’s hemisphere, where most cases are like general flue which subside with seasonal changes. But it is yet to be seen and confirmed whether warmer season can literally play a role in flattening the curve or otherwise. Till then protect yourself & Stay home. \O/ Peace === Nadeem Karim Khan..✍🏻 Image Courtesy:- google.com.pk

response.answer_text: It is very very difficult to put a date on it. It is a question we probably all want to know the answer to and I doubt anyone knows for sure as it depends on many factors. These factors, in all possibilities, tend to differ in varied regions & countries due to substantial variations in demographics, particularly in the adequacy of healthcare infrastructure. These influential reasons(which may help us to draw a least possible broader time frame for the virus to start receding) that are supposed to hamper the recovery timelines can be summed up as follows : 1. The virus is particularly challenging because it can reside in people without showing any symptoms and then go on to be spread by that person. So under such circumstances, the scale of the spread would be very difficult to gauge for giving any scientifically-justifiable timetable to eradicate it completely. 2. As this coronavirus is a novel virus, so any modelling or future predictions are tedious & lengthy processes thereby making it particularly difficult to make a precise timeline estimate with the vaccine development. It would be very difficult for developers to balance the quality of the research work & trials with timeline oriented pressures. 3. The scale of this pandemic is unprecedented and absolutely uncalled for in living memory. Extent of globalisation and international connectivity and people’s movement for economic compulsions are such that curbing the spread has become so difficult. The end-game estimates for virus would keep on postponing itself with absolute uncertainty in such severe circumstances. 4. Come March 2020, we had predictions of: “cases can be limited and reduced to much lower levels in the next few months ” due enforced lockdowns across the countries. But as of now, things are far from those next few months. Moreover, the virus is too widespread now. 5. With the change in seasons, such as the advent of the rainy season in India, there are significant concerns about a sharp increase in coronavirus cases. This could coincide with the start of flu season and healthcare infrastructure aiding the vaccine trials thus may come under added pressure. 6. Many new adversely implicating findings every now and then coming to fore about the virus. The recent one being the WHO findings that states: “virus may be airborne”. 7. Curbing the virus will depend on how well strategies are taken up by people. Contrary to that people are getting increasingly ignorant about the preventive yardsticks & getting fatigued because of prolonged restrictions & economic compulsions. This can lead to messing up with control measures taken up by administrations, leading to wider spreads making it more difficult to come up with a specific timeline for the underlying solution for the pandemic. Vaccine seems to be the only solution? Yes. The key to combating the coronavirus will be the development of a vaccine. That is what is going to control things. We as a part of collective adoption, can develop ways of controlling symptoms too but they only treat, they don’t get rid of it. So a safe & effective vaccine is needed to squeeze it out on a mass scale. However, there are bottlenecks in developing a vaccine which makes it difficult to set a precise timeline for the complete eradication of the virus : 1. With vaccines you have to generate an immune response that is protective enough – any old immune response won’t do. It has to be able to protect against subsequent infections when that happens and that process eventually will take too long. Thus it isn’t as simple as it sounds. 2. The vaccine also has to be safe and it has to be long-lasting enough. Giving so many people immunity for a couple of months is rather pointless. 3. There is the additional problem of manufacturing the vaccine in sufficient quantities and quickly enough. As of now, we don’t know by when there will be sufficient doses to protect all of the at-risk populations, probably with two doses. Additionally, that means industrial-scale manufacturing that governments do not have. 4. As of now WHO lists 160 vaccines currently in development at various stages of research and development. Of these, 139 are currently in ‘preclinical evaluation’ stages.  Source : WHO vaccine development landscape. Having said that it is equally important to note that, too often, severe bottlenecks for vaccine production (such as batch testing, freeze-drying, filling &finishing, etc) are at the last stages. The current global situation requires unprecedented capacities to handle that: again, capacities that governments do not have. So taking all the above realistic constraints into consideration & driven by sheer optimism for a best-case scenario: It’s a long road ahead. There is a very little chance of a 100-percent effective coronavirus vaccine any time soon and could take anywhere between 12 and 18 months to enter the market.

It's new on the world block. Some health experts say it might become a seasonal illness like influenza, the flu. Once an effective vaccine is produced there may be a COVID-19 shot every year just like for the flu. But just like with the flu shot it would probably be optional. Some people that have recovered from it may be able to whether the symptoms as one does the common cold and flu in the future. This may happen because their bodies may develop a stronger immune response against it having gone through it before. Experts say even if it dies down by the end of spring or the beginning of summer, it may return in fall. Why? Well, there are likely, just like the flu, to be strains of the virus still inside some people somewhere in various places in the world even though it may be inert or dormant. When cold weather arrives or a person with it gets sick from something else or their immune system becomes compromised or their immune response becomes low, the virus could reanimate and spread again. Hopefully, the possible second wave will not be as devastating since so many people have caught and have been exposed to it already. Eventually, over time more and more may catch it, with less severe reactions, until crowd immunity is established. That is when a good number of a population of people have developed better efficient immune responses to a virus, where the symptoms become less acute to having very little effect on some or even most of the population. When there is a vaccine at the same time that is the game changer. Yet, I am somewhat of a naturalist. I say do thorough research and find out what natural things you can do to boost your immune system and other practical ways to try to avoid contracting a virus or treating yourself if you do contract it. But I will go see a doctor if absolutely necessary.

We don’t have a crystal ball on when the pandemic will end, but in my non-medical, completely unqualified opinion we are all currently facing three options: Slowly expose ourselves to other people - coming out of lockdown in such a way as to not overwhelm the health care system. Those who transmit the disease will transmit it to fewer people, making care (and contact tracking) more manageable. What is “slow” is debatable. Is it increasing exposure (group size / reduce social distancing) every 2 weeks or every week, or every month?Herd immunity - mass-expose everyone and as everyone gains immunity (or dies) the whole population is cocooned in, and no one else getting sickVaccine - the issue is that the virus may have mutated as it spread, so a vaccine for one country, say Australia, may not work in the US / China / UK… , so returning to international travel is not as simple as we might think. That said, apparently COVID-19 doesn’t have a high mutation rate, so a global vaccine may be a good option over herd immunity.In Australia and NZ, we’re choosing option 1, but we all know we’re really counting on option 3 to come through. The timing is currently looking like January 2021 for a vaccine, but see above, I’m not in medicine, just following reports around the world. Great that the global community of scientists are working together and sharing results and no one is looking to monetise that vaccine (at this time). There will be an issue/ relapse if one country has successfully halted the spread prior to a vaccine (through option 1), and then opening their international borders causes new influx of the disease to that otherwise “cleared” country. I think a number of countries will either ban or require proof / testing of inbound travellers, especially from the USA and other high COVID-19 case countries. Separately, not mentioned above, is a cure (potentially an option 4). If the plasma from recovered patients can act as a treatment for current cases, this could slow down the impact of the spread and the overwhelming of hospitals (assuming patients can recover more quickly than without the plasma or other developed cure). So now I’m thinking it’s time to donate more plasma, even though (I don’t think) I’ve had the virus! Hope others reading may do the same.

When we find a cure (a vaccine won’t do it - we’ve known the basics of vaccination for 224 years [Edward Jenner - 1796] and so far have defeated one whole virus - smallpox). Or when we lock the country down, except for required business (not the “I need a haircut” kind, the “there’s no food left in my house” kind, or the “I have 5 gallons of heating oil left and it’s 20 degrees outside” kind). Then a few months of lockdown. And a working contact tracing system all through it. And mandatory masks, enforced quarantine if anyone is found outside without one. Australia did it. New Zealand did it. We can’t do it? We can. And if the “macho” (read:homicidal) MAGAts can’t do it, they get personal lockdown (called imprisonment) for the duration. Anything short of that and we’ll have the next presidential campaign under threat of COVID-19. And the 2028 campaign. And on and on until we have a cure or we lock down until the curve flattens at zero. (But the longer it takes, the worse the economy gets hit. If we wait long enough, we’ll long for a depression that makes 1929 look like a market correction, because the economy will drop to zero.) That’s when it will end. (With another term for Trump, it ends when we’re all dead. Which would suit him fine. If he dies without going to prison, he “wins”. Even if he dies. His definition of “winning” right now is “dying without having gone to prison”.)

The name of the virus is SARS-COV-2, and the disease is called COVID-19, but the question is otherwise valid and deserving of discussion. A vaccine could end it. Herd immunity (sufficient % of population is immune from having the disease or from effective vaccination) could end it. The needed % is unknown though. The absolute number and rates of deaths relative to population are already in a downtrend. People who have had COVID-19 do develop immunity, although how long the immunity lasts is as yet unknown. There are a small number of re-infected people reported, but most of those who recover seem to have at least some immunity. The number who have been infected is much, much greater than the officially confirmed cases, because many are asymptomatic. The official reporting is not sharing the “good news” Below is a chart available weekly from CDC showing that the US deaths from COVID-19, pneumonia, and influenza combined (the red line) is approaching the threshold to qualify for an epidemic (black lines)  The pandemic (as distinct from the virus itself) could end in 2021 is my sense, but I am not an expert. Note that SARS-Cov-1 from a few years ago has disappeared. A second wave? There was one in the 1918–19 pandemic, but I have not seen anything indicating a second wave is inevitable or even likely. I am taking all precautions to avoid it, but I could be immune naturally or from having had it without knowing. It is scary and real. For planning purposes, one should generally plan for the worst while hoping for the best. As for expectations of what is likely, my layman’s guess, for what it is worth, is the pandemic will be over before the end of 2021. My track record is mixed. I predicted that Trump would be gone as President by the end of 2017. More official CDC charts:

SORRY, IT WILL NEVER END FOR THE WORLD! BUT YOU CAN END IT FOR YOURSELF…. The virus is here to stay. We have to learn to live with it. The lockdown may delay the spread of infection but there should be no illusion that sooner or later we all are going to be infected by it. IT IS INEVITABLE THAT CORONA WILL INFECT AT LEAST 70–80% OF HUMANITY. AND ALSO RESEARCH SO FAR INDICATES THAT ANTIBODIES FORMED BY INFECTIONS/VACCINES WILL NOT BE LONG LASTING. SO IT WILL KEEP INFECTING PEOPLE AGAIN AND AGAIN. There is however a choice of what will happen when we have to face the virus inside our body. We can either overpower it with a well-coordinated response from our Immune System or succumb to it and die eventually. Yes! The choice is ours. All we need is a well balanced immune system to tackle the coronavirus and end the fear of it forever. However, immune system is not built in a day. It takes continuous efforts and a well aligned mind-body-spirit connection to make it happen. Begin working on it right away. Some essential tips: Go for a nutrient-rich diet. An easy way to have a multi-nutrient rich diet is to have a “rainbow diet” - the food on your table should be colourful. Drink lots of water, preferably warm. Eat food that is easily digestible and good for your digestion. Gut microbiome is 70% of our immune system.Have a quality Sleep every day. Quality sleep means following the circadian rhythm, sleeping at least 7–8 hours every day and having deep sleep.Exercises. Do them regularly and for a minimum of 20–30 minutes every day. Do anything that suits you but remember, walking is not really an exercise although it is helpful in general. Don’t overexercise or strain yourself in the beginning otherwise, it can weaken immunity rather than strengthening it.It’s extremely important to do meditation if you want to reduce stress arising from the job, business, finances, personal problems and media. Stress is very harmful and derails all our efforts to bring in harmony in life. If you are not the meditating type, just close your eyes and take conscious deep breaths for at least 10 minutes. It is a good substitute for meditation.Avoid drugs, alcohol and other addictive substances. They damage not only mind and body but spirit too. Let the mind, body and spirit remain undamaged.Do breathing exercises. Pranayama is well recommended. It helps eliminate toxins from the body.For more information about the pandemic and on dealing with it, you can read my book Be an Immunity Warrior which talks in-depth about how we can lead a complete holistic life, free from all pathologies.

I think the pandemic will end with every country (hopefully) adopting Taiwan’s model of how to deal with future pandemics. Their response has been the most successful and they have been ready to deal with a pandemic since their population suffered the first SARS. The people of Taiwan were open to their personal data being required for the purpose of containing this pandemic as they didn’t want a repeat of the first SARS. It worked. When this pandemic ends I think we will need to ask ourselves, will we be willing to do the same (re our privacy) after this, so our countries don’t have to go through this again if we copy Taiwan’s prep model in the future… In comparison China’s draconian measures contained it only in the area of the breakout - so now how do they control it where it is yet to break out amongst the other 99% of their population in the next 12–18 months? (btw no democracy would tolerate China’s method of citizens’ civil liberties being taken away in the same manner). I think it will be most of 2020 we will be dealing with restrictions to our lifestyles, maybe with periods of easing and then lockdown re-occurring depending on the expon. curve readings of each country at any given time. And I think we all have to surrender to the current facts, accept it so we can deal with it with gratefulness that we have a procedure to follow to “slow-the-flow”. The fact is there won’t be a vaccine for 12–18 months … So there are only two choices: as an entire society we all (1) suffer what Italy is going through or (2) we can co-operate now with the lockdowns, etc. and have it spread at lower rates of infection across the year so everyone can get the medical attention they need for both the coronavirus and other medical emergencies/needs. Success rests on each society co-operating as a whole to keep the infection rate to the lower levels so our medical facilities/staff can give treatment to all people until the vaccine is developed. NOW is the most important time to be strict with ourselves in co-operating with lock-downs etc so the additional medical equipment ordered has time to be made and delivered and we flatten those curves. It’s imperative, it’s absolutely necessary and it really is do-able. Being informed of the facts will help all of us to appreciate the importance of why what we do now makes a difference (I highly recommend a very informative podcast “Coronacast” by the Australian’s ABC). I hope this pandemic ends with all politicians more willing to heed and act on the advice of our scientists (and hopefully begins a new era of political parties being made up of more scientists instead of lawyers … or “businessmen”!). Please stay calm because we can, and will, decrease this outbreak … and simply … it’s really not that hard, it will end … stay in, keep distance from others, practice good hygiene. No biggie, we can do this.

Governments will start by making some radical changes to overcome the post COVID-19 economic recession. These would include : Increasing taxes : Obviously, the government will start with the easiest solution. They will increase taxes. They will say that people will have to contribute in order to save their economy, for without their contributions, jobs would be lost and their nation would go broke.Printing money : Did I say that taxes are the easiest way for governments? Actually,… not really! But this one is: Central banks will simply print more money, risking inflation and even worse repercussions to their economies. But let’s hope it doesn’t come to that, and that governments will act responsibly.No more development projects : You know that new highway that was planned for 2022? or the new power plant that was going to feed electricity to half of your city by 2025? Well, you can forget about that for now. The money that will save our critical sectors will have to come from somewhere. Budgets that were allocated for infrastructure and development projects will be transferred to more urgent matters.These measures shouldn’t last long, maybe a couple of years or so. After that, I hope, our economy will be fully recovered from COVID-19. On the other hand, on a more positive note, we might see some good changes. Hopefully, the world nations will start to think about the threats of infectious diseases more seriously. We will see an increase in funds allocated to research about infectious diseases. We might see some positive results from this, from vaccines to new antiviral and antibiotic treatments. We may finally eradicate diseases that have been tormenting large populations for way before COVID-19 : Malaria, Syphilis, Tuberculosis, Polio, HIV…

It will NEVER STOP. it will continue to live on this planet affecting people on this planet forever. The current risk of virus can be mitigated through vaccinating everybody now and newborns in the future, or getting everyone affected today so many can develop antibody and create self immunity against this virus we cant choose any options today, the former because we don't have the vaccine as of today, and the latter because with only 3% fatalities there would be millions of dead body behind.  Lets quickly know something about viruses. They are one of the tiniest and abundant biological entities on the planet. In fact, it is said to contain 10 Million Viruses in a single drop of seawater. Most of them are not fatal to larger mammals and marine life. These viruses engage in microbial interaction and govern the marine ecosystem by maintaining the flow of energy and the cycling of nutrients. There are several other viruses and dominate every ecosystem. Among Virus, only a tiny % is fatal to any given species. Their only goal is to reproduce, so they attack the host cell and trick them to create a copy of themself and eventually breaking down the host. “Viral populations do not grow through cell division, because they are acellular. Instead, they use the machinery and metabolism of a host cell to produce multiple copies of themselves, and they assemble in the cell.” [1]. Among the many fatal ones we had in the past and now said to be eradicated [2] from natural occurrence was Variola virus infecting people with a disease called SmallPox [3] This smallpox evidence can be dated back to 300 BC in mummies and lasted till 1980. Smallpox outbreaks had been mentioned in multiple texts varying in different regions spanning across centuries. So somehow this virus was active in phases creating epidemics and was completely dormant in between. The last case registered on smallpox was in 1975. Although as per WHO although it's eradicated still there are active threats of this virus, we don’t have any cure for this disease, we can prevent this by a vaccine. But a major percentage of people on this planet today are not immune to this virus, because no country any longer vaccinate child because of the risk of the vaccine. So in any case, if the next outbreak occurs there is still a good chance of smallpox epidemic. Corona is very similar to Variola, both spread person to person. The difference is the incubation period and illness. In general, the incubation of Corona is 2–14 days, averaging around 5 days but it is ready for transmission effective immediately. The incubation for Variola is around 12–17 days and not ready for transmission until a week. So the difference is the Corona source could look healthy and transmitting disease without showing symptoms on the host, whereas, whenever the smallpox host was ready for transmission the symptoms were clearly visible.  With 3% fatality only, it is not as fatal as Ebola or Variola etc, with current medical advances of the 21st century we can save almost everyone from corona, but the major problem today is the sheer volume of patients, no nation can cater services if the patients are brought more the infrastructure available. This is the case in Italy, USA, Spain etc. We have to learn something from the past, we had controlled such a scenario in the past by controlling the transmission, ie by Quarantine and social distancing. By locking down the people for some weeks, the transmission chain will break and the new exposure curve will become flat and it will be easy to provide medical assistance to the remaining ones who are infected. I see a few of scenarios, only one of the sane ones is short. We hold out for a vaccine and one is successfully created. It is tested and shown to be efficacious and we start disseminating it sometime in 2021. Everyone gets the shot, it provides some period of immunity, the novel coronavirus is starved of fresh meat and that’s that. For years afterwards anyone who wants to visit the US gets tested as they enter the country to prove they are clear. Regular revaccinations (if it turns out the immunity is short-lived) and testing would become the new norm.We hold out for a vaccine, it turns out it’s not possible (there’s never been a successful coronavirus vaccine). After two or three years of trying and failing it’s is declared impossible and people have to choose whether to live in a bubble for the rest of their lives or take their chances. Perhaps some system is created so people take their turn “coming our” so the hospital system isn’t overrun by people all exposing themselves at once.This is the one possible short-term solution: We suck it up as a nation and do what China did, lock everyone except the truly essential down and test the heck out of those still running what’s left of the economy. After six or eight weeks the virus should be eradicated, again because there’s no source of new bodies to infect. As with (1) we would have to be extremely aggressive about testing anyone entering the country as one new infection and it all starts over again. There would be breakouts, there would have to be a hair trigger on regionally re-locking down to keep things clean.I suppose this one is short too — there’s a collective shrug of “screw it” and everyone just comes out of shelter, lots of people die or are disabled for life due to lung and/or brain damage.

Seasonality of SARS-CoV-2: Will COVID-19 go away on its own in warmer weather? Marc Lipsitch, DPhilProfessor of Epidemiology and Director, Center for Communicable Disease Dynamics, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health (tl;dr) Probably not. Several people, including the US president, have suggested that the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and the disease it causes, COVID-19, will go away on its own in the warmer weather that will come in the Northern Hemisphere in coming months. Some have even suggested that the experience with SARS in 2003 provides evidence for this assertion. The short answer is that while we may expect modest declines in the contagiousness of SARS-CoV-2 in warmer, wetter weather and perhaps with the closing of schools in temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere, it is not reasonable to expect these declines alone to slow transmission enough to make a big dent. Before making the positive case for my assertions, let me start by busting some myths. Myth 1: In 2003, SARS went away on its own as the weather got warmer.SARS did not die of natural causes. It was killed by extremely intense public health interventions in mainland Chinese cities, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Thailand, Canada and elsewhere. These involved isolating cases, quarantining their contacts, a measure of “social distancing,” and other intensive efforts. These worked well for SARS because those who were most infectious were also quite ill in a distinctive way — the sick cases were the transmitters, so isolating the sick curbed transmission. In Toronto, SARS resurged after the initial wave was controlled and precautions were discontinued. This resurgence was eventually linked to a case from the first wave. The resurgence confirms that it was control measures that stopped transmission the first time. Myth 2: The “common cold” coronaviruses are seasonal, with little transmission in the summer, so SARS-CoV-2 will be too.Predicting how a novel virus will behave based on how others behave is always speculative, but sometimes we have to do so when we have little else to go on. So the first problem with this myth is that we don’t know whether those coronaviruses, which go by the evocative names like OC43, HKU1, 229E, and NL63, are good analogies for this virus. Still, it is worth considering the analogy especially to OC43 and HKU1, which are SARS-CoV2’s closest relatives among the seasonal coronaviruses. The other reason this is a myth is that seasonal viruses that have been in the population for a long time (like OC43 and HKU1) behave differently from viruses that are newly introduced into the population. To understand why, it helps to understand what we know about why many respiratory viruses are winter-seasonal in temperate regions like most of the USA. Scientists have identified four factors that contribute to this phenomenon. For some viruses, we have evidence for which factors are most important, for others, we have to extrapolate. Factor 1: The environment.In the winter, the outdoor air is colder, and the air is dryer usually both indoors and out. For influenza, it has been elegantly shown in the lab that absolute humidity — the quantity of water vapor in the air — strongly affects flu transmission, with drier conditions being more favorable. Subsequently it has been shown that epidemiological patterns are consistent with this lab data in the US and in Vietnam, among other study sites. Notably the Vietnam study looked at influenza-like illness, without distinguishing influenza from other types of pathogens. This hints that similar mechanisms may be at work for other respiratory viruses, but to my knowledge are no specific studies of the role of humidity for coronaviruses or other respiratory viruses besides flu. Also important: there may be some very humid conditions that also favor flu transmission, especially relevant in the tropics. Still it is safe to say that in temperate countries, dry cold air = favorable conditions for flu transmission. For coronaviruses, the relevance of this factor is unknown. A recent preprint on which I collaborated suggests that transmission is possible in many different climates, and points out that Singapore, for example, which lies nearly on the equator, has had significant transmission. This is one piece of evidence, but as my colleague Dr. Eli Perencevich has pointed out there are many differences between Singapore in February and a temperate zone in summer — different day length, ultraviolet radiation, and other factors that may be important for coronavirus – we simply don’t know. Factor 2: Human behavior.In the winter humans spend more time indoors with less ventilation and less personal space than outdoors in the summer. In particular, schools are a site of much infectious disease transmission. School terms have been strongly identified as periods of higher transmission for respiratory viruses including those causing chicken pox, measles, and flu (here and here). The 2009 pandemic flu in the United States was very much decreased during the summer, and then came back rapidly in September. The relevance of school terms is important but unknown for the SARS-CoV-2. Few children have been identified as cases. This may mean they do not get easily infected and don’t do much transmitting. Or it may mean only that they don’t get severe symptoms when they are infected, and transmit nonetheless. Or something in between. Understanding this is key if we want to know whether school closures can help control COVID-19 spread, as well as to anticipate how much summer vacation may help reduce spread. Factor 3: The host’s immune system.It is possible that the condition of the average person’s immune system is systematically worse in winter than summer. One hypothesis has focused on melatonin which has some immune effects and is modulated by the photoperiod, which varies seasonally. Another with more evidence is that vitamin D levels, which depend in part on ultraviolet light exposure (higher in summer) modulate our immune system in a positive way. The best evidence for the relevance of this hypothesis is that vitamin D supplementation reduces the incidence of acute respiratory infection, according to a meta-analysis of randomized trials. On the other hand, we found that this effect was unlikely to be a large factor in the variation in influenza incidence between summer and winter. This is a promising area for more study but at present its relevance seems uncertain. Factor 4: Depletion of susceptible hosts.Even without any seasonal variability, infectious disease epidemics rise exponentially, level off, and decline because when many individuals are susceptible, each case infects more than one new case (R eff > 1). Then as the proportion of susceptible contacts declines, the epidemic peaks (R eff = 1), and eventually declines (R eff < 1). When there is some factor (like any or all of #s 1-3) varying seasonally, and when new susceptibles appear in the population over time (for example through births) this process interacts with the seasonal factors to produce recurrent epidemics typically at the same time each year. This leads us to the last point: Even seasonal infections can happen “out of season” when they are new.New viruses have a temporary but important advantage – few or no individuals in the population are immune to them. Old viruses, which have been in the population for longer, operate on a thinner margin — most individuals are immune, and they have to make do with transmitting among the few who aren’t. In simple terms, viruses that have been around for a long time can make a living — spread through the population — only when the conditions are the most favorable, in this case in winter. The consequence is that new viruses — like pandemic influenza — can spread outside the normal season for their longer-established cousins. For example in 2009, the pandemic started in April-May (well outside of flu season), quieted in the summer (perhaps because of the importance of children in transmission of flu), and then rebounded in September-October, before the start of normal flu season. Seasonality does not constrain pandemic viruses the way it does old ones. This pattern is common for flu pandemics. So in summary:For the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, we have reason to expect that like other betacoronaviruses, it may transmit somewhat more efficiently in winter than summer, though we don’t know the mechanism(s) responsible. The size of the change is expected to be modest, and not enough to stop transmission on its own. Based on the analogy of pandemic flu, we expect that SARS-CoV-2, as a virus new to humans, will face less immunity and thus transmit more readily even outside of the winter season. Changing seasons and school vacation may help, but are unlikely to stop transmission. Urgent for effective policy is to determine if children are important transmitters, in which case school closures may help slow transmission, or not, in which case resources would be wasted in such closures. Previously it was thought children were not easily infected with SARS-CoV-2. Recent evidence from Shenzhen suggests that children may be infected and shed detectable virus at about the same rate as adults — so now the only question is whether they transmit as readily. It seems likely the answer is yes, but no data as of this writing to my knowledge. Seasonality of SARS-CoV-2: Will COVID-19 go away on its own in warmer weather?

If by “stop” you mean “eradicate” then quite probably the answer is “never.” Eradicating a virus is a time-consuming and tricky thing. It’s possible (because it has been done before), but there are a lot of factors that play. You need a virus that doesn’t mutate much, you need a good vaccine, you need a global population that both has access to and a sufficient willingness to take said vaccine and you need time. With Coronavirus, I don’t think we yet know how mutable it is. We don’t have a vaccine yet. We certainly are a long way from having any potential vaccine globally available. And most importantly we have an increasing number of people, globally, that for a variety of reasons - some legitimate and some plain stupid - will resist the idea of taking whatever vaccine may be developed. Based on all that, I’m rather pessimistic that this virus will be eradicated. That said, I think it’s reasonable to assume that as we learn more about it and develop vaccines and treatments the impact of Coronavirus will substantially diminish. My guess on that would be 12–24 months before we start seeing a major reduction in impact. But that’s just a guess. Caveat and full disclaimer. I am not a doctor nor an epidemiologist. Everything I said is an opinion and should be taken with a substantial grain of salt. I pay attention, am interested in this stuff and read about it some, so I feel broadly good about my opinion, but it is only that. At the time of this post, no qualified expert has provided an answer. When some do, please toss my opinion out the window and go with what the pros say.

This will reduce the pressure on health industry, providing more time for the healthcare providers to treat the ongoing cases. In the context of India, I would like to say that we have two major challenges at hand due to which a 21 day lockdown may not be enough and needs to be extended. These include: 1.Mass migration of labourers across the nation. 2.People violating the quarantine protocols. First of all, please get educated about how exponential growth works. You are still observing a spike in cases because these are the people who were infected around 10–14 days before the lockdown and so the cases are coming up now only. Secondly, this will keep rising in the coming weeks because the asymptomatic carriers would have infected their family members and other people they came in contact with by now. Let's support each other and save millions from dying.

In less than a month, cases of contamination have increased from 10000 to 700,000. 3,793 dead in the United States in 24 hours! 100,000 new cases recorded in 4 days.  Towards a global pandemic? "Whether it appears in nature or in the hands of a terrorist, epidemiologists say that an airborne pathogen that spreads rapidly can kill 30 million people in less than a year," the billionaire told an annual meeting of world diplomats. "And it is quite likely," he said, "that the world will have to experience such an epidemic in the next 10 to 15 years, so we are putting ourselves at risk by ignoring the link between health security and international security. Bill Gates had called on governments to invest in research to develop technologies capable of creating vaccines in a matter of months. He was right, here we go. But I don't think the current pandemic will be overcome in a few months. We have survived epidemics that were infinitely more serious, at times when people did not know what a virus was. However, because of global warming, we can expect much more virulent epidemics. As soon as the corona virus has been defeated, strategies will have to be developed to deal with these potential new enemies, which are invisible but infinitely dangerous . What I think of the current pandemic People must become aware that everyone is concerned about this danger and that this pandemic hides others, perhaps infinitely more disastrous. Summary of the current situation: Example of China: out of a population of 1300,000,000 inhabitants, there are about 82,000 cases of contaminated people. That is 0.0063% of the population concerned. Because we have not yet reached the inflection point. And there is no systematic screening because we don't have the means and equipment. (parties, inappropriate meetings ...) ***Measures, it's everybody's business. *** The drastic measures were explained in the media: - No gatherings (cultural or sporting or other events); - Closure of schools ; - Respect the distances (2m) in public places. - Coughing, sneezing in the elbow ; (disposable handkerchief) - Avoid contact with persons at risk ; - Wash your hands often; - Stay as short as possible in public places (shopping malls ..) - Wear a mask if symptoms appear; - No physical contact between people (handshakes, hugs ...); - Regular disinfection of affected elements by the population (handles, etc.) in public places including public transport, at the workplace. - Contact your doctor if contamination is suspected. - Healthy people can be vectors of the virus. - Avoid understandable emotional behavior such as excessive grocery shopping.
