2021–2022 at the earliest. There’s two ways for this to end so it’s over: Vaccine. Develop an effective one; manufacture it in the billions of doses; administer the billions of doses; and wait for it to do work. Hopefully, it will be developed (the track record for successful vaccines is not very good) and hopefully it will work better than the flu vaccine, which still does not stop all flu viruses.Herd Immunity. Since there are so many recorded instances of patients with COVID-19 getting it a second time, it does not appear that we can count on 60–70% of the population getting it and developing herd immunity.More likely than COVID-19 being “over,” it will probably be a disease we learn to live with, to work around, to keep going through our routines despite it still being here threatening our health and well being. We will have Hot Spots where people will need to self isolate for a few weeks until the contagion is quelled, and then things will go back to the new normal. We will adapt; we always do. And because this will not be acceptable, we will work on treatments so that we can get it to an acceptable level, much the way we handle cancer.

It’s not that easy. You have to understand a bit about how epidemics work, to see why though. One of the biggest factors in how an outbreak spreads is the R0 rate — the basic reproductive rate. It’s the average number of people that 1 infected person will infect themselves. If lower than 1, the disease will almost always not trigger an epidemic. It can’t sustain itself — it’s the same idea behind countries needing to have a replacement rate of >~2 babies per couple to sustain a population. If they don’t, then your population will slowly decrease as people die off. With a virus, people usually die or become immune to it. So unless the virus is infecting more people than it is killing/immunizing, it won’t go anywhere. On the other hand, if R0 > 1, the replacement rate is exponential, and you have yourself an epidemic. With some viruses, if the symptoms are not serious enough to the point where the host (human) can continue going out into the world, go to work/school/etc, the R0 is usually higher. If the human has been knocked on their ass and is laying in bed for the duration of the entire virus, that’s less people to infect that they’re coming into contact with. Unfortunately, COVID-19 is right in that goldilocks spot — serious enough to have a ~3.4% fatality rate (which is pretty high) but not serious enough to cause young, 20–40 year old people to call in sick for work, cuz they really need that paycheck. What if the waiter that served you your food yesterday has COVID-19 but won’t be able to pay rent if she doesn’t go to work? Methinks you’re gonna get infected too. Another important metric is how close people are in proximity to each other and how often they interact (as well as how the virus spreads). On one end of the extreme, if everybody stayed in their house 24/7, the virus would have nowhere to go. But that’s not how modern society works. This is usually measured in “adequate contacts per day” where an adequate contact is a contact between an infected person and an uninfected person that produces an infection in the second party. The more people that the average person interacts with on any given day, the higher this contact rate will be. To illustrate how effective viruses can be at spreading when the “contact rate” is high, I want to talk to you about the Samy virus — not a human virus, but rather an internet virus that took hold of MySpace in late 2005. Some guy wrote a harmless little virus that changes a MySpace user’s status to “Samy is my hero” and would send Samy himself a friend request. Then, when another user viewer an infected user’s homepage, that user would also be infected with the “Samy is my hero” tag line. Pretty harmless, but it spread at a devastating pace. How quickly did this virus spread? I mean, it required active participation — users would have to actively view someone’s page for the virus to spread. Would you be surprised if I told you that within 20 hours of the virus going live, it had infected 1 million people on MySpace? Our modern world is pretty interconnected, both physically and on the internet, which makes us susceptible to both physical viruses as well as internet-borne cyber-viruses. Samy serves as a useful lesson in the risks of a globally intertwined world. So how long will this COVID-19 epidemic last? We don’t know. It’s hard to assess exactly what the R0 rate is, or how long the virus lasts, or what proportion of people are staying home from work, or if combative techniques such as vaccines will be helpful. There’s simply too many unknowns that affect the duration of the epidemic. It is safe to say that the epidemic will pass, though. It might be bad, but it’s not going to cause an apocalypse. The best advice is to be careful, wash your hands, and listen to the instructions from healthcare officials.

Short answer: At least until May and maybe June Long answer: Below is a document sent today to my family, friends, and colleagues on the evolution of the coronavirus pandemic in each country and the estimated containment times. Evolution of the Covid-19 Pandemic as of March 24, 2020 By Patrick Crosset, statistician-economist Barcelona March 24, 2020 This document is an update to a document released on March 20. New countries, new indicators, new developments and country-to-country comparisons are added. The dates of end of confinement and the estimates of death on these dates are updated. It has been 3 months since the Coronavirus appeared on a Chinese market in Wuhan to spread today 196 countries around the world. We now know that several million people, even tens of millions, have been infected with this virus (the 383,000 cases recorded are only a tiny part of the number of real cases). These underestimates vary from country to country: from low for South Korea to very high for Italy or Spain, which each have at least one million people infected. So to make statistics on cases declared by the authorities makes no sense: a country that will do massive screening like South Korea cannot be compared to a country like Spain which reserves its tests for the most affected patients . Unfortunately, the only statistical indicator that is not misleading is the number of deaths. We will use below the data as of March 23, those of March 24 are still incomplete. The number of “gross” deaths In the ranking of the 12 most affected countries in terms of death toll, Italy has overtaken China since March 19, and Spain has passed Iran since March 23. In countries with 200 or more deaths, the highest percentage growth in the number of deaths between March 19 and 23 was in Spain: + 178%. Spain is likely to overtake China in number of deaths on March 25; it will then be the second most affected country in the world.  Evolution of the number of deaths from March 19 to March 23 in the 12 most affected countries:  The number of deaths reported to the population It’s a more relevant indicator because it takes into account the demographic size of the country. For this we will use the number of deaths per million inhabitants. With this ratio, two countries are significantly more affected than the others on March 23: ● Italy with 97 deaths per 1 million inhabitants ● Spain with 46 deaths per 1 million inhabitants A l’intérieur de chaque pays, il peut y avoir des divergences importantes selon les zones. Ainsi en Espagne, ce ratio est de 233 par million d’habitants dans la Communauté de Madrid et « seulement » de 10 par million d’habitants en Andalousie. Within each country, there can be significant differences depending on the area. In Spain, this ratio is 233 per million inhabitants in the Community of Madrid and "only" 10 per million inhabitants in Andalusia. Four other countries are relatively affected: ● Iran with 21 death per 1 million inhabitants ● Switzerland with 14 deaths per 1 million inhabitants ● France with 13 deaths for 1 million inhabitants ● The Netherlands with 12 deaths per 1 million inhabitants Belgium (8 deaths per 1 million inhabitants) and Great Britain (5 deaths per 1 million inhabitants) will be within a week at the same level of mortality as the countries in the above group. For the moment, the other 4 countries (China, South Korea, Germany, United States) do not exceed 2 deaths per million inhabitants. This ratio: ● should not evolve for China and South Korea, ● could slowly evolve for Germany ● evolve faster for the USA Evolution of deaths by country In order to be able to make this comparative analysis between the 12 main countries affected, we chose as the initial date for each the day when the number of deaths reached the number of 17. This was in ascending order of dates: ● January 22 for China (17 deaths) ● February 26 for Iran (19 deaths) ● February 27 for Italy (17 deaths) ● February 29 for South Korea (17 deaths) ● March 7 for the USA (19 deaths) ● March 8 for Spain (17 deaths) ● March 8 for France (19 deaths) ● March 14 for Great Britain (21 deaths) ● March 15 for the Netherlands (20 deaths) ● March 16 for Germany (17 deaths) ● March 16 for Switzerland (19 deaths) ● March 19 for Belgium (21 deaths) How did the number of deaths evolve from these dates? IMPORTANT: all the analyzes below are made from the dates mentioned above, that is to say the dates when there were at least 17 deaths in each country. If we analyze the first 10 days from the above dates, Spain is the country with the highest growth in the number of deaths (533 deaths on the 10th day) ahead of Great Britain (335 at 10th day), Italy (233 to 10th day) and… France (175 to 10th day). As a reminder, China was at 259 deaths on the 10th day, Iran at 124 and South Korea at 53. On the first 16 days, the gap widens between Spain (2311 deaths on the 16th day), Italy (1266 on the 16th day) and France (860 on the 16th day). As a reminder, China was at 636 deaths on the 16th day, Iran at 429 and South Korea at 75. Among the twelve countries most affected, only one stands out for the very slow growth in the number of deaths, it is South Korea: on the 24th day, there were 43 times more deaths in Italy than in South Korea, ! Why ? South Korea learned from past mistakes, including SARS in 2003 and MERS in 2015, and started industrial production of screening kits early and chose a systematic screening policy. The stick is also used: if you break the quarantine, it will cost you a fine… of 2300 euros! It is also the policy successfully implemented by Taiwan with only 2 deaths per 23 million inhabitants!  How soon will the increase be reduced depending on the country and how long will the confinement last? If we take the Chinese example, sixty days now since the 17th death, we can estimate the slowdown points of the rise. But if and only if the confinements are respected as they were respected in China. ● The first slowdown occurred in China on the 26th day after reaching 17 deaths ● The second slowdown occurred on the 34th day after reaching 17 deaths ● The third slowdown occurred on the 50th day after reaching 17 deaths  Notice on the graph above the much faster increase in the number of deaths in Italy and Spain than in China. In Great Britain too, but we don't see it yet. South Korea has contained the virus and the death toll in that country is not expected to exceed 300. We predicted on March 19 that Italy should reach the first slowdown point between March 23 and 28. And since March 22, the number of deaths has been decreasing in Italy (see the graph below). However, it is still necessary to wait a few days for this drop to be confirmed. Normally the second slowdown point should arrive in late March / early April and the third in the second half of April. At the end of April, the number of deaths in Italy should be between 10,000 and 15,000.  Spain is expected to reach the first slowdown in early April, then the second in mid-April and the third in mid-May. At the end of May, the number of deaths in Spain could exceed 15,000, and even 20,000. It will be the most affected country in Europe and certainly in the world. Madrid is also expected to be the city with the highest number of deaths in the world. If we compare Spain with Italy, the most affected country, we can clearly see that mortality is much higher in Spain in the first days after the 17th death. If it continues like this, Spain should be the first country to exceed 1,000 deaths a day. The Spanish situation is very worrying and, to avoid a health disaster, particularly in Madrid, it seems necessary that the Spanish government requests massive external aid in health care and equipment, why not from China.  Iran reached the first slowdown point on March 20 (we predicted it between March 23 and 28). The second should be in early April and the third in the second half of April. At the end of April, the number of deaths in Iran could exceed 3,000. France should reach the first slowdown point in early April, then the second in mid-April and the third in mid-May. At the end of May, the number of deaths in France could exceed 5,000. The United States is beginning to extend containment measures throughout its territory. According to the States, they should reach the first slowdown point from the beginning of mid-April, then the second from mid-April to the end of April and the third from mid-May to the end of May. At the end of May, the number of deaths in the USA could exceed 5,000. Note the strange correlation between the evolution of deaths in the United States and in Iran! It’s obviously a coincidence.  Great Britain has had containment measures in place since yesterday. The trend in the death toll was worrying in recent days: worse than the first days of Italy! It is difficult to give trends because the confinement is too recent. The number of deaths should be at least 10,000. The Netherlands does not apply strict containment. It is likely that it is therefore difficult to assess the trend in the number of deaths. Germany and Switzerland have a parallel evolution. Systematic screening and containment have reduced mortality more there than in other European countries. The total number of deaths does not exceed 120 to 23 March and the trend seems to be under control. In two months, the number of deaths should not exceed 500 in each of these two countries. The data for Belgium is still too recent, but the development is quite worrying. Confinement in Europe and the USA will last at least until May, and maybe end of May, beginning June. Some additional graphics for the most affected European countries  First 16 days:  First 10 days:   © Any partial or total reproduction is authorized with mention of the source below: Evolution of the Covid-19 Pandemic as of March 24, 2020 – Patrick Crosset The statistics analyzed in this document come from the worldometers- coronavirus website.

The world hasn't come across a pandemic as impactful as the COVID-19 in decades. The global population has been understandably scared. The uncertainty of death striking any person in the world cannot be disregarded. Everything has come to a halt. In tough times like these, people can only keep their fingers crossed and hope for life to get back to normal sooner rather than later. But is this pandemic going to end anytime soon? The only way to win over a plague like the COVID-19 is to eradicate the virus completely. Nationwide lockdowns can maybe curb the spread of the virus and stop it from multiplying in number, but can’t guarantee a COVID-free world. So, there arises a need to find a vaccine ASAP. Update on the vaccine for COVID-19 From the moment this pandemic gained global attention, scientists in various countries (almost all countries) have been trying to develop a vaccine. The most successful one yet is the vaccine being developed by the University of Oxford in collaboration with the UK pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca. They have found out that the virus has a specific “spike protein” which helps in an easier penetration into the cells and have been working on developing a drug to stop this. The results of the test trials have been positive till now. The vaccine helps the body build antibodies against the “spike protein”, thereby increasing the immunity. Moreover, it has also shown to increase the number of T-cells in the body that help destroy the infected cells. Side-effects to the vaccine till now Some people were observed to have reactions like mild fever, muscle ache, and headache which are being treated with prophylactic paracetamol for the time being. What next? This might be the ultimate vaccine, or scientists might develop a better vaccine. However, once a vaccine is found, it’s distribution among the global population would still be an issue. Hence, an extensive distribution strategy would be required to vaccinate the world population. Practically, it would take at least a few years to completely eradicate the virus. But instead of letting this fact worry us, let’s just be optimistic and hope that the day everything comes back to normal isn't far away.

This virus is highly infectious. A virus (and by extension a viral infection) will 'fade out' when it will not find a live-body to multiply. As long as you have a live-body with virus multiplying in it, the world would find it difficult to get rid of this disease. How can we tackle the virus (Prevention & Cure) Cure: We can’t make a cure overnight (it takes years to make one!!). If some already-being-used medicines can cross-protect (like hydroxychloroquine) then it will help. However it will still require some ‘experiments’ on humans to confirm it. All medicines have some side effects, essentially a medicine is a good balance between effects & side effects. So till results are out we can only hope that, we find something really good, from our current medicines. Prevention: 1. Vaccination: The best strategy is vaccination. Essentially you intentionally infect the body with a weak-disease causing virus. Like polio vaccines are actually polio viruses, but very weak and so unable to cause polio. Once the body ‘fights’ these weak-viruses it becomes ‘ready’ for real viruses. So can we make vaccines? Yes we can. But, it will take more than a year to reach there. Then also we would not know how effective that vaccine will be. Remember we do not have a HIV vaccine even after 30 plus years of research. 2. Social distancing: In absence of a vaccine, the best strategy would be social distancing. This will not allow the virus to have a ‘fresh-live-body’ to multiply. Therefore once all the infected people are treated, this virus will become history. What are probable outcomes. Next two months (i.e., by the end of June 2020) will be very critical, personally I think the present lockdown may continue till June end. I hope situation will improve by that time. Otherwise, after that the question will be whether to die from virus or hunger. So it might be unmanageable to continue the lockdown. It might take one & a haIf years to defeat this virus and it might become usual, walking with masks & full body protection (polythene-raincoat like), while going on with our daily-lives till we overcome this virus. Basically, it might just change the world as we know it. Optimistic thoughts/perspective: it may do just nothing to 70% of us & 95% might survive it even under worst case scenarios. When will this end Best case scenario: Two-months lockdown, and hopefully coronavirus is history. Worst case scenario: Only God can answer that. Also we will need a lot of him/her. Moderate case: One & a half years. We will have a vaccine &/or a cure. Being an optimist, I hope for the best. Looking forward to meeting you in not-so-distant-future, breathing freely without any fear! Till then take care my friend. Stay safe.

By mid-2021, hopefully, the pandemic will be largely under control. There are over 80 vaccine candidates being developed all over the world. We gonna have vaccines ready by this year end.  According to China's Xinhua News Agency, four Chinese COVID-19 vaccine candidates have started international phase-3 clinical trials. Some of the phase-3 trials are expected to complete the first round of vaccinations in early September, with preliminary data expected as early as November.  Phase-3 clinical trials usually involve thousands of people to verify the safety and effectiveness of the vaccines, which are key to their market approval. As the epidemic has been under control in China, the country no longer has conditions for large-scale clinical trials, so all the phase-3 trials are being carried out overseas. Two inactivated COVID-19 vaccines developed by the China National Biotec Group (CNBG) have been approved for phase-3 clinical trials in several countries in the Middle East and South America, involving more than 30,000 people. An inactivated COVID-19 vaccine developed by Sinovac Biotech Co., Ltd. is undergoing phase-3 clinical trials in some countries in South America and Southeast Asia. A recombinant COVID-19 vaccine with the modified defective adenovirus as the vector is also undergoing phase-3 trials. According to a guideline for the clinical evaluation of COVID-19 vaccines recently released by the National Medical Products Administration, the vaccine should provide immunity for at least six months, preferably for more than a year. Let's hope that the vaccines are available ASAP. It's really difficult to wait. :(

No one knows exactly when Covid-19 will stop. But surely we can help each other by taking some precautions. Recently we heard that people are doing social gatherings without wearing masks and maintaining social distancing. It is completely wrong to do such tasks in pandemic because if everyone will follow the same then we won’t be able to stop or control Covid-19 from spreading. In India, there are so many people who don’t even have sufficient knowledge about Covid-19. WHO (World Health Organization) is also advising people to stay at home and look after their physical and mental health. Here are some steps that can be taken to stay safe: Wash hands frequently: Clean your hands regularly and thoroughly with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer or wash them with soap and water. Maintain Social Distancing: Maintain a distance of at least 1 meter between yourself and the one who is sneezing or coughing. Take precautions while travelling: Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth in public places as your hands touch many surfaces which can be contaminated with virus. Once your hands get contaminated they can transfer the virus to your eye, nose or mouth and can make you sick. Always wear a face mask when you are outside. Practice Respiratory Hygiene: Make sure that you and the people nearby you are practicing good respiratory hygiene which means covering mouth and nose with a tissue or bent elbow while coughing or sneezing. Also, throw the used tissue in a dustbin. Stay Updated with Current Updates: Stay informed about the current updates of Covid-19. Avoid going to the places with confirmed cases of Covid-19. Now the most important thing that everybody should have knowledge is that India has very limited healthcare facilities. So, if the Covid-19 will spread in a larger amount our healthcare system will not have the capacity to serve so many patients. Take care of the elders and the children in your family as their immunity is very low to fight with Covid-19. Tips to Gain Immunity 1. Have a diet rich in fruits and vegetables 2. Eat garlic and ginger. 3. Quit smoking and tobacco. 4. Drink a lot of water. 5. Exercise regularly. 6. Practice yoga to minimize stress. 7. Gargle with warm water If you want to stop the spread of Covid-19, follow proper safety guidelines and stay at home.

Nobody actually knows when this virus will face its death. Although, there are a few ways to learn to live with it. Herd Immunity ApproachWhen most of a population is immune to an infectious disease, this provides indirect protection or herd immunity to those who are not immune to the disease. For example, if 80% of a population is immune to a virus, four out of every five people who encounter someone with the disease won’t get sick (and won’t spread the disease any further). In this way, the spread of infectious diseases is kept under control. Depending how contagious an infection is, usually 70% to 90% of a population needs immunity to achieve herd immunity. Measles, mumps, polio, and chickenpox are examples of infectious diseases that were once very common but are now rare because vaccines helped to establish herd immunity. We sometimes see outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases in communities with lower vaccine coverage because they don’t have herd protection. For infections without a vaccine, even if many adults have developed immunity because of prior infection, the disease can still circulate among children and can still infect those with weakened immune systems. This was seen for many of the aforementioned diseases before vaccines were developed. Other viruses (like the flu) mutate over time, so antibodies from a previous infection provide protection for only a short period of time. For the flu, this is less than a year. If SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is like other coronaviruses that currently infect humans, we can expect that people who get infected will be immune for months to years, but probably not their entire lives. 2. Vaccine  When the vaccination trials on humans become successful, there will be a big hope! Current update on vaccines: There are over 110 prospective projects in works to find a workable cure for SARS-CoV-19 which spread from a wet market in Wuhan in December last year. Some have reached the clinical trial stage, others have shown a little less than favourable results. Leading researchers are still saying that it can be another 14-18 months before the world gets to access a vaccine. The same is the case with Indian vaccine, as experts say that it is still in the nascent stage and it will take a while before we see conclusive development. Vaccines require a lot of crucial studies, phases of trials to test out potential side-effects to test its safety, feasibility and cost. Status: Moderna's RNA vaccine Moderna's RNA vaccine, which is amongst the top frontrunners in the race is set to move into the second phase of the clinical trials in the month of July. The company, which makes use of a novel mRNA sequence fights the infected proteins and carries instructions to the body to deploy neccessary antibodies to fight against the infection. Moderna Inc. has successfully finished stage 1 of the clinical trial, where it has reported promising positive results on atleast 8 candidates who developed protective antibodies against coronavirus. Chinese CanSino Biologics Inc vaccine The strongest new contender in the global vaccine race has been touted as the vaccine developed by CanSino Biologics Inc from China. Studies conducted so far have claimed that the vaccine, which has surpassed the human testing phase appeared to be safe. The report which has been tabled is based on a Lancet study which drew observations from an early trial conducted on humans in several laboratories, based on 108 participants aged between 18-60. The vaccine was made with a certain mutation of a virus, named Ad5, which genetically modifies the protein structure once injected inside the cell. Once the body identifies, the virus is able to break down the molecule and stop it from further multiplying. The study also shows that the vaccine injection could possibly help the body's immunity and T-cell production as well. However, there is still a long way to go for this vaccine to receive green signals, since a lot of side effects during injection have been observed. Let me know what are your views on the same.

It likely won't. Ever. A vaccine will be produced at some point, but look how many people don't get a flu shot. COVID-19 will be the same. It's spread too far now to realistically expect a worldwide eradication. A vaccination will never be 100% effective, and the virus will mutate enough to require yearly updates, similar to a flu shot. It isn't all doom and gloom, though. A vaccine will prevent most cases, and treatments for people who do contract it will improve as the medical community gets more experience with it. This year will most likely be the worst of it, and the panic will probably be at least as dangerous as the virus itself. People are already causing problems by stocking up on soap and things like that. Production of goods will be impacted by quarantine measures, leading to shortages. Basically, the dominoe effect on society will have an economic impact that will disrupt business as usual. Trying to carry on business as usual would facilitate the COVID-19 spread, so we're kind of stuck between a rock and a hard place. The best advice I've heard is basically to prepare, not panic. If you want a stockpile of food, don't go clear out the canned goods section. Just buy a little extra for a few weeks to slowly build up your stockpile. Same with any other goods you think you might need, especially things like hand sanitizer that the medical community needs more that you do.

It has already ended, at least in some places. Yes, many have pointed out that it will be here forever, along with Spanish Flu, H1N1 etc. I’m talking about the pandemic of course. Generally, the virus seems to have run its course about three months after hitting the peak. It’s already hit the peak in most of Europe. If you look at places like Sweden, the UK, and New York, which got it early, the daily death toll is down to single digits. In the UK, the historical suicide rate is now 3x higher than the COVID-19 mortality rate, at 30 a day vs 10.    Other places that either through planning or luck postponed the virus, such as Florida and Ethiopia, still have some way to go to reach the peak.   So a direct answer to your question: between now and November for most of the world. Countries such as Australia and New Zealand which have delayed the spread will have the virus for a bit beyond that. Update: The CDC director agrees that suicides are more significant We’re seeing, sadly, far greater suicides now than we are deaths from COVID. We’re seeing far greater deaths from drug overdose that are above excess that we had as background than we are seeing the deaths from COVID. — CDC Director Robert Redfield I’m not sure if he’s technically accurate, but another month or two and he will be.

When a vaccine that works is found, tested for safety and effectiveness, and mass manufactured. Not before. (The only alternative is letting it rampage unchecked, killing millions, until it burns itself out, which of course is no alternative at all.) Usually the vaccine development process—preclinical trials, phase I trials, phase II trials, phase III trials, and finally approval and mass-production—takes years. But given the urgency, scientists are racing and hoping to have one next year. To keep up with this, there are vaccine trackers on various news sites, e.g. Coronavirus Vaccine Tracker I New York Times. As of right now, July 17 2020, it seems like only four vaccines have made it to phase III trials, and none have been approved for general use. One Chinese vaccine candidate, based on promising unpublished phase II trial data, has been given limited approval for use in the Chinese military when “specially needed”. (Even when there is a vaccine, I think it is possible that the virus will still exist endemically i.e. persistently at low rates—e.g. aided by anti-vaxxers—but enough of us will be immune to give the population herd immunity, so it won't be epidemic i.e. won't be spreading.)

Coronavirus is now a pandemic. Let's tackle denial first. “I don’t live in denial or panic,” you say, “I live in hope.” But hope is not a strategy. Hoping for a magic treatment or a timely vaccine is naivete. New drugs and vaccines typically need months and years in clinical trials to measure safety, efficacy and side effects.  We should urgently ramp up novel coronavirus testing at all levels. This is only the golden standard; Testing, tracing and effective management of COVID patients. Identifying mild — yet contagious — cases, followed by aggressive quarantine, is the best public health strategy to control this outbreak. Meanwhile, don’t panic. Get prepared. Wash your hands, cover your cough with an elbow, and cover your sneeze with a napkin; and wash your hands again after discarding the napkin. Avoid touching your nose or face. Stay 3 to 6 feet away from people with flu-like symptoms. If you develop fever, cough or flu-like symptoms, stay home and stay calm: most patients with such symptoms these days are suffering from known, much less dangerous seasonal flu. The virus doesn’t dwell upon conspiracy theories and has no political favorites. We must respond to this global threat by getting information from authentic sources and rising above partisan politics. Previous outbreaks of H1N1, SARS, Asian flu or the Spanish flu lasted anywhere from 12 to 36 months. The global coronavirus outbreak is currently in its sixth month and the virus has already infected over 20 million individuals in more than 150 countries. We should neither deny nor freak out about this reality; we should prepare. This too shall pass.

It will probably never be over. Now I will elaborate why I made this statement and why I used the word ‘probably’. Why is it unlikely to be over? Because it's an infectious disease and that too a viral infectious disease. Even if human cases come down to a very low number, the pathogen will likely survive in its animal reservoirs. Eg. Bats and likely Pangolins too.Once the initial tide gets over, the virus may mutate into a less severe form that will very rarely kill its host, thus increasing it's own chance of survival and transmission. Remember it's better for a pathogen that its host doesn't die otherwise the pathogen would also get killed with the host.In long run non-communicable diseases are going to be focus of all medical R&D, especially in the western countries. In all likelihood cancer, diabetes, heart diseases will still cause a greater mortality than an infectious disease.Yet there is a small chance that this virus may be eliminated if not eradicated. How? Vaccine: A lot depends on the characteristics of vaccine that we are going to have against coronavirus:Protection: if the vaccine prevents 90% of coronavirus pneumonitis, chances of elimination are better.Duration: longer the duration of protection better the chance of elimination.Live/killed vaccine: chances of elimination are more if we are able to develop a live attenuated vaccine like polio.Immunity: If coronavirus infection confers life long immune than chances of elimination are higher.Animal reservoirs: if a animal reservoirs are only a few like bats then the chances of elimination are more.

There’s no perfect answer to that. Why? Because we are still learning how to deal with COVID-19. Nevertheless, history can offer us some insights as well as possibilities.  SOURCE: Here are 5 possible COVID-19 endings based on history. Learn and Adapt Ending -This kind of pandemic ending will happen when the majority becomes tired of it all. So, people start to learn to live with the disease. And believe me, with a vaccine or without, this is a forgone conclusion. We must learn to live with it.Vaccine Ending - The vaccine is one miracle I am hoping and praying for—a medical ending. Unlike in the past hundred years ago, humanity has grown leap and bounds due to medical science. So, this ending is within the realm of possibilities.Mutation to Weaker Form - Mutation into less virulent forms does happen in cases of common colds. As transmission continues, there is a possibility that COVID-19 can become less virulent.Social & Cultural Shift -Let’s take Ignaz Semmelweis, a Hungarian physician, as an example. After noticing the weird high mortality rate among laboring mothers. He conducted an investigation and tried to find an answer to this problem. He theorized that medical students might have spread microbes after doing autopsies. So he mandated doctors to do handwashing with chlorine before touching any patients. Though, history tells us that many didn’t like it and ignored this rule. Still, Dr. Semmelweis eventually became known as the father of hand hygiene as time flew. Though not in his time. He shifted our views on handwashing. Futurewise, he saved a lot of women and families.No one else to infect Ending - I hate to talk about this one with you. Why? Well, considering the current scientific breakthroughs in vaccine development. I find the chances of this event happening next to nil. Hey, it is one thing to be happy about.

It will probably be more of a problem in poorer countries. Why? We have no method of exterminating this virus.This virus is not self-limiting.This virus infects people of all ages.This virus kills people of all ages.There are no cures for virus caused diseases. There are only treatments for the symptoms.This virus is easily transmitted from person to person.Asymptomatic people are transmitting it to healthy people.It’s currently virulent in 184 countries even though these countries are in different climatic zones.One vaccine may not necessarily offer permanent immunity. We may have to have a vaccine every 6 months or annually for it. Currently we have to have a vaccine every year against the flu.SARSr-CoV-1, the virus that caused the 2002–2003 pandemic is still with us and still killing people. Also, there’s no vaccine for it.MERS-CoV, the virus that caused a pandemic around 2012 is still around and still killing people.There are four different human corona virusae that cause the common cold.That’s why I’m saying it’s here to stay with us, forever.

No one knows. In 1918, the world had no choice but to let the virus run its course. Even if there hadn’t been a war on, the state of knowledge at the time precluded development of a vaccine. That pandemic faded in about three years, and even before that mutated into a much less virulent form. An argument Trump seems to be implicitly making is that if we just ignore it, the Covid pandemic will run the same course. But there are two important differences between the 1918 flu and Covid-19. The first is that the 1918 flu had no lasting consequences for those who survived it. Those it did not kill were fine afterward. This is not universally true of Covid-19. Although some appear relatively unaffected afterward, many suffer long term debilitating health problems. It is not clear how widespread or long-lasting these sequelae might be. The second difference is that we now do know how to fight viral disease. If we limit the spread of the disease now, there is at least the possibility of saving millions of lives by moderating our behavior while we wait for a vaccine. The question, quite simply, is whether the potential of saving millions of lives is worth the price of moderating our behavior, or not?

The COVID-19 pandemic will only end if we all work towards ending it Scientists are busy finding a cure, doctors and medical staff are helping the sick, essential services workers are doing their best, … and most others are ignorantly or rebelliously spreading the virus!? As long as people act in unconcerned ways the spread of the virus will keep increasing day by day. I see so many people on the streets going about life just as if nothing as big as the pandemic is happening, and I feel an unshakable dread that this is only going to get worse and worse in wave upon wave. It does look like our only hope is in a vaccine but shouldn’t we at least try to minimize the damage on humanity till then? Why fighting COVID-19 depends on all of us!  The one take away from what has happened so far is that there have been thousands of avoidable deaths that we should all feel sad for and try to stop. Unfortunately correct awareness about the disease is not that high and this has lead to widespread ignoring and flaunting of the preventive measures authorities have tried to implement. In the science of epidemics it can be predicted how things will go depending on number of new cases per day. Slowing down the number of cases per day is the only way to manage a sudden pandemic like COVID-19 that grows exponentially.  Avoiding close contact with people slows COVID-19’s spread  It’s the strangest thing to watch people protest the protective measures that are meant to save their own people’s lives. It is not a new fangled theory, scare tactics nor political or draconian - it is the solution in the absence of a vaccine. Please use these videos to get through to those who aren’t understanding how critical all of our roles is yet. 🙏🏾🙏🏾 TC & Stay Safe.

Well, it's difficult to predict, however, we can certainly speculate. Let's look at some of the worst affected countries (9th March, 2020) and their progress:  China: in the above image, white regions have no existing Covid-19 cases. Although Hubei province (in dark brown) remains worst affected province of China, fortunately, the trend was quite good for the last couple of weeks, all across China. For example, in my province (Jiangsu), as of March 8th, 2020 00:00-24:00, there are no new cases since 19th February:  Similar trends in my Chinese hometown (Suzhou):  Now let's look at China's cumulative data:  Very encouraging trends in China. About 1500 people are recovering every day. So, it seems that China's existing Covid-19 cases may practically come to an end in about a month's time. Related: Latest Covid-19 infections statistics Now let's look at the cumulative data outside China (9th March, morning):  Overall, more than 2000 cases were added in the last 24 hours. Number of people recovering are just 44. However, South Korea has made a good progress. South Korea reported 69 new cases, continuing a downward trend. The death toll rose by one to 51. The new cases brought South Korea’s total infections to 7,382, while the death toll rose by one (to total 51). The rate of increase in new infections fell to its lowest in 10 days on Sunday in one of the countries most severely affected outside mainland China.  Italy is another worst affected country. In Italy, the deaths rose from 233 to 366, a rise of more than 50% in 24 hours, with the total number of cases being about 7,375. Moreover, the biggest concerns are about the old people in Italy. Some record suggests that 23% of the Italian population are over 65, making it the oldest in the world after Japan. This could partly explain the rising number of deaths in Italy. Well, Italy is a developed country. With good medical facilities and coming lockdowns in Lombardy and other severely affected areas, we can expect Italy to recover in coming days. Now, coming to Iran and the Middle East, this is where I am concerned the most. Iran reported 49 new coronavirus fatalities over the past 24 hours, bringing its death toll to 194. About 743 new people were diagnosed with Covid-19 in last 24hours. Irans’s total cases stand above 6500. Moreover, the US economic sanction on Iran could also be a reason for the collapse of Iran's capabilities to fight against Covid-19 outbreak. So, when the Covid-19 would end? Maybe soon in China. However, some countries might struggle with Covid-19 for at least a few more months, maybe beyond. Let's see! Also, I wish to thank the Chinese government for their sincere efforts to control the Covid-19. Now, rest of the world can learn from China. Much love! When will the COVID-19 virus end? Please ignore Jason Bell’s ignorant rant. It will end when people like him realize the coronavirus is real, realize that we are the only way it spreads and understand that we can do what it takes to stop it. It probably won’t ever entirely end; it will probably mutate and return next year. If we don’t get rid of it soon and it mutates, we could have two versions of the virus. And don’t forget that we have an annual flu season on top of the coronavirus. The good news is that wearing masks and social distancing and washing our hands thoroughly will help protect us from the flu (which I hope Mr. Bell thinks is real). A mutation doesn’t mean the virus will be worse. In fact it’s hard to realize how it could be worse than a virus that can infect someone and display no symptoms for two weeks while they can spread it. It also leaves some with not ever having had symptoms even after two weeks while it kills others. Mutations can end up with a milder version of the virus. This happens with the flu. Some years it’s much worse than others; some years, it’s comparatively mild. We need to look to the science — the Dr. Fauci’s out there, not our fearless (and clueless) leader — and ignore conspiracy theories.

Most likely for as long as mankind survives, and maybe longer, though not in exactly its current form. How long will we be subject to restrictions and afraid of catching it. FIt is hard to say. One viewpointis that we now know enough to relax the measures as the virus is not as lethal, by itslef as was originally thought (most deaths are in older people and most of those are in people that have one or more chronic health problems). My best guess is that we’ll be kept under house arrest for another month or two. There are attempts to worry us that nothing will change until until effective drugs and vaccines are developed against it, but that is ridiculous for several reasons. Anti viral drugs are not especially effective and it takes a long time to develop vaccines. Then it isn’t possible to make enough to vaccinate everyone. If the measures are maintained for too long the economic and social damage will end up being worse than that done by the virus .. if it isn’t already worse. What is the most likely outcome for the virus itself? That it will become less virulent and become endemic, but no more than a nuisance, like colds and most ‘flu’. Worse outcome. It will mutate rapidly, altering the surface proteins by which it is recognised and marked for destruction, so that acquired immunity does not last very long. Worst outcome. It trades genetic material with some endemic disease and produces a highly contagious highly lethal killer We also need to be vigilant to make sure that unscrupulous governments and security forces do not use this as an excuse to increatse their routine surveillance of ordinary people and take away some of the freedoms that ordinary people have taken centuries to win … as they did across the world with 9–11.

response.answer_text: If it was gone tomorrow we would spend at least two-year digging out economically. Discovered infections are down from a peak of 70,000 a day to “just” 35,000 a day, but that has come as testing has diminished. It would be a much more meaningful number if testing had actually increased dramatically as most all health care officials are demanding. Since our data is spotty on viral spread, the death count is rising, every effort to “open” schools has resulted in actions that send back known infected students from across the nation back to their homes in small towns, cities and villages across the country we can expect to have to endure the effects of this disease for at least 6–9 more months followed by at least two years of economic troubles. For all the underclass evicted from an apartment or housing complex - you have a landlord also potentially facing bankruptcy. If you want to reduce the time to live with COVID there is a simple way. Get out and VOTE. You will shave months off the physical heartache and years off the economic hardships.

Look at this photograph. This collage is made by cropping news articles from standard newspapers like TOI, The Indian Express, The Tribune, The Hindu etc. The news flashed in this picture are authentic government datas and predictions about the peak and flattening of curve in India. This photograph clearly shows how much clueless and helpless the world is in this Pandemic. No one has ever experienced something like this before and its nearly impossible at the level of human to accurately predict the end. Few factors may indicate the acceleration and deceleration of the pandemic though. Overpopulation & dense populationLess social awarenessNot using preventive measuresThese accelerate the spread of the virus in a rapid way. Being an airborne virus, there is no way to stop it if we don't try it at community level. Using masks, sanitisers.Reducing the frequency of going out.Following the rules strictly in containment zonesThese help to decelerate the rate of spread. There are many equations, theories, graphs and assumptions made by researchers and doctors which are getting published on a regular basis in newspapers and internet. But all of them are predictions based on assumptions. And everytime we assume, the COVID-19 virus gives us a new surprise. What to do ? Follow rules set by govt.Take care of your own hygiene.Go out when there is an emergency.Avoid unnecessary contact.What will happen if I follow these rules? The virus will still keep spreading. So, why should I suffer if its not going to bring any change. AND WHY DON'T YOU SUGGEST AN END TO THIS ? Actually, you are partially right. If you abide by the rules even, there will be someone who will break it. There are also patients who are following the rules and are still getting affected. We cannot stop the viruses which have already spreaded. But we need to stop the further spread. If you follow the rules, chances of infection in you reduces significantly. There will be rampant infections still going out there, but atleast some part of the flow will stop at your level. Believe me, this is the only possible way to stop the virus. Stopping the flow.Curing the affected. Coming back to your question, No one really knows when this pandemic will end because no one can control what another man does. The precautions are to be taken at personal level. The frontline warriors can only warn us about the consequences and put forward the precautions, but its us who needs to follow them. When the entire world will follow the sanitisation procedures and social distancing, the infection will start to terminate.  If you were looking for an exact ending time, I know that my answer has disappointed you. But my friend, no one knows the exact time. But its not possible in near months. 2020 will pass. It may subside in 2021 given that there is a massive revolution of community awareness. P.S : I am not adding any graphs and theories of predictions because they will make this answer more clumsy. You can google it and see various theories about the spread of infection. 1. Coronavirus: What is 'flattening the curve,' and will it work? 2. How Infection Works Thank you for reading Jyoti

Corona virus i.e COVID 19 has spread to a level where it cannot be stopped. It can only be slowed. This should be our aim as well. Slow spread means people get treatment resulting in fewer deaths. Also our body gets enough time to build resistance. Imagine that you drink entire large bottle of whiskey at once. There is a good chance that you may die. Now imagine drinking one peg a day. You survive. If your systems are bombarded with patients, if your body is bombarded with virus, it succumbs. If you lockdown a community then there will be temporary respite and you may control it there but as soon as lockdown ends, then virus may make a re-entry from other places. So it is essential to have slow and controlled exposure to this virus so that our bodies develops resistance to it. So once entire population is exposed to Corona and our body builds anti bodies or some immunity against it then it will become like any other regular fever. This is the end state !

China announced no new infection on March 19.China announced no new death on April 7th. The virus infects and kills in about 3 weeks time. The infection is mainly due to contact with infected surfaces and environment. The comparison between LA (5000 cases), Phoenix (1200 cases) and NYC (80000 cases) shows that:- Dry weather (droplets evaporates)- Sunny weather (UV kill the viruse)- City structure: in the South west people move by car, they do not walk. They live in single family house, not building. Are the main driver of the epidemics. LA enforces a mandatory stay at home, Phoenix does not. Quarantine without testing is useless. The example of Italy shows the number of infections did not slow within 3 weeks of quarantine as would be expected from a two weeks latency disease. How to reproduce LA results. Massively disinfect cities, buildings, HVAC, trash columns, lifts and stairs. people get infected by touching a soiled surface or by breathing contaminated air. Mass test and sort the infected from the healthy ones. Quarantine the infected away from the healthy ones (airborne virus). If the weather keeps being nice, sunny and warm. We should be cleared by Mid May.

I’d like to be clear and to the point, of answering this question! As of today Wednesday, April 8th, the situation as shown in the screenshot of Jons Hopkins University site below.  Till now there no one on the planet can be certain that this deadly virus could be stopped on a definitive date before the appearance of its vaccine. Let’s go through the different case scenarios that could help overcome Coronavirus Pandemic and their impact on the economy and our daily life. The first case scenario: Creating the vaccine That is almost the best scenario as all who would be given the vaccine couldn’t get infected. Unfortunately creating a vaccine could take more than a year according to researchers. However, the hopes rise after WHO Director-General said that Coronavirus vaccine and treatment research has “accelerated at incredible speed’. That makes sense now as more than 30 companies in a race to create the COVID-19 vaccine. Why getting the vaccine is the best scenario in the battle against the pandemic? Because only the vaccine that can prevent people from getting sick and so there will no be new cases. The impact on the economy It will be great as the supply chains will be resumed and people get back to turn on the wheel of production. The Second case scenario: Creating a treatment The treatment can be reached much quicker than the vaccine however still there will be new cases of infection that should appear daily. The impact on the economy Sure we will get out of this panic phase as that should slow down the death rate to the minimum. So there will be trust in the future which will drive the economy to a higher level soon. The third case scenario: Creating a treatment and a vaccine at the same time This is the optimum solution that will eradicate the pandemic. The impact on the economy Will set the economy on the right path again and all the world will get to its normality.  The fourth case scenario: Still there’re neither a treatment nor a vaccine In this case, the pandemic will last longer as there is not an effective solution available other than social distancing and further quarantines. That just slows down the infection rate at the expense of the economy. The impact on the economy That, unfortunately, should enhance the global economic recession.

Stay Home Stay Safe information based on News By Winhugelotto Family HIGHLIGHTS Scientists in Worlds have anticipated finish of Covid-19 episode in India by May 22 End dates for India, 97 percent by May , 99 percent by June and 100 percent by July 26 SIR model created by specialists anticipate Covid-19 to proceed in world till early December 2020 Sitting in homes because of lock down constrained by novel corona virus pandemic, a huge number of individuals in India and over the world have this inquiry at the forefront of their thoughts: when will Covid-19 end? Specialists in Singapore have gambled responding to this inquiry. Based on the example of spread of Covid-19 from China to the remainder of the world and easing back down, the scientists in Singapore have an anticipated date for 131 nations every when novel coronavirus episode will end there. Covid-19 will end in India around May 21-22, the scientists said. This is when novel coronavirus disease will be 97 percent down contrasted with April 20, which they found as the turning date. This is near what the Indian Council for Medical Research (ICMR) indicated a week ago. ICMR executive Dr Balram Bhargava had stated, "One can say we have had the option to level the bend." The ICMR said the inspiration rate has been steady at around 4.5 percent in India lately. This steady pace of spread of Covid-19 could be a sign of India having passed the turning date, evaluated by the Singaporean scientists. Their numerical model predicts that by June 1, India will have restored 99 percent of Covid-19 cases. Also, the novel coronavirus will be killed by July 26 from India, the analysts assessed. Covid-19 advancement chart for India dependent on SIR model, created by scientists in Singapore This will, be that as it may, sounds hopeful given the size of the flood in huge Indian states and urban areas - Mumbai and Pune in Maharashtra, Delhi, Jaipur in Rajasthan and Indore in Madhya Pradesh among others. Then again, four states however littler in size of the populace - Goa, Tripura, Manipur and Arunachal Pradesh - have gotten free of Covid-19. Be that as it may, there is solid confirmation for the model, called the SIR (vulnerable tainted recuperated) model. It assessed February 8 to turn date for China, and February 27 as End-97 percent date. On the ground, China on February 19 announced the most minimal number of new corona virus disease in a month, showed that the nation was past the turning date. The SIR model had March 4 as End-99 percent date for China, which on March 7 revealed 99 new Covid-19 cases, the first beneath 100 day by day cases since the episode. April 9 was End-100 percent date for China. It has not occurred from a severe perspective of the term as China keeps on announcing new cases. However, it was on April 8 that China permitted individuals to leave Wuhan, the Covid-19 ground zero, just because since it authorized lockdown in January. Likewise, China has said that practically all the new Covid-19 cases lately are imported. On April 25, China said it recorded only one neighborhood novel corona virus contamination case in 10 days. Others were imported Covid-19 cases. The SIR model is extremely near the ground circumstance in China. This examination expectation brings some desire for Indians. Nonetheless, the scientists have themselves cautioned that "the model behind our expectation is just hypothetically reasonable for one-phase scourge. The forecast is likewise molded by the nature of the information." As indicated by this numerical model, Covid-19 will end toward the beginning of December this year. Till Now we should Follow Basic Rule 1) Do some indoor walk ,exercise & change diet to Improve Immunity Power 2) Stay away from close contact with individuals who are wiped out. Remain at home when you are wiped out. 3)Keep away from close contact 4)Limit your movement

Before answering the question ‘When will the covid-19 end’ lets have a look at ‘How will the covid-19 end’ Living in self-isolation has profound socio-political implications, in addition to the effects that it has on a person’s mental health and well-being. Although more and more studies are showing that quarantine and isolation methods are indeed effective and that we should all continue to keep our physical distance, it is hard not to grow impatient and wonder how long this is likely to last. Actually the most reliable way to to escape covid-19 and live our life to the fullest like we all used to is by successful implementation if vaccines. Oh, but hold on, there are no such promising vaccines yet! so is it right to rely on them? well, experts say that we have to have another strategy to win over corona virus. With social distancing measures and an eventual vaccine, COVID-19 will turn into a thing of the past. However, a vaccine will take at least a year before being publicly available even if COVID-19 is breaking records in vaccine development. But the tireless efforts of scientists will pay off. Most vaccines are still likely to be 12–18 months away from being available to the entire population, and this period is long enough to cause lasting social and economic damage if the lockdown persists. normally it may take years of trials before a vaccine reaches the population, but during the pandemic, scientists can fast-track this process by doing as many of the necessary steps as possible in parallel. So this is kind of a positive ray of hope. But is this enough? No! Experts have said that expecting a promising vaccine to be out as soon as possible is being way too optimistic. And a man must always plan by having a pessimistic image of situation in their minds. Some experts have claimed that, just like every other virus, corona virus may also stay with us forever. But to survive through it we would need a vaccine. The question is will we be home isolated unless a vaccine is successfully developed? When talked about lifting up the social distancing as it is causing a great loss of economy, the WHO advisory stressed the importance of what happens after governments lift measures of physical distancing. “Certain severe measures in China have been very effective in curtailing outbreaks in China. But now, the question is: What happens when they release those severe measures? Will there be a second wave of infection? Nobody is able to predict this with certainty.” No one can certainly answer to the question of when will all end end. But, even if some restrictions are lifted from social distancing you will be expected to go out only when it is really important and not because you want to hang out with your friends. If your work is dependent on the uplifting of all the restriction, I would probably suggest that please look out for an alternative. This is the best time one could take their business online and expect good results. References- When will the COVID-19 pandemic be over? When and How Will COVID-19 End? - The Medical Futurist All the best :-)

Q: How long will the covid 19 last? The virus itself will likely be around for a very long time, if not forever. While it is possible to effectively eradicate a virus (smallpox, polio), it's difficult. The viruses that cause colds and influenza show no signs of being eradicated anytime soon, for example. The current pandemic will run its course in time. They always do. We're getting into the summer months in the northern hemisphere, and that will help to limit its spread. Countries in the southern hemisphere are moving into their winters and they may see an upsurge as a result, though I personally couldn't say one way or the other. People are gradually, though perhaps slowly, developing a herd immunity to the disease as more and more become infected, survive, and develop an immune response to the virus. This will help to slow its spread going forward as well. Nonetheless, fresh cases (and, unfortunately, deaths) will likely continue to arise, but it appears that the worst of the pandemic is largely behind us. We'll see if that continues to hold in the US as the various States relax their lockdown measures. So far, so good, but time will tell. As for the future, it seems to me this virus is probably endemic by this point, meaning it is in the population and will resurface annually. We will likely see an annual covid season every year that overlaps the flu season. That's just my guess, of course, and other's mileage may vary.

Note - The answer is written on 25 March 2020 with the existing and verified knowledge from trusted sources. I will be very generic and lucid in my explanation while giving correct and verified information. This answer may become redundant within days, weeks or months as scientific community come up better alternatives and solutions to tackle this pandemic. The virus has a very slow rate of mutation and hence vaccines can be developed in the coming months if rumors about hydroxychloroquine are true. There are mixed sentiments in the scientific community regarding the efficacy of this drug. (Study by NPR, CDC) But India and the USA are using these drugs in various stages of their treatment and till now (ICMR handout information) it has buttressed the recovery process overall but still, it cannot be considered a vaccine. India especially is doing everything in its efforts to delay stage 3 (community transmission; here the cases multiply quickly) of this pandemic. In ICMR words, India is trying to “flatten the bell curve” in order to reduce the effective number of cases before community transmission ushers.  And the whole world is doing the same and with time, the number of cases will be controlled, the health care system will be steadfast and this pandemic will be arrested. India has a good track record in arresting and tackling global health issues like Small Pox and Polio. And with concerted efforts, the number of cases will flat out and become negligible and can be better handled. Right now, the pandemic has not yet peaked worldwide. It is increasing at a very rapid pace and the number of deaths has almost tripled in less than 2 weeks.  COVID19 has 2–3% fatality rate (across all ages) and mostly old people with health complications have an increased level of risk. As seen from the experiences of China who peaked in their bell curve (in the total number of cases last week) have been effective in flattening the curve after strict actions by the government and citizens in the form of social distancing and self-imposed/govt imposed quarantine. The quick rate of transmission, despite having low fatality makes it a pandemic. To prevent the collapse of the healthcare system, we have to make our family and loved one safe by being at home. The number of positive cases in India will probably run into thousands but that delayed onslaught will help in good recovery rates and fewer critical cases and thereafter fewer fatalities. We are in this together. Stay Strong. Stay at home. Stay positive. Stay hard. A

The virus will never end, it will be with us forever. However, if you are asking about the situation with respect to lockdowns and travel restrictions, that will depend upon the country. As long as the country is under lockdown, case numbers will remain low or drop to zero, at least officially, but it can not open up without allowing cases (and potentially, fatalities) to rise. How long can a country afford a total lockdown? That becomes a political question. Many people (that includes some enlightened and knowledgeable people at WHO, democrat types, Greta Thunberg etc.) would prefer a permanent lockdown where the government keeps stimulating the economy by printing money and giving handouts. But if a country opens up, or at least tries to move towards normalcy, the virus will sweep through the nation at different speeds until the country has herd immunity (depending on population density, general diet, eating habit of people, lifestyle etc.), and kill whoever is supposed to die, leave some with long term damage, most will recover, and many more will stay asymptomatic or only very mild symptom nothing different from a cold. It will also incentivise people to eat and drink healthy and make their own personal trade off between their own pocket and their own health. Simply, if you think your health is more important than your money, do not go out to work and stay isolated at home. If you are ready to accept some risk, go out to work. As simple as that. And I believe this is the phase much of India and US are going through. Now, even if a country imposes very strict lockdown to isolate the early cases to supposedly make the country covid free (that is what New Zealand and Australia were celebrating before the renewed lockdown), then the question is whether it can keep its border indefinitely sealed. We will see about that, but I suspect not very long. Here are some examples. Singapore explores air travel bubbles in push to reopen borders safely Croatia Has Reopened to Tourists From All Countries - Travel Off Path. Panama Is Reopening for International Visitors in October Bigger countries can afford to stay shut to the outside world for somewhat longer, but smaller countries like Singapore, UAE, Switzerland etc. which thrive and prosper by trade, by continuous flow of goods, people and capital, cannot afford to stay isolated for long. As more and more countries gradually open up, it is already starting a positive feedback loop to attract businesses and tourists alike. Believe me or not, there has always been a competition among the countries to attract investment dollar, corporations, start ups, tourism etc. to create a diversified economy and all that. Further, as more and more countries get convergence of rates, they will realise that there is very little justification in keeping themselves isolated from each other when all of them are already counting cases within a narrow range. So no matter how much of a lockdown-advocate some people are, eventually every single country/state in the world will ask itself the question of how many lives each billion in GDP is worth. Every single young adult, be it those who were planning to start college and an adult life away from home, or finishing university and looking forward to join the workforce, or those who were planning for higher education (often somewhere abroad) will ask how many more months or years of their most crucial formative period will they keep sacrificing by hunkering down at home to save another octogenarian’s life. And mind that these are some of the years that shape their destiny for decades to come, time when they get out of home, learn to live as an adult, move to a new city or even country, becomes acquainted with the professional/corporate world, potentially meet a life partner. I wonder whether they will agree that a government stimulus, even if a stimulus cheque directly delivered to their hand, is enough of a compensation for that. Here is an example. ‘Generation Screwed’ created by COVID as crisis ‘scars’ cohort for life Fun thing about India. Nobody can fault them for not trying their lockdown, really hard and swift when apparently the situation warranted it according to some politicians. So they locked the country down, postponed the university and school leaving examinations, closed the campuses back in march, when daily case counts were fewer than 500. Oh, sure, nobody in India wanted it to become like Italy. And a lockdown will save everyone, right? While throughout the last week, the postponed examinations were conducted, and colleges and universities started welcoming students back, with much online fanfare, heralding the new beginning and all…when the moving average case count of past one week stands square at around 80,000. Basically, 160x more than when they decided to close. The irony is hard to miss. Yes, there is a not dying for wall street crowd. But very few of them realise that people work with the primary goal of feeding themselves, and when that livelihood is jeopardised, they will rather accept a virus with a mortality rate of 1% than sitting on their couch and watching their jobs being done by someone else, or outsourced to other countries.

It's impossible to say with any degree of actuality just how lengthy the COVID-19 pandemic that took the world by way of a hurricane in early 2020 will final. There are approaches to explain a 'give up' to a virus. One is the elimination, which is a reduction of the latest cases to a certain low range (ideally zero). The other is eradication - a clean, everlasting, and whole wiping out of an infectious agent. While lots have been discovered approximately the virus's capacity to spread between people, infect cells, and positioned infected humans vulnerable to various foremost fitness issues, estimating its duration in an international population depends on how all of us behave, which can be tons tougher to version. Much as predictions on weather change vary relying on how we act now, it might be feasible to recommend situations that further forecast the unique futures facing us. What if we lived in a superglobal? Taking the moves of nations such as New Zealand and Vietnam as case studies, effective social distancing measures are a powerful manner to restrict the spread of SARS-CoV-2, showing that the virus may be eradicated on as a minimum a neighborhood degree. The reasons why humans in one-of-a-kind communities don't have interaction in social distancing are complicated and sundry. Some are influenced by the aid of non-public, political, and moral values. Others are laid low with monetary choices, missing social welfare to assist them. In an ideal world, in which distancing was observed strictly sufficient to make the number of network transmissions negligible everywhere in the world, the cutting-edge era of functioning virus particles will be the final. SARS-CoV-2 particles would then smash down inside the air within hours. On surfaces, inside only some days. Knowing how lengthy the virus persists in a human frame is a touch tougher to pin down. One early examination showed it remains possible for about nine days after first signs seem, with viral fragments detectable so long as a month later. In first-rate cases, a month or of ideal international isolation seems to be enough to clean all people of the virus for accurate. Our global is far from best. What's extra reasonable? Without social isolation to reduce the virus's transmission from infected parties, protection from substantial immunity is the following exceptional aspect. This issue depends on how lengthy the common person keeps immunity from SARS-CoV-2, a factor this is nonetheless uncertain. The reminiscence cells that produce antibodies may want to stay powerful for as few as a couple of months or last up to more than one year or extra. A vaccine dispensed and brought within a brief enough time body may want to pressure the R (range of human beings in all likelihood to be inflamed via some other infected character) to drop under a parent vital for the virus to loaf around. While producing vaccines for past coronaviruses was complex, there was giant progress for SARS-CoV-2. Early efforts are displaying promise, that means we may want to optimistically assume fairly effective vaccines to be had by means of the give up of 2020 to early 2021. If doses may be produced in enough quantities - itself a sensible and logistical hurdle - they might nonetheless need to be allotted into some distance corners of the globe. Then there may be the question of how many human beings should (or even would) be vaccinated. There are few precedents we can appear in the direction of. One concerned the diplomatic efforts of the World Health Organisation, a software to get rid of smallpox subsequently succeeded in the overdue Nineteen Seventies. The Global Smallpox Program took almost twenty years to satisfy its desires, however, it additionally suffered from constrained vaccines and occasional investment. With sufficient price range and cooperation, we could feasibly globally remove SARS-CoV-2 in years in preference for a long time. Will the coronavirus be around all the time? The bleakest of realities is SARS-CoV-2 is right here to live, with reservoirs of the virus being maintained amongst globally-linked groups for the foreseeable future. Vaccines will most probably enhance performance and manufacturing, even though human behavior being what it's far, even making them mandatory will make it unlikely they will be administered in sufficient portions. New medicinal drugs will more than probably assist lessen the number of deaths and different damaging health consequences. Politics, social traits, and new approaches of conducting business and domestic dwelling will evolve to mirror man or woman values toward COVID-19's spread. Historically, pandemics both fade, as deaths and infections plummet, or we just get used to the ebb and float of a brand new sickness. Science can only achieve this a lot. The rest is as much as an international population of people who increasingly mistrust one another greater than they fear a killer virus. When will COVID-19 end? Well, if by “end” you mean “go away completely” then probably never. The virus exists and will probably continue to exist amongst the population from now on, it’s pesky that way. This is probably going to be one of those viruses that floats around the population every year. However, what you probably mean is “when will the pandemic, the lockdowns, travel restrictions and all the current insanity associated with it end?”. In that case, that will probably end once a viable vaccine is developed and approved. Once a significant enough percentage of the population is vaccinated and one infected person does not lead to hundreds, if not thousands of further infections and deaths, we can go and loosen all the restrictions we have put in place to stop that from happening. At that point we can also continue to put work into viable treatments so that those who still do get it don’t die or are at least far less likely to. Now that doesn’t mean that the virus will be gone, this very well might end up being one of those yearly viruses that we need to get vaccinated for like the flu shot. But it will be just that, one of those things we need to get vaccinated for every year, not a world-stopping crisis that everyone has to drop everything to deal with immediately as it is now.
