Observing the severity and the exponential spread of the virus the only plausible way to end the virus is vaccination. Presuming we have already deciphered the nature of the virus it will take atleast another 10 years to reach its distribution stage. As vaccine will have a portion of the attenuated viral protein the major challenge is to determine its stability over time so that it doesn't revert back its pathogenic nature and thus it will take atleast 5 to 7 years to pass through all 3 stages of clinical trial. Then it needs to Be mass produced and subsequently pass all the stability tests to get approval for distribution which will take atleast another 3-5 years. Although if the distribution strategies might be designed in such a way that not 100% of the population will need to get vaccinated but still will be immune to the virus, this phenomenon is called herd immunity. Herd immunity the resistance to the spread of a contagious disease within a population that results if a sufficiently high proportion of individuals are immune to the disease, especially through vaccination.Herd immunity created via vaccination contributed to the eventual eradication of smallpox in 1977 and has contributed to the reduction of the frequencies of other diseases. If herd immunity has been established and maintained in a population for a sufficient time, the disease is inevitably eliminated—no more endemic transmissions occur. R0- the average number of secondary infections caused by a single infectious individual introduced into a completely susceptible population. Higher the R0 higher is ther percentage of total population required to get vaccinated in order to reach herd immunity. COVID19 have R0 of 2-3 and thus will require 65-70% of vaccinated population to reach herd immunity and possible eradication of this pandemic.

OK let’s clear the air here! There is no COVID-19 vaccine at this time. There is a lot of research going on and my understanding is that there are over 100 possible vaccines. It was truly amazing how fast we got possible vaccines after this COVID-19 became a problem. What we do not know and this is what the careful research is about is (1) We do not know how many people given a test vaccine will convert to immune. (2) We do not know what levels of partial immunity will happen (3) We do not know if the immunity will last and if so for how long. (4) We do not know how many doses will produce adverse short term responses. (5) We do not know how many doses will produce long term damages (6) We do not know how many doses will kill people What we do know is that any vaccine will have all of these effects to some degree. The use of any vaccine is a balance between the adverse and the positive values of it. IN SCIENCE the most important thing you can understand is when you do not know something. It has been the source of more bad experiences in mankind’s history than anything else that assumptions of what we knew were certain were in fact wrong. To say in science “I do not know” is practically the beginning of learning. To admit to yourself that you do not know is quite unsettling to many people. In reality it is usually the best answer you can give to any question. You should not be afraid of lack of knowing. You should be afraid of making a mistake because you think you know.

Unknown. This is new science. Unfortunately, Covid-19 (the particular coronavirus which is a problem this year - there are six older coronaviruses which can infect humans), does not seem to disappear on its own (which often happens with some viruses) nor to evolve quickly (which tends to weaken the power of an early strain). The general answer is “after the world has developed herd immunity.” That might be speeded up if we get, mass produce and widely distribute a safe and effective vaccine. But, unfortunately, in spite of the almost universal assumption we want to go down that road, it is NOT clear either IF or WHEN we will have such a thing. Not once with the previous six kinds of coronaviruses, has a safe and effective vaccine for humans been developed. Worse, the way considerable literature on Covid-19 reads (to my eyes) appears to imply the antibody response does not last very long. Not nearly long enough to make it worth making and distributing a vaccine. [As in, you might have to do it more than once a month. That is not practical.] Regardless, most of the planet will be exposed to this disease in the next year or two. And we will almost certainly develop herd immunity. This is the normal way epidemics and pandemics have been defeated.

Roughly 60–70% of humanity will be infected, with confirmed cases being significantly lower due to lack of testing seen in many countries and asympatomatic cases seen in many patients. The mortality rate will be just over 1%, with millions of deaths. The pandemic will last for 12 months, with the current wave ending in late May to early June. The summer will see a lull in cases, but by the fall of 2020 a second wave will hit as cold weather strikes again. By the spring of 2021 the virus would have hit its carrying capacity and herd immunity would begin to kick in. Social distancing instituted by various governments would successfully flatten the statistical curve, ensuring the health care system isn’t overrun but the pandemic lasts significantly longer. A global recession would be noted as starting in March of 2020, with the first and second quarters of 2020 seeing a sharp decline in economic activity surpassing even the Great Recession of 2007–2009. Unemployment will soar to around 15%, and governmental legislation such as the massive upcoming US stimulus package will only do so much to stem the tide of hurt. Rather than a V shaped recession, the recession would be L shaped. The downturn would further inflame populist sentiment and set the stage for further political upheaval. In the end, humanity will survive as usual, but the novel Coronavirus will change the course of contemporary history.

Russia has become the first nation to complete clinical trials of Covid-19 vaccine on humans, and the results have proven the medication's effectiveness, the media reported on 9 August.  Why is a coronavirus vaccine important? The virus spreads easily and the majority of the world's population is still vulnerable to it. A vaccine would provide some protection by training people's immune systems to fight the virus so they should not become sick. This would allow lockdowns to be lifted more safely, and social distancing to be relaxed. What sort of progress is being made?  Research is happening at breakneck speed. About 140 are in early development, and around two dozen are now being tested on people in clinical trials. A group in China showed a vaccine was safe and led to protective antibodies being made. It is being made available to the Chinese military. Other completely new approaches to vaccine development are in human trials . However, no-one knows how effective any of these vaccines will be. When will we have a coronavirus vaccine?  A vaccine would normally take years, if not decades, to develop. Researchers hope to achieve the same amount of work in only a few months. Most experts think a vaccine is likely to become widely available by mid-2021, about 12-18 months after the new virus, known officially as Sars-CoV-2, first emerged. That would be a huge scientific feat and there are no guarantees it will work. Protect yourself and others around you by knowing the facts and taking appropriate precautions. Follow advice provided by your local health authority. To prevent the spread of COVID-19:  Clean your hands often. Use soap and water, or an alcohol-based hand rub. Maintain a safe distance from anyone who is coughing or sneezing. Wear a mask when physical distancing is not possible. Don’t touch your eyes, nose or mouth. Cover your nose and mouth with your bent elbow or a tissue when you cough or sneeze. Stay home if you feel unwell. If you have a fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical attention. Calling in advance allows your healthcare provider to quickly direct you to the right health facility. This protects you, and prevents the spread of viruses and other infections. Masks Masks can help prevent the spread of the virus from the person wearing the mask to others. Masks alone do not protect against COVID-19, and should be combined with physical distancing and hand hygiene. Follow the advice provided by your local health authority.

It is hard to say. All viral diseases have differing outcomes in the longer term. SARS seems to have vanished altogether. No known cases anywhere in the world since 2004 MERS continues at a low level in Saudi Arabia and some neighbouring countries. Nothing in Europe or the US recently. Ebola flares up in sub-saharan Africa occasionally but is not an issue in the developed world. HIV (a retrovirus not a coronavirus) is still prevelent worldwide. With one or two notable exceptions, no one who contracted HIV has ever “recovered”. They either die or contain the infection by taking suppression therapy. Fortunately those on successful therapy do not infect others. Its the undiagnosed who pose a threat. The HIV patient requires constant monitoring to ensure they have not developed resistance to their current drug regimen. Malaria (a parasitic disease) continues to ravage South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa. 2,000 cases were diagnosed in the USA last year (source CDC). It is the worlds No 1 killer disease with 228M diagnoses in 2018 and 405,000 deaths in 2018 (source WHO). Puts the current Covid-19 pandemic into perspective I guess.

There remains a considerable amount of variability in the timing of controlling the covid. virus. three possible scenarios are given below: 1.Best case –A vaccine developed by the end of 2020 is shown to be effective, and is widely disseminated. As herd immunity is established, the pandemic starts to wind down significantly By the end of 2022 (that’s the lead time to produce and administer the vaccine worldwide) 2. Not quite as good – The vaccine is moderately effective, is partially accepted, and produces resistance in 50 to 60% of the population . There remains a simmering pandemic with local outbreaks, eventually producing herd resistance eventually produced.In this case, the pandemic may began to wind down around 2025 3. Even worse case – The virus morphs into new forms and/or the vaccine or active infection doesn’t produce lasting immunity, resulting in ongoing persistent coronavirus infections . In this case, there likely would be an ongoing level of morbidity and mortality similar to the annual influenza These numbers are highly variable but they should be pretty good guesses

How do you think the coronavirus pandemic will end? In short, a somewhat desecrated landscape to be rebuilt; hopefully better enabled to plan and resist future turmoil in whatever form. Virus Covid-19 - by definition the pandemic ends when recovery is when fewer and fewer new cases occur generally associated with an increasing number of immune persons. Immunity by exposure to the virus whether symptomatic or not OR following immunisation with a vaccine. Hopefully with a vaccine. Then the population develops herd immunity. The few vulnerable individuals are increasingly unlikely to be exposed. Whatever the virus will remain with us, probably forever in its current or a mutated version. We will need to be ever vigilant and maintain immunisation. Community and political attitude - hopefully previous complacency knocked out and replaced by meaningful considerations or actual issues, with foresight to the range of outcomes and potential for unintended consequences. Hopefully knock out complacency on a host of issues including local economy and manufacturing, maintaining a capacity to readily gear up to local self sufficiency, maintaining and improving local environment and ammenities, encourage moral and ethical aspects of all behaviour, and broaden individual skills including reasoning Forward planning - have a standing mechanism for organisation and control to be invoked immediately on suspicion of a pandemic. Really there is no time to lose - as we have seen! Use a fire blanket in the kitchen early or lose most of the house. There is an ever present risk of pandemic as recent events and infections have shown. Quarantine was well established in Australia following 1919, then TB, a few other scourges. Until fairly recently when irreplaceable quarantine assets were sold for gain! Despite future predictors of various recent contagions including SARS and Ebola. Politically the small likelihood of a need for quarantine was not enough to listen to health professionals who all know about pandemics. Doctors have been consistent in warning of the inevitability of a pandemic such as the 1918/19 flu. See Bill Gates 2015 TED TALKS address on not being prepared. So, a huge wakeup call for every human on this planet.

This is a difficult question. Firstly, there are regions of the world that are yet to be effected by Covid-19. Secondly, prematurely ending lockdowns could cause reinfections and prolong the virus outbreak. The virus could mutate and cause another round of the disease. The progression of the virus so far has moved essentially from Asia to Europe and now to The United States. The countries most badly hit have been Italy, Spain, Iran and the United States. The African continent, South America and countries such as India, which have large and vulnerable populations with limited healthcare facilities, are yet to have significant outbreaks of Covid-19, although it is sadly likely that there will be an outbreak in these countries in the coming months. The virus is likely to infiltrate countries at varying times and therefore peak at different times. These countries are not equipped to deal with this kind of medical emergency, the United states is suffering hugely and they are the most powerful nation on earth - imagine how Africa will fare. As China is recovering after almost 3 months of lockdown we should not expect our own countries to go back to normal until at least the same amount of time. What will determine the length of time of the virus outbreak across the globe will be the creation of vaccines, which are not expected to come for up to 1 year, and subsequently how quickly these vaccines can be deployed around the world. The wide distribution of testing for the population will be invaluable as then we can know who has the disease and anti-body tests will tell us who has had the disease so may be immune. Once the virus has been defeated in one country, international travel should be prohibited until the virus is completely wiped out. Otherwise the risk is that the virus spreads again. So far the level of testing has been appalling, not simply because so few have been done, but also because measuring peoples temperatures is not a sure way to test for the virus. Most people show no symptoms or very mild ones ie their temperatures are normal. The only way to tell if they have the virus is by doing proper blood sample tests. It may take only one infected person to slip through the boarders to cause another outbreak and then we are back to square one. To conclude this is a tricky situation. Although the virus may be defeated in our own countries within 3 / 4 months of the start of the outbreak, life will not be back to normal until perhaps the end of 2020 or beginning of 2021 if countries in Africa, South America or India start to have outbreaks.

It depends on what you mean: If you literally mean “Will SARS-CoV-2 ever cease to exist?”, the answer is: Probably not. If it was just a human virus, we could drive it extinct - it sounds crazy, but we’ve actually done that before: see Smallpox - Wikipedia. But assuming the reports of SARS-CoV-2 having an animal origin are correct, there may always be a “reservoir” among those animals. I don’t think it’s physically possible to track down millions of bats and give them all vaccines (or even just kill them) - there are simply too many bats!But if you mean “Will things ever return to normal?”, the answer is: Probably so - daily life will probably return to normal (or at least something much closer to “normal” than where we are right now). It may take a while, but eventually we’ll find a vaccine and/or a cure. Well, either that or everyone will be recovered (and thus hopefully immune) or dead. But either way, most people’s daily lives will cease to revolve around COVID-19. Eventually, it’ll be like the Spanish flu of 1918: something people read about in history books, but not something anyone gives a moment’s thought to otherwise.Unfortunately, it is also possible that we can’t get immunity, or that we lose it in a matter of months. That makes the problem an order of magnitude harder! So until I see convincing evidence otherwise, I’ll continue to assume that we can get immunity. We’ve got our hands full with real problems, so let’s not worry about possibly-nonexistent problems.

Consider that a vaccine would prevent people from contracting the virus, and a drug could help eliminate the severe symptoms of those who have it, and prevent them from giving it to others. As we speak human trials of a vaccine are ongoing in Seattle at a quick pace, and anti-viral drug tests are ongoing in Britain, China and America. Proper science requires numerous human trials with a placebo given to people likely to get the virus and it must be made clearly the the vaccine’s side-effects if any are not severe on the population as a whole. So we are really looking at a year, or year an a half. Clearly our economies and individual sanities cannot sustain living in isolation for such a period, so really the only solution will be when we ramp up the amount of tests so we can test everybody who suspects they were in contact with someone who had it. Next, we enforce isolation on those individuals found to have it, and the rest of society can move to a somewhat normal state with the social distancing policies in place, which may be less extreme than currently. With this in place the number of new cases will decline, and those who had the disease will likely already have an immunity to the virus. The world will enter a period of occasional outbreaks, but swift actions by governments to test those suspected. I believe this is our future for the next year, until scientists have a long-awaited announcement. So in summary until a cure comes, our only hope is to ramp up the testing, results, and isolation policies for those found to have it.

There are two different ways to portray a 'conclusion' to a plague. One is disposal, which is a decrease of new cases to an appropriately low number (ideally zero). The other is annihilation - a clear, perpetual, and complete clearing out of an infectious agent.  The appearance of vaccine has absolutely been one of the significant advances in medical care. It has helped control the spread of a great deal of illnesses. Because of the mass vaccination programs, it has now been a long time since smallpox, a lethal and deforming infection caused by the variola infection, was destroyed from the world. Fortunately, elimination can happen. New Zealand seems to have accomplished elimination and different nations, for example, Vietnam, South Korea and Australia may before long go with the same pattern. In any case, in numerous nations, including India, Covid-19 is by all accounts the unwanted visitor who simply won't leave. Working on New Vaccination Current vaccination, despite the fact that it doesn't include vaccinating material from the scabs of an individual, works on a similar guideline. More vulnerable or inactivated strains of microorganisms are utilized to animate a safe reaction against the pathogen and to give protection against the sickness it causes.  Nonetheless, the examination recommends a digressed, in the form of related and weaker infections to annihilate different diseases. Explaining the significance of their findings, Dr Hendrik Poinar, head of the Ancient DNA Center at McMaster University allegedly stated, "This work focuses to the significance of taking a look at the assorted variety of these vaccine strains discovered in nature. We don't have the foggiest idea that how the number of could give cross-assurance from a wide range of infections, for example, influenza or Covid". The Rise and Fall of an epidemic  The symmetric rise and fall of an epidemic in such pictures is encoded in an empirical principle known as “Farr’s law”, postulated after studying data from smallpox outbreaks. But real Covid-19 data stands in sharp contrast to the neat symmetry of Farr’s law. Whether countries have been fairly successful in controlling their outbreaks (for example Germany and Denmark), or less so (for example the UK and the US), we generally see a rapid rise and relatively slow and uncertain decline in the daily case numbers. Simple situations Simple situation 1. An episode can end since herd immunity develops. In this situation, illness moves through the population, easing back as an ever increasing number of contaminated individuals recuperate and get immunity. The term of the episode relies upon the size of the population, and every day new cases in the end tail off to zero. We see the symmetric rise and fall suggestive of Farr's law and can infer that some cycle like this was behind the information which drove Farr to his law. Toward the finish of the episode, the proportion who have been infected relies upon the essential reproduction number – the alleged "R0 esteem" – of the epidemic. Simulations propose it would not be much underneath 80% for Covid-19, a devastatingly high figure. Simple situation 2. An outbreak can end through the presentation of solid "physical distancing". This ought to be perused to incorporate increased hygiene, mask wearing, avoidance of get-together, and all practices that decrease contamination spreading. In this reproduction, physical distancing starts unexpectedly, and is sufficiently able to lessen R under 1. Day by day new diseases drop promptly and in the long run tail off. In genuine data, we should, inside half a month, see a reasonable drop in day by day cases. With conceivable degrees of physical removing, infection tail off more gradually than they rise, and Farr's law is violated. A vital component of this situation is that in the event that alleviation happens early enough in an outbreak, at that point just a small portion of the total population will wind up being contaminated. Displaying India's Data India's Covid-19 pestilence has been slowed however not contained by the lockdown, which neglected to prevent serious metropolitan outbreaks. With the lockdown getting eased down, the probability of infection being sent out from hotspots to new territories – prompting to leak, in our structure – is increased. Displaying gives numerous conceivable fates for the outbreak, steady with its advancement so far. The following figure shows a simulation whose yields sensibly coordinate Indian recorded diseases to date. This is in no way, shape or form a "forecast" – just a recreation reliable with accessible information, halfway to feature that there is no convincing motivation to accept the outbreak will be over by September. This is a serious idealistic situation: peak in day by day revealed cases is arrived at half a month from now and there is no resulting resurgence. Day by day cases decay to some degree slower than they rose and in the long run hits plateau. Various decisions of model parameters, all predictable with the information to date, change the height and timing of peak, the speed of descent, and the degree of the subsequent plateau. I've read some uplifting news about potential vaccinations for the novel Covid. Does that impact the timeline by any means? It's still too soon to tell. The most recent vaccination update: Early outcomes from a vaccine trial led by analysts at Oxford have demonstrated guarantee. The preliminary, which included 1,077 individuals, demonstrated that an infusion of the immunization made their bodies make antibodies and T-cells that can battle COVID-19. Both are signs that these sound individuals had some kind of immune reaction to the infection.  That is not by any means the only vaccination standing out as truly newsworthy, however. A vaccine in progress by biotech organization Moderna, Inc. (what's more, in organization with the National Institutes of Health) indicated some early achievement in a small human trials. In this specific preliminary, the specialists gave eight solid members two dosages of the immunization beginning in March, and they created novel Covid antibodies. The Moderna competitor antibody is pushing ahead into a bigger, more broad Phase II study that will include several members. From that point onward, the vaccination will move into Phase III, the last phase of vaccine advancement. Along these lines, indeed, that is all energizing news—however it doesn't actually mean you'll be going to games and monster summer shows sooner rather than later in light of the fact that you're inoculated and set to go. So at this moment, a great deal is still open to question, and you shouldn't consider the pandemic over at any point in the near future. There are likewise seven different vaccines at the clinical assessment stage, as indicated by the WHO. Number of gatherings, including the WHO, are focusing in on fair access. Won't that help tackle those worries? Stohr: It would be irresponsible not to do anything. All things considered, most of the total population won't get a vaccine. The infection will proceed to spread, and it could take a few years before the infection has influenced a vast majority of the population. It's not the antibody that will end the pandemic. The infection will end this pandemic by consuming each bit of dry wood it will discover. The fire won't go out before the last powerless individual has been influenced. So what may occur with the novel Covid in the following months? Try not to be astonished if occasions keep on staying canceled or delayed until there is a vaccine—and hope to remain inside, save for basic trips and exercises, and breaking point contact with others for the predictable future. The more individuals who adhere to the guidelines in their general vicinity, the happier we'll all be, specialists concur. Remaining at home and taking other separating measures are "a significant method of hindering the spread of the infection and purchasing time," WHO chief general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, PhD, Tweeted as of late.  However, to genuinely get rid of the infection, Ghebreyesus proceeded to state, "we have to assault the infection with forceful and focused on strategies—testing each speculated case, disconnecting and thinking about each confirmed case, and following and isolating each nearby contact." There is another silver coating here: "As the infection spreads, an ever increasing number of individuals will create immunity to it, so the effect will decay with time," says Dr. Kesh. Once more, however, exactly how long that could take isn't clear. Meanwhile, continue rehearsing the entirety of the hygiene and lifestyle habits you've been hearing again and again. Truly, you'll need to accept circumstances for what they are as COVID-19 forges ahead, as the future stays obscure. In any case, the fate of the Covid pandemic relies upon how we react to it together, and there's plenty you can do to help, specialists to concur. Keep the standards with respect to social distancing and self-isolation in your area, remain quiet (as much as possible!) and adhere to the rudiments, as well. Wash your hands frequently, get them far from your face, recognize what symptoms to pay special mind to, remain in and away from in danger population when you're not well, and energize your loved ones to stick to this same pattern. Hello friends Pankajakasthuri declares final clinical trials of ZingiVir-H as adjunct therapy for COVID-19 patients Patients reported negative RT PCR recovery in an average of five days, all results submitted to AYUSH for necessary approval  By EP News bureao August7, 2020 Read Article Pankajakasthuri Herbals India announced significant success in their study to find a treatment for the novel coronavirus patients. The company released the successful completion of the clinical trials for its tablet, ZingiVir-H as an add-on therapy for the pandemic. The clinical trials were conducted on 116 patients infected by COVID-19 at medical colleges across the country, with 58 being administered Zingivir-H and the rest were given a placebo. The studies found that 58 patients treated with the herbo-mineral drug, ZingiVir-H recovered and reported a negative Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) recovery in an average of five days while others took an average of eight days to recover. The clinical trials of ZingiVir–H have been completed following the guidelines provided by the World Health Organization and the final results have been submitted to the Ministry of Ayurveda, Yoga & Naturopathy, Unani, Siddha and Homoeopathy (AYUSH) for approval. Talking about the completion of the clinical trials, Dr J Hareendran Nair, Founder and MD of Pankaja Kasthuri Herbals and Pankajakasthuri Herbal Research Foundation said, “It gives me immense pride and honour to announce that our medication, ZingiVir–H, has been successful in providing much-needed assistance and help to COVID-19 patients in their recovery. This is one of the first herbo-mineral drug and ayurvedic medicine for COVID-19 that has achieved a negative RT PCR test as a primary endpoint.” The clinical studies took place at KR Hospital, Mysuru, Karnataka; RCSM Medical College and CPR Hospital, Kolhapur, Maharashtra; Saveetha Medical College and Hospital, Chennai, Tamil Nadu and ESIC Medical College and Hospital, Faridabad, Haryana. “We wanted to test the efficacy of the drug, which is made with seven ingredients, on patients in various hospitals across the country. This has further encouraged us and strengthened our belief that Ayurveda-based drugs can play a vital role in this fight against COVID-19. We are also soon planning to announce the results of the ongoing clinical trial with standalone treatment on 135 patients”, Dr Nair added. Commenting on the Ministry of AYUSH to expedite the process of necessary approvals for all the Ayurveda drugs that are undergoing clinical trials in various hospitals in the country, Dr Nair said, “Today, when millions of people suffering from this harmful disease and are in hospitals battling the virus, I would like to urge the Ministry of AYUSH to support scientifically-backed modern Ayurveda-based treatments and drugs that have long-lasting benefits and can help save lives. At PKHIL, we are equipped to scale up and meet the requirements of the nation, once necessary approvals are issued by the ministry.” Pankajakasthuri Herbals India submitted the first reports of ZingiVir-H to Ministry of AYUSH at the end of June 2020, while the interim report of 42 patients examined by a peer review committee was submitted on July 8 and the primary endpoint result of 116 patients was submitted to on July 24. The company is expecting the final decision from the ministry soon

There are still many unknowns that might affect how deadly recurring waves of COVID-19 might be. We don’t yet know, for example, how long someone remains immune to the novel coronavirus after an infection. “The No. 1 thing we think about in terms of whether something is going to be endemic or whether it’s possible to eradicate it is whether immunity is permanent or long-lasting,” says Emily Toth Martin, an associate professor of immunology at the University of Michigan’s School of Public Health. “If you’ve got a virus where immunity can wane over time and someone can get reinfected, that is a very difficult virus for it to be eradicated.” With the other four coronaviruses currently endemic in humans, we know that immunity disappears gradually over time — it likely takes years. Adults might get infected with the same virus they had as a child. But even this kind of temporary immunity could be crucial in the short term. Doctors who have already been infected could treat patients without worrying about becoming sick. The same goes for other essential workers, like grocery store clerks, nursing home aides, delivery people and others. And even if someone gets sick with the coronavirus again, the second infection might not be as bad. With other viruses, there’s evidence that, even if someone is reinfected, their immune system might be better equipped to handle it the second time around, Martin says. A virus’ mutation rate is another important factor in determining the severity of reappearances of an endemic virus. The flu is so pervasive because it mutates readily, swapping around the surface proteins that our immune systems rely on to recognize viruses. “You can get a new flu infection every year because your antibodies are not necessarily as protective,” says Andrew Brouwer, a research scientist and epidemiological modeler also at the University of Michigan’s School of Public Health. “We don’t really know what that’s going to look like for this virus.” Another big unknown right now is when a vaccine will be available.This is something that’s going to be with us for some time, or for the foreseeable future, just like the other coronaviruses,” Adalja says. For that reason, “it’s incumbent upon us to make a vaccine to eliminate it as a threat.

There are 3 factors in the general disease triangle which can determine the severity of the effects of a disease. If the environment is conducive for the growth of the disease causing pathogen, the host is susceptible to the disease causing pathogen and the pathogen itself is virulent enough to produce disease symptoms in the in the host individual; it can cause a disease in the host.  There is no way to exactly predict when and how will this catastrophe end unless we have a necessary statistical model. But in simpler and vague terms this disease shall end when one of these factors is no longer effective . This can be possible in one or more of the following scenarios: COVID 19 is no longer virulent. It has lost it’s ability to cause disease in humans. It can be a result of genetic mutations in the makeup of the virus.Environment is no longer conducive to support its growth. We can expect the Coronavirus to become ineffective under different environments and weathers.Humans are no longer susceptible. This can be possible if Humans develop resilience to the virus by immunisation discovered vaccines.These are just such examples and assumptions for how the catastrophe can end. There can be many other possibilities.

The human COVID-19 epidemic ends when by unwavering commitment to a total containment - 'bending the curve' from skyward to flat to downwards to repeated weeks of numbers in every jurisdiction sufficiently low that there can be near instant contact tracings done to locate and isolate all possible infected. When we have a consistent 'statistically 0′ new infections count. Or if (with a remotely possible ‘when’) a safe effective vaccine is developed. Because COVID-19 won’t 'go away'. It is always going to be out there in the wilderness - in members of numerous host species. We know of bats, civet cats, pangolins, and camels. We'd be fools to presume there aren't various other host species. This is why it is vital that we commit to containing and completely erasing COVID-19 from the human population. Then, with extreme vigilance, we've a good likelihood of catching now well known CoV-2 COVID-19 earlier when it next finds an unwitting human host.

Technically the pandemic is over when the continued death rate reaches a certain level. Defining COVID19 as a pandemic will be recinded. From a immunological standpoint - it ends when the virus reaches complete burn out phase. Meaning it has lost its ability to travel through the population and survive. In other words, there are no more people to infect. Viral mutation among SARS coronaviruses is very rare, so like the previous six SARS viruses, it will reach its limit of infection and die out. This happened with SARS-CoV1, Zika, West Nile, MERS, and H1N1. You don’t hear about these pathogens anymore because our immune systems adapted and the virus has little to no chance of infecting large portions of the population anymore. This will happen with SARS-CoV2 because that is what SARS coronaviruses do. Unlike influenza A, which mutates slightly every year and does not evoke an strong immune response, you can get it every year. More virulent viral strains burn out in the population because we make strong, lasting antibody responses.

What I think you're truly asking is, When will life start to return to normal? Our best answer to that is, when we can treat the disease and it's no longer spreading wildly. This will require proper disease control and the development of a safe, effective vaccine. Remember, in the strictest sense, that is, zero known cases existing, only smallpox and rinderpest have been truly eradicated. All other diseases are dealt with via prevention and treatment: babies get vaccinated against mumps and measles; PreP helps keep people from getting HIV, and medicines can keep it from blossomong into AIDS in those who have it, so it's no longer a death sentence, but it still exists; you still have to get a flu shot every year. In time, with the proper behaviors and tools, Covid-19 may no longer be a grave threat, but it's likely the disease itself will be with us for a long time.

Ah, about 180 or so. And some changes will be permanent. Since we are using the ancient methods of quarantine, social distancing, masks and other physical methods to evade a rampant corona virus, we’re simply dodging a hail of bullets, not disabling the gun. Inexplicably, viruses do become dormant, so this one will too, but we have no idea if that will be next week, next month or next year. The worst thing we could do is assume we do know, come out of hiding, and get socked by the reserve bullet supply, This has happened before; San Francisco executed a near-perfect, textbook virus response in 1918, then relaxed quarantine quickly and experienced a huge backlash infection and death rate with a second round of that pandemic. So, there are no guarantees, no assurances, no realities except that it’s a really good idea to wear a mask, stay away from others and keep clean.

In China it will probably end in April. By examining the rate of discharges at hospitals and the requirement that no new cases be detected for multiple consecutive days before the lockdown is lifted, it is foreseeable that china could become the first country to declare itself free of the disease by early to mid April. This wouldn’t mean to lower their guard or stop testing at transportation hubs and points of entry or other vulnerable places. Far from it. It will be on everyone mind until a vaccine is proven to be safe and effective. Not so fast for other countries in the world. Countries taking earlier strong preventive and containment actions with considerable combat capabilities (Testing, Case tracking, isolation) will be the first to re-emerge as disease free. this brings us back to the role and responsibilities for China in helping struggling countries pull out from this. They have immense industrial and technical expertise in dealing with the situation at scale. This is not only a great public relations opportunity but also common business sense.

The Covid-19 virus and its various mutations are here to stay. However, humanity will learn to deal with it with vaccines and drugs in due course. From Covid 19 Lockdown: How Soon Should We Open Up? | Sramana Mitra This comment is about the timeline for treatment, a vital piece of the opening up puzzle. There are two drugs (and many more under investigation) that look promising: hydroxychloroquine and remdisivir. Results from gold standard trials are expected in June. If either or both work, then opening up broadly this summer is a no brainer. This is the best case scenario. [Detailed and credible analysis provided by Wired and The Economist] If treatment that can be administered without overwhelming hospital capacity is available within a couple of months, then the fact that the vaccines may take 18 months to come through is a manageable issue. However, opening up without severe checks and balances now, in my assessment, would be inviting massive second wave cases and deaths. My guess (based on lots of reading) is that there will be a temporary reduction in new cases due to mitigation efforts. Governments will most likely understand what works to contain the spread, and tests will be readily available. Scientists will work to develop vaccines and antivirals, but nothing is guaranteed. Medical professionals will learn what works and what doesn’t in terms of treatments for the elderly. Wishful thinking is that vaccines will be ready to go before 2021 flu season. This cycle will recur until vaccines and or antivirals are developed. Hopefully this will be by mid 2021. Coronavirus will likely mutate, so it will be essential to keep remaking vaccines as we do with the flu every year. We will have a shaky 12–18 months until we learn to deal with it.

Well it basically depends on how well people follow the guidelines set out by the governments. If the people follow the guidelines and stick to the social distancing protocols, then the virus can peak in around 2–3 months, and after that pass away. But if they do not correctly follow the guidelines, then the virus can last for much, much longer. The reason why social distancing has the power to achieve that is because the virus cannot jump to a new host if people do not stand close enough to each other to catch particles from another person breathing, talking, or coughing. Therefore, if people stay away from each other, then what will happen is the virus will be combated inside of one person’s body, but no longer be able to find a new host. Ergo, it will die off and cease to exist once the one person recovers.  The virus can also live on surfaces for a while, therefore it will not completely die off straight away, however governments and businesses are also working well to disinfect areas and commonly touched objects. So if people stick to the social distancing protocols and remain at least 1.5 meters away from others at all times, then the virus can reach the peak of its activity in around 2–3 months, which means that afterwards it will start to decline and there will be fewer and fewer cases.

“Is the coronavirus pandemic almost over?” Where? There were 14 new cases in Australia today, with 1 new death, and those are high number for them. New Zealand had 1 new case today, and that was the first in the country since May 14th. The last COVID-19 death in New Zealand was on May 14th. These nations, along with Germany, China, South Korea and a few others, have the disease well controlled. But even they cannot relax. With so few cases, they can rely on widespread testing rather than quarantining everyone, but they must maintain vigilance and may need to re-institute lockdowns. In the U. S., both the number of cases and the number of deaths is increasing slightly. Some areas (e.g. New York and Washington state) are looking fairly good, but others (Montgomery county in Alabama) are looking pretty bad. There is no end in sight for the United States.

It continues to spread because it can. It’s what pandemics do. Most people are still completely susceptible to it and the virus is not weakening. More importantly, not enough people are serious about preventing the spread. (Many aggressively resist all the normal protective and preventive measures such as distancing and wearing masks). As long as this behaviour persists, the virus will continue to spread until a large proportion (55–60%) of the population has (1) been infected, provided they survive, or (2) carries protective T-cells, or (3) has been vaccinated. Globally, less than a million deaths have happened so far. The 1957 and 1968 pandemics of influenza (this is NOT influenza), killed between 1–4 million. The 1918 influenza pandemic killed at least 18 million (at a time when the world’s population was only 1.8 billion (currently the global population is more than four times that figure). Expect a lot more spread.

What if we never manage to find a vaccine for Covid-19? Covid-19: what will happen if no coronavirus vaccine is developed? As the search to find a vaccine for Covid-19 continues, doubts about its feasibility persist. In this context, WHO (World Health Organization) warns that one must also be prepared for the possibility that the long-awaited vaccine never arrives. If there is no reason to panic, however, we must start to consider incorporating these new health habits for good. Since the start of the Coronavirus, there has been a subject that has come back to the table very regularly for obvious reasons: the vaccine. For months now, many laboratories around the world have embarked on a frantic race to synthesize the molecule capable of immunizing us … Except that many actors, especially political ones, were a little wrong by skipping the question of “If” to go directly to the “when” one. However, before knowing when a vaccine will hit the market, the first question is indeed whether such a vaccine is conceptually possible. And for now, that’s still anything but a guarantee: There is a very real probability that the long-awaited Grail will never come and that we will be forced to live with this virus. This is also a point on which the WHO (World Health Organization) has been keen to make a strong point. “There is no panacea and there may never be,” said the Director-General. organization, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, at an online press conference. Certainly, some clinical trials are already underway and raise hopes that are as legitimate as they are realistic on the likelihood of obtaining a vaccine in the long term. But without giving in to catastrophism and dismissing the work of researchers from the outset, it would be irresponsible to take this possibility for granted.

It's impossible to say with any degree of certainty just how long the COVID-19 pandemic that took the world by storm in early 2020 will last. There are two ways to describe an 'end' to a plague. One is elimination, which is a reduction of new cases to a suitably low number (preferably zero). The other is eradication - a clear, permanent, and complete wiping out of an infectious agent. While much has been learned about the virus's ability to spread between people, infect cells, and put infected people at risk of a range of major health problems, estimating its duration in a global population depends on how we all behave, which can be much harder to model. Much as predictions on climate change vary depending on how we act now, it might be possible to propose scenarios that similarly forecast the different futures facing us.

Here are some straight up facts. The best case scenario that the administration has highlighted is between 100K to 240K deaths in the US. I understand this is a broad range and it is difficult to estimate anything narrower than that with the data we currently have. As of yesterday, there have been just over 5,100 deaths in the US. This means that going by the projections, we're at best 5% of the way through this nightmare and possibly only 2.125% of the way through it. While I appreciate all the optimism floating around, I do also want us to be realistic here and understand that this is not going to be an overnight fix. We must brace ourselves psychologically for this storm and know that no matter how hard, this too shall pass. So keep the challenges and fun games and high spirits coming; let's do everything we can so spread some smiles through this ordeal. Isolation is not easy; even more so for those of us who live alone and away from their near and dear ones. I want us all to support and be there for each other as best we can through these difficult times. Remember that we're all in this together, and, the only way we win this war, is together.   The difference between solitude and loneliness is choice.    So if you are sad, lonely, upset, worried or depressed and just need someone to listen, pick up that phone and call your friends and loved ones. It is okay to feel this way; it is okay to feel vulnerable and scared in these unprecedented times. And if you can't think of anyone to reach out to, hit me up and I'll be honored to listen to your concerns. Stay safe everyone! Take care!  In case we haven’t met before, I’m Rohan Kamath. Thank you for reading. I hope I could help you smile today. :)

No. The only means of getting well is one’s own immune system. Many people seem to think that a vaccine is going to “make them immune”. This is a big fallacy and unfortunately one propagated by the medical industry. A vaccine only gives one an opportunity to develop antibodies, nothing more. Vaccine or no vaccine a person can still get infected. A person’s immune system is the only way to a cure. The immune system must be working to capacity to either generate the antibodies or use any antibodies created by way of a vaccine and clear away the virus. If the immune system is declined, no amount of any vaccine or any other medicines is going to “cure” the infection. However a person can arrest the problem of declined immunity by recognizing that the real danger is in the infection and not anything external such as fear of losing one’s job etc. With this realization the immune system goes into full swing and destroys the virus, i.e., cures the infection.

Prediction of future event is a risky enterprise to one’s reputation. Nevertheless, I am curious whether certain growth model (e.g. the height of a person) can do the job of addressing this important question. Many unknowns drive anxiety in this stressful situation. It may be useful to many to have a feel of what’s going to happen. Whether the results reported here make me look like a fool or otherwise, you will get to know in three months’ time from today (28 March) On 27 March, I did a quantitative modeling of the number of Covid-19 infection cases, using the data from the readily available website: www.worldometers.info/coronavirus. The global infection started around 21 February, when Italy began to experience massive infection that follows, and it is called Day 0. I ran a curve fitting algorithm on the latest 34 data points (green dots) and then extrapolated the number of cases to future dates by solving a math problem that involves a (generalized) logistic function. Based on the data fitting result, it is certain that at the present moment, the number of cases is accelerating. Around Day 57 in the above plot, which is May 17, there will be an inflection point where thereafter the number of cases will decelerate. But since the infection confirmation is delayed by about 2 weeks, so add 2 weeks to Day 57 and the model suggests 31 May to be the inflection or turning point. What it means is that the worst is over. My guess is that Africa is the next continent that might see a dramatic increase after Europe and America. The model suggests that by June 24, at least Singapore and Japan, for example, will see single-digit cases sporadically, as the number of cases is tapering off (analogy: the height of a youth is not increasing as much anymore). Caution: This is the most optimistic scenario. As always, extrapolation is fraud with falsehood. So believe the model at your own risk.

Agree with Lokesh — nobody knows. CDC offers an on-line training platform at https://www.cdc.gov/csels/dsepd/ss1978/lesson1/index.html called “Principles of Epidemiology in Public Health Practice, Third Edition
An Introduction to Applied Epidemiology and Biostatistics” One can follow through the lessons and learn all about epidemiology. The final section https://www.cdc.gov/csels/dsepd/ss1978/lesson6/section2.html illustrates with time series graphics how previous outbreaks of disease came and went. From https://www.healthline.com/health/r-nought-reproduction-number#covid-19-r-0 We know R0 (pronounced R-naught) — the probable one-to-many infection rate — is 5.7 — one person infects 5.7 others — a terribly high. “With an R0 of 5.7, at least 82 percent of the population needs to be immune to COVID-19 to stop its transmission through vaccination and herd immunity.” If no vaccine becomes available, with great fear, we can watch on this web page https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/ as the daily numbers increase, and we can watch — among other projections — my predictions for USA cases and deaths at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1NMyNhAKGKowW-uvpqeIiU4j4AnFZm22rp0cL97aT9jY/edit#gid=0 where tomorrow’s forecast = today * (1 + (today - yesterday)/yesterday) [ remarkably similar to the Einstein-Hilbert equation w = (u + v) / (1 + u * v / c^2) ] In the USA alone, 82% of the total USA population of 328.2 is 269.1 million. Let’s call that the herd immunity level. My worksheet “How long till herd immunity” https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1NMyNhAKGKowW-uvpqeIiU4j4AnFZm22rp0cL97aT9jY/edit#gid=302222547 forecasts that in the USA, we reach total cases of 269.1 million (270,765,395) on 09/29/2021 — September 29, 2021 (Row 481 on the worksheet). Can R0 be changed? Yes! We know the methods — wearing masks to protect others from our emissions and to protect us from theirs; buildup of immunity by maintaining good health; avoiding large crowds (sorry about that); isolation of known cases, and more. I can change the factors in the worksheet, but the numbers don’t lie. Absent a medical breakthrough, a sudden drop on R0, or a sudden jump in herd immunity, we’re in a for a long struggle against SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19.

When/If people start treating this thing like the world-war-like situation it is and there are executives in charge who know what they’re doing. It won’t be possible to do shut down the economy completely. There will be new waves. It’s too late to trace people. We need to get to near-universal testing and a partial restart, where people with comorbidities (including high age) continue to stay home. We need to start putting ill patients on precautionary ox-y-gen = O2 — not ventilators, as it’s increasingly obvious lung disease is not the primary problem here. Perhaps infected people with comorbidities could be housed in convention centers for that purpose, with one giant central O2 supply line providing them 24/7? The key here is that in severe cases the oxygen saturation drops so low, so fast, that by the time they go to the hospital it’s often already too late. Infected people who are low risk, should stay home and receive home delivery meals and a daily checkup to test their oxygen saturation. Their housemates should be considered already infected. We would IMHO be greatly helped if we would take a more mature look at the excentric French doctor’s results, which have been unfairly maligned because Trump prematurely endorsed them. His cohort now has a death reate of just ~0.4%, over >3,000 previously hospitalized patients: COVID-19 - IHU. If we do all that, it could IMHO end pretty quickly. If not, most of us probably will eventually get it, before it turns endemic (in less lethal form, like a second flu) or it would disappear (due to herd immunity).

The only truthful answer is that nobody knows. Definitions count though. The covid pandemic now working its way around the globe already has several different strains circulating. In that respect the first strain pandemic may be nearly over already, while a second and third get going. If anybody knows, with certainty, that having had one strain protects you from both reinfection by that strain (acquired immunity) and from close relatives of that strain then that would be great news. However, some sources say immunity wears off in months- in which case people who were infected in the spring may be reinfected in the autumn or winter. If immunity wears off that is bad news for vaccines ending the problem once and for all. If strains become different enough that any acquired immunity falls away that’s a problem too, as it means we can expect seasonal problems just like flu (in seasonality, not symptoms) and so annual vaccinations may be necessary. (One of the reasons, apart from the obvious immediate humanitarian needs to build major production facilities around the world.) I apologise for the vagueness here. I’m not a prophet, and I read what you probably do- serious newspapers and a few online serious sources. Too many people see a profit in creating confusion and uncertainty, offering their own cures and preventive measures. Some of them write here. I trust the thousands of medical researchers rather than businessmen with a profit motive.

History of Smallpox Quote” In 1959, the World Health Organization (WHO) initiated a plan to rid the world of smallpox. Unfortunately, this global eradication campaign suffered from lack of funds, personnel, and commitment from countries, as well as a shortage of vaccine donations. Despite their best efforts, smallpox was still widespread in 1966, causing regular outbreaks in multiple countries across South America, Africa, and Asia. The Intensified Eradication Program began in 1967 with a promise of renewed efforts. This time, laboratories in many countries where smallpox occurred regularly (endemic countries) were able to produce more, higher quality freeze-dried vaccine. A number of other factors also played an important role in the success of the intensified efforts, including the development of the bifurcated needle, establishment of a surveillance system to detect and investigate cases, and mass vaccination campaigns, to name a few. By the time the Intensified Eradication Program began in 1967, smallpox had already been eliminated in North America (1952) and Europe (1953), leaving South America, Asia, and Africa (smallpox was never widespread in Australia). The Program made steady progress toward ridding the world of this disease, and by 1971 smallpox was eradicated from South America, followed by Asia (1975), and finally Africa (1977). “Unquote

Public health experts around the globe are scrambling to understand, track, and contain a new virus that appeared in Wuhan, China, at the beginning of December 2019. The World Health Organization named the disease caused by the virus COVID-19, which references the type of virus and the year it emerged. The WHO declared that the virus is a pandemic. The Verge is regularly updating this page with all the latest news and analysis. You can see where and how many cases of the illness have been reported in this map. The majority of the illnesses were initially in China, where the virus first emerged, but the rate of new cases there has nearly stopped. There are now many times more cases outside of China than there were inside of it at the height of the outbreak. There are large outbreaks of the disease in multiple places, including Spain, Italy, and the United States, which currently has the worst outbreak of any country in the world. As this important story continues to unfold, our hope is to answer all of your questions as people work to understand this virus and contain its spread. Table of contents Where did the virus come from?Where is it spreading?How dangerous is this new virus?How easily can the virus spread?Can we treat this virus?What can I do to protect myself and others?Should I travel?How at risk is the United States?Where did the virus come from? At the end of December, public health officials from China informed the World Health Organization that they had a problem: an unknown, new virus was causing pneumonia-like illness in the city of Wuhan. They quickly determined that it was a coronavirus and that it was rapidly spreading through and outside of Wuhan.  Photo by Kevin Frayer/Getty Images Coronaviruses are common in animals of all kinds, and they sometimes can evolve into forms that can infect humans. Since the start of the century, two other coronaviruses have jumped to humans, causing the SARS outbreak in 2002 and the MERS outbreak in 2012. Scientists think this new virus first became capable of jumping to humans at the beginning of December. It originally seemed like the virus first infected people at a seafood market in Wuhan and spread from there. But one analysis of early cases of the illness, published January 24th, found that the first patient to get sick did not have any contact with the market. Experts are still trying to trace the outbreak back to its source.

While the SARS virus replicated deep in people’s lungs, probably contributing to the higher mortality rate, that also made it less likely to spread than the COVID-19 virus, said Dr. Stanley Perlman, a microbiologist at the University of Iowa who studies coronaviruses. The new coronavirus grows in people’s noses and airways, so it can be more easily spread through coughing and sneezing, like the flu, he said. Though people with SARS probably weren’t contagious until they were very ill, that isn’t the case for COVID-19, so it will be harder to catch people before they infect others, he said. “As soon as you start having very, very minor symptoms, that sore throat, that itchiness, that sneezing, then you’re contagious,” Perlman said. “I don’t think it’s going to be like SARS and just go away.” SARS killed hundreds and then disappeared. Q: How does the Covid-19 outbreak end? A: There seem to be several possibilities. Worst case: almost everyone is infected BEFORE an effective vaccine appears. Mortality is ~4% in 1st world nations, but maybe 10% in 3rd world nations. Up to 1/2 of 80 year olds die; up to 1/3 of 70 year olds die. Total deaths exceed 500 million.Best case: Containment and quarantines work, and less than 5% of the population in 1st world countries and 20% of the population in 3rd world countries are infected over the next 12 months. What’s more, the milder version of COVID-19 that appears to be circulating, becomes the dominant strain, resulting in an average mortality of 2% or less. And finally, an effective vaccine is delivered world-wide in 12 months or less. Total world wide deaths are less than 15 million.Middling case #1: Containment & quarantines work somewhat, but not as well as they appear to be working in China. (There are reports now that they aren’t actually working that well in China, either. We’ll see.) A vaccine takes 18 months, and is only partially effective. World wide infections reach 50% in total, with an average mortality of 4%. World-wide deaths exceed 100 million. COVID-19 continues to circulate as a seasonally serious disease.Middling case #2, etc: You shuffle the possibilities,and pick!Bottom line? Nobody knows, except God. There can be a few different questions drawn from this one. When will the lockdowns and stay-at-home orders be lifted? It depends on the state. Some may lift them in May, but others will likely stagger the reopenings of businesses throughout the summer. But even then, most sporting events will be played in empty arenas, and most theaters, museums, and restaurants will limit how many people can go in. However, in the fall, governments may reimpose the measures to prevent a second wave from hitting. When will the nonstop global media coverage of the virus end? COVID-19-related events will appear on the front pages of newspapers and be the main focus of TV and internet news from now until at least 2022. And such events will probably continue to appear in the news, at least intermittantly, until around 2025 or so. What will happen with the virus eventually? The virus will become one with the seasonal flu (endemic). While vaccinations will eventually prevent another pandemic like this one, the COVID-19 frenzy will reappear for the next 5–10 winters.

It will probably begin to peter out in mid-summer. By then we will still be dealing with death and economic destruction. After a few quiet months, it will roar back in October or November, just as the 1918 Flu Pandemic did. Our only prayer is that it does not get worse, like the 1918 Flu did. It will sweep around the world once again unless we put even more stringent controls in place. I suspect Trump will queer the election because of the virus, then drop contaminated samples into Iran.

I think it will end at some point in 2022, or if we are lucky and manage to deploy a vaccine earlier than that, in late 2021. The shortest historical pandemic I know of was the 1918 Flu Pandemic, which lasted 2 years. It’s a great example of an uncontrolled pandemic that just burned its way through the world without meaningful countermeasures, until it mutated into less deadly strains and natural immunity established itself from exposure.  For those hoping the world can do what China did; that solution does not stop the pandemic once it is global like this. It just resets the exponential growth curve. While most cases run their course during quarantine, you eventually have to lift the quarantine. There will still be carriers. People who made a mistake. Without herd immunity, it starts again from those people, in a sort of reset clock, but over the course of months, and starts again. No country can quarantine forever or it will collapse under the economic strain of it. I would not be at all surprised if some countries don’t make it through the first one. The USA and many European countries do not have the level of totalitarian power need enforce a quarantine, which means they rely mainly on the people’s voluntary compliance. That’s not going to work with the entire lamentably huge “moron” portion of the population. The only way the pandemic ends, as others have noted, is when all of the virus strains mutate into a less deadly form, a vaccine is created and universally distributed, or most people get infected and herd immunity is established. If it behaves like pandemic influenza viruses, SARS CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19, may go away in 30–40 years or it may remain with us much longer. The fact that it is most severe in older folks suggests that we are unlikely to evolve any sort of innate resistance since the pressure is not felt until long most of us are done reproducing. I am somewhat pessimistic about an effective, safe vaccine anytime soon. The jury is still out on if and how often people become reinfected. The isolated reports may be real or they may represent recrudescences of the initial infection. If natural infections provide minimal protective immunity, one can hardly expect vaccines to be better. I expect the initial vaccines will be better than nothing but are likely to have some relatively severe side effects. To some extent, it is a good thing we will be targeting old folks who have one foot in the grave to begin with rather than young children as we would have to live with the damage we would do kids much longer.

There’s nothing much to hang hope on as far as an end to it coming any time soon. We can’t cure colds and we can’t cure seasonal flu. It’s likely C19 will be around for quite awhile. A vaccine will be helpful. But that’s a mitigation measure (same as it is with seasonal flu) and not a cure. We need that asap, though, in order to imbue the health care system with carrying capacity. If C19 patients are taking up all the ICU beds, we’re in dire straits. Additional knock-on deaths will occur because there are a bunch of elderly patients (and young ones who encounter accidents and other ailments) that will not get the care they need. Not to mention a natural disaster that might happen concurrently.

Our susceptibility to it will drop to very small numbers once we have ‘herd immunity’, but it will be like seasonal flu. It will never truly ‘go away’.

Do you expect COVID-19 to continue to spread? We can get little glimpses into the future from places that are recently getting infected, places that aren’t infected, but also the places where it all started. And if you go back and look at China right now, they [identified the virus] in early January, they had a full on response, sort of threw everything at it, and it’s middle of March now and they estimate maybe end of March they’ll be coming out of it, so a full three months. When you look around the world in Europe, North America, the Middle East, you can see that we’re really at the period of exponential growth, we’re still seeing the virus going up very, very rapidly, even in hard hit places like Italy, for example. These countries still have months of this challenge in front of them. When you look to other parts of the world, like Africa, for example, and parts of the Indian subcontinent you can see that it’s just beginning. Even though they have very, very few cases, if you look carefully at that curve, it’s also in a phase of exponential growth. Looking further into the future, what do you anticipate? Will COVID-19 ever disappear? What it looks like is that we’re going to have a substantial wave of this disease right through basically the globe unless something very different happens in the southern hemisphere. And the question then is: What’s going to happen? Is this going to disappear completely? Are we going to get into a period of cyclical waves? Or are we going to end up with low level endemic disease that we have to deal with? Most people believe that that first scenario where this might disappear completely is very, very unlikely, it just transmits too easily in the human population, so more likely waves or low level disease. A lot of that is going to depend on what we as countries, as societies, do. If we do the testing of every single case, rapid isolation of the cases, you should be able to keep cases down low. If you simply rely on the big shut down measures without finding every case, then every time you take the brakes off, it could come back in waves. So that future frankly, may be determined by us and our response as much as the virus. What countries are in the most vulnerable situation? Everyone is vulnerable, but the big question of course is what’s going to happen when this really starts to take off in those low-income countries where they don’t have as much medical capacity such as in Africa. It’s one of those things that you don’t want to imagine because the numbers could be so grave. The population distribution could help. Is the humidity and the temperature going to help make a difference? I would hope so, but look at the situation in Singapore, that’s a hot, humid country. So the situation in these countries could be very difficult.

The Wuhan Coronavirus outbreak in still in its infancy. Early models called for only a 5.1% detection rate versus actual infections. So anyone saying this is under control is fooling themselves. Wuhan is essentially under martial law. The military is converting the covered sports arenas in Wuhan into quarantine centers according to relatives and friends we have there. They are also taking over the gigantic Expo Convention Center in Hankou near epicenter for a quarantine center. This is in addition to a couple of new thousand bed quarantine facilities just constructed. You don’t do this if everything is under control. Shanghai just closed all of their schools for the entire month of February. 7,000 nurses are on strike in Hong Kong because they want access cutoff to the mainland China. Many quarantine centers are quietly being setup in the US including one 20 miles from my home in Washington State. Fortunately the early stats show a low death rate at 2%+-. However, numbers will most likely balloon when testing catches up with infections so even with a low death rate, the numbers may end up quite large given models and actual numbers to date relative to those models. My heart goes out to all of our Chinese brethren.

I am unaware of any viruses that are properly named after their country of origin. Even the massively devastating so called “Spanish Flu” has been speculated to have originated in the United States. It would be fair to say that virtually every country will have been the origin of their own viruses. Naming rights usually go to discoverers. In the case of viruses, as for many natural phenomena, there seems to be some naming conventions that pretty much determine what a virus might be called. As best I understand it Covid 19 is a derivation of coronavirus disease of 2019 which would be quite a mouthful so Covid 19 is used as shorthand - a practice that is very common in technical fields (particularly in my profession - aviation). Calling a virus “the China virus” is like naming a venereal disease after the person you got it from to you when you are equally culpable for failing to wear a condom, or like naming the delayed United States Covid 19 response the “Trump retard” when the POTUS’s failures are just one component of the problem the US and other countries are facing with the advent of this virus. There are many potential lessons to learn from our failures up to now and every country, state, district, city, suburb, business, family, and individual. In the aviation industry we have mostly got past the knee jerk reaction of blaming accidents purely on pilot error or any single cause. These days accident investigations seek to obtain lessons for all parts of the system and it is considered extremely poor practice to attribute an accident’s cause solely to the final error before the event. As for the individuals and groups who are trying to rename Covid 19, I found a couple of biblical references that are likely to apply (there are others!) Mathew 7:15–20 You will know them by their fruits Romans 14:10 Leave the judgement up to God China has shown that they learn from each outbreak (China’s response to a novel coronavirus stands in stark contrast to the 2002 SARS outbreak response). China will do their own investigations for their own part. It will be imperfect but so will everybody else’s. So in closing I refer to another biblical reference. Mathew 7:3 And why worry about a speck in your friend’s eye when you have a log in your own? Let’s concentrate on getting our own houses in order and we will all be better off.

All vaccines work according to the same basic principle. They present part or all of the pathogen to the human immune system, usually in the form of an injection and at a low dose, to prompt the system to produce antibodies to the pathogen. Antibodies are a kind of immune memory which, having been elicited once, can be quickly mobilised again if the person is exposed to the virus in its natural form.The problem is making sure the vaccine gets to all those who need it. This is a challenge even within countries, and some have worked out guidelines. In the scenario of a flu pandemic, for example, the UK would prioritise vaccinating healthcare and social care workers, along with those considered at highest medical risk – including children and pregnant women – with the overall goal of keeping sickness and death ra tes as low as possible. But in a pandemic, countries also have to compete with each other for medicines.Because pandemics tend to hit hardest those countries that have the most fragile and underfunded healthcare systems, there is an inherent imbalance between need and purchasing power when it comes to vaccines. During the 2009 H1N1 flu pandemic, for example, vaccine supplies were snapped up by nations that could afford them, leaving poorer ones short. But you could also imagine a scenario where, say, India – a major supplier of vaccines to the developing world – not unreasonably decides to use its vaccine production to protect its own 1.3 billion-strong population first, before exporting any.Outside of pandemics, the WHO brings governments, charitable foundations and vaccine-makers together to agree an equitable global distribution strategy, and organisations like Gavi, the vaccine alliance, have come up with innovative funding mechanisms to raise money on the markets for ensuring supply to poorer countries. But each pandemic is different, and no country is bound by any arrangement the WHO proposes – leaving many unknowns. As Seth Berkley, CEO of Gavi, points out: “The question is, what will happen in a situation where you’ve got national emergencies going on?”This is being debated, but it will be a while before we see how it plays out. The pandemic, says Wilder-Smith, “will probably have peaked and declined before a vaccine is available”. A vaccine could still save many lives, especially if the virus becomes endemic or perennially circulating – like flu – and there are further, possibly seasonal, outbreaks. But until then, our best hope is to contain the disease as far as possible. To repeat the sage advice: wash your hands.
