response.answer_text: No, in fact, there will be no end whatsoever to the Covid-19 virus. That does not mean that the present chaotic conditions won’t come to an end. Right now they are trying to get it under control so thinks can, eventually, return back, at least somewhat, to normal. We will be developing what they call a “herd immunity” to the virus by virtue of so many people having contracted it and then surviving thus becoming immune to it. The virus will have, then, a much harder time finding a host to infect that is not immune which will make it much more difficult to infect people. Also, within a year to 18 months, they will probably have a vaccine developed which, when administered, will make you immune to the virus, at least for a given amount of time. The virus itself, they think, first appeared in infected bats which were eaten by some Chinese and, in those people, it evolved to a point where it could be passed from one human to another. It had never been a scourge of humans before and nobody was immune to it and that is why it is so virulent right now, worldwide. It is related to the virus that causes the flu and common colds and, now that it is here, will always be here to some extent.

Experts says there’s a good chance the coronavirus will never go away. Even after a vaccine is discovered and deployed, the coronavirus will likely remain for decades to come, circulating among the world’s population. Experts call such diseases endemic — stubbornly resisting efforts to stamp them out. Think measles, HIV, chickenpox. It is a daunting proposition — a coronavirus-tinged world without a foreseeable end. But experts in epidemiology, disaster planning and vaccine development say embracing that reality is crucial. For now, though, most people have not been infected and remain susceptible. And the highly transmissible disease has surged in recent weeks, even in countries that initially succeeded in suppressing it. Left alone, experts say, it will simply keep burning through the world’s population. So we can hope or better pray for our normalised life.

While I HOPE very soon, I suspect it will fade this summer but return in the fall or winter, and be a problem until a vaccine or effective treatment arrives. One of the enormous errors we may have done was to rarely test RANDOMLY a cross-section of the population. This would let us know how many people don’t have symptoms or have mild ones. Instead, by just testing those that feel sick, we are left without useful knowledge. The State of New York did try to test randomly one day, and found 20% of those tested in New York City had Covid-19 (many didn’t realize it), and 6% in upstate New York. Iceland also tried and many that had it didn’t know it, but I don’t know for sure what the numbers were.

In the simplest of terms, it probably won’t be eradicated in the near future (like smallpox). The eradication of smallpox took generations. What we know is that it mutated from SARS, and that it continues to mutate. Some shape, manner or form of it will continue to exist for the immediate future, very much like influenza. And yes, even bubonic plague. An immunization like the flu shot will be developed, and hopefully keeps pace with the mutations. What it does not prevent are other viral infections from sprouting randomly, and anywhere in the world. Or, those of us who choose to take matters unto themselves and disregard protocols. In the long run, if this goes according to history, it makes sense that those of us who historically have been hit by infestations such as plague, smallpox, and so forth may develop a form of natural immunity to nasty bugs. When? The answer will come in stages. As hospitals manage intake, and the curve is flattened, there may be a loosening on lockdowns. People with immunization may enjoy more freedoms. Preventative measures, like gloves, masks and handwashing stations will be more accessible. Some regions will enjoy more softening of restrictions earlier, as the disease is controlled. Until then, we go with the flow.

Right around the end of April to about the beginning of June, we will be seeing the virus start to subside. Medicines will be coming out, probably more vaccine tests will be available for the general public to try out and see the effects. Towards the end of the year after all the willing participants to the vaccine tests ….they will go ahead and pass a official vaccine that will go into effect at the start of 2021. Covid 19 will never go away but when it returns ….. it will be a very…. just low grade flu because most will have either got vaccinated OR they will have a strong immune system to fight off the disease.

To be frank, at present the world doesn’t have the perfect answer to this question. Nobody really knows that when it will end and how it will end because everyday a high amount of positive cases are adding day by day. This reminds me of an image that I recently came across on Google:  Image Source: Google “The most negative word of 2020 is “POSITIVE”. Everyday we are coming up with a news that coronavirus is growing and growing continuously. I do remember that it was late January when I was suffering internet and was doing some research for my article. This is when I came across a website; “WORLDOMETERS”. This website shows the world population data which I wanted for my article but it was then I noticed that it also have the Coronavirus in their Menu bar.  Image Source: Worldometers So, I clicked on it. I noticed the number of Coronavirus patients was around few hundreds. But then I do realised that this is something really serious, so I checked the data everyday to see the changes in the graph. Trust me, I have never seen such a massive jump in any of the graph that I came across till date. From few hundreds, today the total number of cases are in millions.  Image Source: Worldometers The number showing in the screenshot above is the current number of cases throughout the world. It is not just shocking but it is heartbreaking that just in few months this has spread throughout the globe. This brings me to the question that “When Worldometer was quick on it then why not governments of different countries identified that this was coming! “ If they would have then the result would have been something else. But now everyone has this question; “WHEN IS THIS GOING TO END?” Honestly, no one has the right answer for this with assurance. Though, today I came across a study on on “When Will COVID-19 End”. This study was published by Data-Driven Innovation Lab of Singapore University of Technology and Design . This data driven lab has prepared a detail report by following susceptible-infected-recovered model. The model is regressed with data from different countries to estimate the pandemic life cycle curves and predict when the pandemic might end in respective countries and the world. The study has presented the bar graph of different countries. The graph shows the estimated downfall and the end date of Coronavirus in respective countries.  Image Source: Singapore University of Technology and Design So all you need to do is just click on the graph and it will show you when there will be a downfall in the number of cases and by what date there will be no more cases of Covid-19. But the point to consider here is that they have clearly stated that “The Content from this website is STRICTLY ONLY for educational and research purposes and may contain errors.” Therefore, it is very much necessary for us to follow what we are following currently and that too for long until it is publicly announced that Vaccine and/or treatment is found. Currently, there are n number of countries working on finding a vaccination and some are trying plasma therapy but we need to know that a legit vaccination takes time to show results and has to pass through n number of stages before being termed as a proper cure. Therefore, I am sorry to say but so far there isn’t any proper answer to this question. But the good news is that our mother earth is healing and it will be a beautiful place to live in after the end of pandemic, only if we now obey plus respect the nature and care for our healthy future.  Image Source: Clix Gallery Therefore, this leaves us with the only solution to this question and that is the best way to end this pandemic is by following WHO rules and also by staying updated with recent information shared by WHO. Rules: Wash your hands frequently.Maintain social distancing.Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth.Practice respiratory hygiene.If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early.Stay informed, Do not spread fake news and follow advice given by your healthcare provider.When coughing or sneezing cover your mouth and nose with flexed elbow or use disposable tissue and discard after use.Above mentioned rules are set by World Health Organisation. It is our duty to abide these rules and maintain social distancing. We need to remember one thing that the only way to get infected now is by not obeying these rules and by not maintaining hygiene. Therefore, Stay HomeStay SafeMeditate/ Prayand above all, “Break the chain”Remember, “This shall too pass….”

When do we get rid of the corona virus? My best bet: Never I think that this virus, sars-ncov-2, will be incorporated in what we usually call “the annual influenza”. Albeit it will probably, as other viruses has done (the Asian flu or the Spanish flu - which are now within the “annual influenzas”) mutate to a less deadly form. I also think that in time we will have a vaccine for this strain, which people in risk groups will take when the season is in. Another question is: When will the acute phase of the covid-19 disease be over ? My best bet here is: It depends where in the world you live, but probably not entirely over (as in free international travel again) until an efficient mass distributed vaccine is here. And that is probably going to happen during 2021 hope fully in the Q1 or Q2 Until then I think most countries will fins some kind of equilibrium in handling the infection, weighing this against measures and trying to avoid lock downs, at least only take this a as a last effort in smaller regions. And testing and tracking will need to be stepped up. The most worrisome are all the poorer countries, where the health care risks being overwhelmed even more than in Italy, Spain and New York. Especially with non transparent governments who denies the virus and can be expected to hide fatalities rather than addressing the issue.

I kind of think there are four possibilities. We develop a vaccine. People that get vaccinated don’t get the virus, so don’t spread it to others. There are some vaccines in development, and they’ve injected a few people with it. They need to wait and be sure these people don’t all die. So that’s like 12–14 months. Then, if the vaccine works, they have to make it.We figure out how to treat it. Suppose we find a way to reduce the death rate and suffering with an existing medicine (a new medicine would require all kinds of testing). If we could get this to twice the flu, that’s probably good enough. I don’t know if the recent therapies being discussed are going to really work. But if we can manage this thing down, that could end it.We develop an accurate and quick test, and people would take tests very frequently. This would help isolate those who are carrying the disease.We discover that way more people have gotten the disease than previously thought. In other words, most people have been exposed. This line of thought has been talked about on social media, but I really can’t figure out how that would be possible. Sure, there are many people carrying the disease who haven’t been tested. But I’m still more convinced that this disease is not yet that prevalent — mainly because there weren’t huge numbers of people in the hospital in February. If the disease has already been spreading around a lot, how could we not have had any significant hospitalizations? So I really don’t believe this line of reasoning…

I am trying to be optimistic, and having seeing how bad it could get, geometric progression with no real I guess when it would stop, I have been watching the rate of increase of the death toll seem to began to flatten out. 6 weeks ago, America had yet to have its first actual death from the Coronavirus, although there were already 62 Active cases. Since then we've watched the death toll rise, up a gradient that looks like some sick version of a roller coaster ride. But the time where the death rate is doubling every few days may be behind us. The death rate has increased almost everyday, but that increase has been dropping, and looking at the numbers for today, April 11th, it looks like we may not be able to match yesterday's numbers, which is a good thing. Of course, it's possible that there are so many dying today but they just simply have not had time to report their numbers to the CDC. But if we have peaked, if the death rate does start to go down from here, we might see the end of this in the middle to late month of May. Of course, that is a big if, but one to pray for. For now, stay inside, stay safe. May it not be too much longer.

Viruses are ancient. Studies at the molecular level have revealed relationships between viruses infecting organisms from each of the three domains of life, suggesting viral proteins that pre-date the divergence of life and thus infecting the last universal common ancestor.  While the origin of viruses is still unclear. There are 3 hypotheses: Virus-first hypothesis: Viruses evolved from complex molecules of protein and nucleic acid before cells first appeared on earth. By this hypothesis, viruses contributed to the rise of cellular life.Reduction hypothesis (degeneracy hypothesis): Viruses were once small cells that parasitized larger cells.Escape hypothesis (vagrancy hypothesis): Some viruses evolved from bits of DNA or RNA that "escaped" from the genes of larger organisms.What is clear is that viruses have actively been participate to the evolution of life and that they will continue doing that. Now let's first take a look at Coronavirus history.  The story of the coronavirus begins in a journal article published in 2007 when infectious disease specialists published a study claiming that "the presence of a large reservoir of SARS-CoV type virus in horseshoe bats, as well as the culture of eating exotic mammals in southern China is a time bomb. The possibility of a re-emergence of SARS and other new viruses from animals or laboratories and, therefore, the need for preparation should not be overlooked. They were ignored.  The evidence of China’s deliberate cover-up of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan is a matter of public record. In suppressing information about the virus, doing little to contain it, and allowing it to spread unchecked in the crucial early days and weeks, the regime imperiled not only its own country and its own citizens but also the more than 100 nations now facing their own potentially devastating outbreaks. More perniciously, the Chinese government censored and detained those brave doctors and whistleblowers who attempted to sound the alarm and warn their fellow citizens when they understood the gravity of what was to come.  China has a history of mishandling outbreaks, including SARS in 2002 and 2003. But Chinese leaders’ negligence in December and January—for well over a month after the first outbreak in Wuhan—far surpasses those bungled responses. The end of last year was the time for authorities to act, and, as Nicholas D. Kristof of The New York Times has noted, “act decisively they did—not against the virus, but against whistle-blowers who were trying to call attention to the public health threat.” This is what allowed the virus to spread across the globe. Because the Chinese Communist Party was pretending that there was little to be concerned about, Wuhan was a porous purveyor of the virus. The government only instituted a lockdown in Wuhan on January 23—seven weeks after the virus first appeared. As events in Italy, the United States, Spain, and France have shown, quite a lot can happen in a week, much less seven. By then, mayor Zhou Xianwang admitted that more than 5 million people had already left Wuhan.  When will it? Here is a pessimistic forecast for March 2021: In one year tens of millions of people have died from the COVID-19. Countless others have died because hospitals are too overwhelmed to adequately deal with heart attacks, asthma and diabetic attacks. The economy has entered a depression because fiscal and monetary policy is ineffective when people fear leaving, businesses are closed and a large part of the population is unemployed. A vaccine still seems far away, immunity among those who have recovered proves fleeting and the coronavirus has joined the seasonal flu as a recurring danger.  Here is an optimistic alternative scenario for March 2021: Life largely returned to normal in late summer 2020, and the economy rebounded strongly. Countries have successfully broken the transmission cycle in the spring of 2020; warm weather then reduced new infections and provided summer respite for the northern hemisphere. By the second wave of fall, the mutations had dampened the coronavirus, many people were immune, and drugs have been shown to be effective in treating it and even reducing infection. Tens of thousands of people have died, mostly in their 80s and 90s and some suffering from respiratory problems, but in February 2021, vaccinations were introduced worldwide and the virus was defeated.

This is difficult to achieve but yes, it can be attempted. so the philosophy has to be Each one saves one i.e. just self. Worth including that vaccine is also under development.

One possibility, historians say, is that the coronavirus pandemic could end socially before it ends medically. People may grow so tired of the restrictions that they declare the pandemic over, even as the virus continues to smolder in the population and before a vaccine or effective treatment is found. It is happening already; in some states, governors have lifted restrictions, allowing hair salons, nail salons and gyms to reopen, in defiance of warnings by public health officials that such steps are premature.As the economic catastrophe wreaked by the lockdowns grows, more and more people may be ready to say “enough. “I think there is this sort of social psychological issue of exhaustion and frustration,” Yale historian Naomi Rogers said. “We may be in a moment when people are just saying, ‘That’s enough. I deserve to be able to return to my regular life.’” STAY SAFE CHEERS….

Nope. It will probably become a worldwide endemic disease. Overtime we will develop antibodies that will protect us from it, not just by catching it and surviving (which will become easier once our hospitals will have reliable drugs and therapeutic protocols to heal the patients), but also by having regular, yearly vaccines against it. The point of fighting it back now isn’t getting rid of it, it is limiting the speed of its spread so that our hospitals can cope with it while we don’t have yet the necessary drugs, protocols, and most importantly the vaccines. It is interesting to notice that one hypothetesis of the scientists about its rapid spread is that most people who catch the virus don’t ever develop symptoms or only develop mild symptoms, and yet they are contagious. If this was true (and we will know if a reliable sierologic test is developed to check for antibodies), it may mean that the number of people who develop antibodies to this infection is much highier than we suspect. These antibodies do not prevent people from reinfecting from other strands of the virus (which has a very high tendency to mutate), but may make future reinfections less dangerous.

Has the flu? Once in the human population such illnesses get traded about nominally unless a resistance is built up. Why do we have cold and flu season? Because these illnesses are always with us but in winter months they tend to have longer lifespans and we tend to have lower immune responses. Combined that creates the cold and flu season. I think we will eventually have an antivirus which will seriously cut the spread and perhaps allow the illness to die. I expect that covid-19 will merely become a lurking illness to pop up now and again once an antivirus is in regular use. And then of course there will be the antivaxers. What to do with them when it is an issue of public health will be a huge question. My guess delay and allow the illness to spread via anti vax populations.

Viruses are not films that there will be a climax scene and ‘the end' will pop up. Viruses dont end, the diseases they cause get eradicated and that happens when the virus cannot find a vulnerable host to infect. That can happen only when All of the people in the world have developed immunity to the virus through previous infection, vaccination or adoptive transferAll of the human race is wiped out by the virusSince we know by now that the virus kills less than 5% of people it infects, the second macabre scenario is almost impossible. I say almost because viruses can mutate and become more virulent. So only scenario one is realistic. If a vaccine is developed and most people are vaccinated, along with some herd immunity, the epidemic may first be coverted to sporadic cases over the next 3-5 years. However if no vaccine is developed or the virus keeps mutating, we may be looking at periodic waves or outbreaks forever.

Given the COVID-19 virus belongs to a family of viruses known for three major characteristics: The ability to rapidly mutateThe lack of ability of humans to form long-lasting immunity, even after prior exposureA very high level of communicabilityI would find it extremely unlikely that it will naturally disappear. I would expect, instead, that it continually mutates, much like the common cold, and would continue to be passed around forever. In general, I would also expect those mutations to make it somewhat less virulent though I would also expect that the virulence would vary according to the strain. In short, I expect COVID-19 to be around for a VERY long time, just like Influenza, though significantly more dangerous.

The truth is people will catch Covid-19 and 90% of us will shake it off like a bad cold. The only people who it will affect negatively are those who are elderly or infirm. Or Young babies. Probably after a decade or so. In order to make this easier to explain, I want all of you to forgot that we have medicine and just imagine that we are back at prehistoric times. I think it will end after the effects of the extreme quarantine measures begin to kick in and sustain themselves for a while. The quarantine and lockdown are definitely helping to limit the growth in the number of infected individuals. Soon enough, the number of new cases will peak and begin declining. The infected population will also peak and begin declining after some weeks delay. Once government officials can be absolutely certain that the risk of a resurgence is negligible or nonexistent, they can begin easing some of the restrictions. Soon after, life will transition to a state of normalcy (with the exception of the economy which will take time to recover). This scenario assumes that no country’s healthcare infrastructure becomes overwhelmed by the pandemic. Unfortunately, right now I’m reading that things have gotten so bad in some areas of the USA that vital surgeries are being indefinitely postponed in order to make room for coronavirus patients (I still need to more thoroughly fact check this though). If the US healthcare infrastructure is overwhelmed by this crisis, it will be tougher (if not darn near impossible) to keep this pandemic from ballooning completely out of control with tens of millions of Americans becoming infected at some point (and with deaths in the hundreds of thousands or millions). The last thing any place needs is too many people going undiagnosed or untreated, since this would only worsen the spread of COVID-19. The more people there are with the disease at any given time (especially undiagnosed/untreated), the faster it spreads (all other factors being equal).

I think it will be around into next Spring and then circulate at very low levels far beyond that. What’s likely to happen is that as the pandemic reaches dangerous levels in a country, rules around social distancing and extreme measures to prevent spread and protect the health services in that country become more stringent. As levels becoming infected eases a bit, the rules are relaxed and the illness will then undergo a second wave of spread, which is likely to result in the rules around social distancing etc being tightened again. This tightening and relaxing of measures to control the pandemic may happen for some time. There’s also a school of thought that the rate of infection may ease slightly in the summer months, only to come back with avengeance in the autumn.

What is meant by “control”? Absolute elimination? No more reports of new cases? That would be an unreasonable expectation to ever reach. We have been living with thousands of viral diseases throughout history, and it is irrational to single out this one virus and insist that it be eliminated. The reasonable objectives of “control” are that the number of cases requiring hospitalization are well within the capacity of hospitals, which was described as “flattening the curve”.The number of new deaths are comparable to or less than that of other diseases that we have traditionally found acceptable, such as the flu.By these two criteria, I believe it is already under control. And I have no doubt that the number of new deaths could be significantly reduced immediately if present restrictions on hydroxychloroquine were relaxed. Let the front-line physicians who know what they’re doing do their jobs, without so much political interference.

The short answer is that it won’t. The Bubonic plague started around the 15th century, and it is still infecting people to this day. Though, what I think you are trying to ask is: when will it be treated with the same severity as the flu? To that answer, it is unknowable. A bunch of big drug companies are currently in high gear to come up with a vaccine, but it won’t be enough for some people. Some people get the vaccine for the flu and still die, despite precautionary measures. So if you want a specific ballpark of when Covid will end, according to this article from men’s health (When Will the Novel Coronavirus Pandemic Be Over?): “Spring 2022 is most likely the earliest we’ll have both a widely-available and effective vaccine for the virus and a dominant worldwide immunity”. I hope this answers your question.

Thank you for the question: When will the COVID-19 virus end? The second wave is coming, then a third, at least. Ready or not, they’re coming. I looked through historical records. In most centuries there's a pandemic be it bubonic plague, yellow fever, smallpox, cholera, Spanish Flu or whatever. Average length of the pandemics: 3 years. Average number of waves: 3. Don't expect things to clear up until the end of 2022 at the earliest. In the meantime be healthy, be safe, and practise cleanliness regularly.

Well the outbreak probably means—where it first started with significant numbers, serious illness, and death. That appears to have happened in China and the outbreak itself is over. Covid has now spread and is a pandemic. But the pandemic is far from over. Cases are on the rise in the US and the UK. Some of that is driven by the opening up of society and, apparently, by young people not following precautions (note I understand and I’m not judging younger people even though I’m older in terms of age; in fact I sympathize—the young have their whole lives ahead and it must be a scary thing to be asked to put one’s life on hold). But there is a positive sign. The ratio of deaths to cases has gone down and factors in that change may include better care, better understanding of how to care, better understanding of and treatment for at risk factors, hospital capacity not being overwhelmed, and perhaps that the virus has mutated to a less virulent stain (if a virus is too virulent, it kills hosts before they can spread it). For a source, see this: COVID-19 death rates have drastically fallen among all age groups — even as cases spike. Of course, the pandemic is still here and we ought to be taking personal precautions. I know some people protest and debate. But consider this (i) no precaution is perfect (masks, distancing, hand sanitizing) (ii) but we don’t need them to be perfect—what we need is for them to be good enough to lower the spread of the disease so that there are fewer cases and fewer deaths (iii) and while no one individual has perfect protection, everyone’s protection is improved. In summary, the pandemic is not over, there is hope, and we ought to continue to take precautions.

Nobody knows but it is going to be more dangerous in upcoming days in India as well as in The World. Most of the Corona hotspots so far have been urban affluent districts, with richer states hit harder than the rest. India’s case count is now roughly double what it was ten days ago. This is a much slower rate compared to early-April, when cases were doubling every four days. Deaths have also seen slower rise. India’s death toll from covid-19 as of last evening was 826, roughly double what it was eleven days ago. Still, at the current rate of compounded , the number of cases could rise to 50,000 in the next eight days, and strain an already weak health system.  States - Over the past seven days, West Bengal, Maharashtra, and Gujarat have seen the highest spike in cases among top ten states with most cases. These three states account for 67 percent of all the new active cases in this period. Over the same period, fatalities have surged the most in Rajasthan, Gujarat, and Andhra Pradesh. These three states account for 37 percent of all covid-related deaths over the past seven days.  Districts- Over the past two days, Mumbai, Ahmedabad, New Delhi, Indore, and Thane districts have seen the biggest spike in confirmed cases nationally. These five districts account for 49 percent of new cases over this period, data compiled by http://howindialives.com shows. Other districts that have seen a sharp spike over the past two days include Pune, Kolkata, and Krishna district in Andhra Pradesh. The coronavirus case count has crossed 2.9 million globally even as several parts of the world, including India, continue to be under lockdown to contain the pandemic.

Viruses are unlike bacteria or other parasites, in not having a birth/ spore stage, an adult stage which reproduces or replicates and death. Vuruses do replicate whenever they get entry into a suitable host cell and get access to the cell's organelles to use the cell's material to reproduce the viral RNA. Outside a host cell, different types of viruses can remain dormant for long time spans. This said, it is possible for the outer layers of a virus , made up of proteins and lipids to be damaged enough by presence of high temperatures and strong chemicals to render the virus incapable of entering into a host cell . The various articles or snippets about how long the SARS -Cov 2 remains active are guesses about this, since the numbers are changing all the time , depending on the source.

Unpredictable. No consistent pattern has emerged. In China and South Korea, new cases started to decline about two weeks after the epidemic started to spread exponentially. (China is now reporting less than 50 new cases per day, down from a peak of 4,000 new cases per day 5 weeks ago.) In Japan, new cases increased steadily for several weeks, then entered exponential growth recently. In Iran, expansion has been biphasic, peaking about two weeks after exponential growth began, but then starting to rise again. Italy went exponential three weeks ago and is still expanding exponentially. Other countries (Europe and the US), went exponential less than two weeks ago so the jury is still out. So far we have no way of knowing how these patterns may have been affected by public health measures. Add to that questions about the reliability of the data, and you have uncertainties piled on top of uncertainties. Best case scenario, if the US follows the Chinese/South Korean pattern, is that new US cases will peak in about a week or two, then gradually decline. But don't hold your breath. Or actually, do hold your breath, at least in public.

The CoViD-19 pandemic may end in a couple of months after the successful vaccine is out, ( I would put a date of June next year) but unfortunately I do not see SARS-CoV-2 being eradicated ever. There are a couple of reasons. The virus spreads very efficiently. It binds to ACE-2 receptors much more easily than its cousins that caused the SARS and MERS epidemics. This means , theoretically, a lower viral load could infect someone. Therefore new hosts can be attained relatively easily.The virus causes mild symptoms in most cases and can spread from asymptomatic people. This is a crafty move by the virus. It's more deadly cousins made the hosts really sick and that meant the patient was easy to trace and confine; and even if not traced, wouldn't be able to move about actively, spreading the disease, due it's more lethal nature. SARS-CoV-2 , on the other hand , causes mild symptoms to asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic people are harder to trace and can actively move about. How many office days did you miss because of a light cough?There are a lot of people to vaccinate. Estimates say that if 500 thousand Indians were vaccinated daily , it would take around 5 years to vaccinate all of us. And that's just India. As long as one potential host remains , the virus can replicate and survive. But even then, is it possible that systematic vaccination drives can eradicate the virus and the disease? Unfortunately no. That brings us to the next point.The vaccines may safeguard us against the virus for only a short period of time ( less than 6 months). A study found that only 17 percent of recovered CoViD-19 patients had detectable amounts of antibodies post 3 months of their recovery. That hints that revaccination may be required for people, crushing the chances of eradication of the disease altogether.

What we can expect is for the coronavirus to last at least a year and longer. The virus may never completely disappear but become a recurring infection that continues. We haven't gotten rid of numerous viruses over the last two decades in particular. For example, the bird flu does continue with about 1000 cases per year. And measles had near disappeared but revived again and while efforts have been made to eradicate but so far not. Both viruses are more infectious than Covid-19. There's so little that we know for the long-term, and it will be some time before there is a better understanding of the virus. We will only have better answers when the virus is on the wane, and the number of cases drops. We can expect the virus to be long-lived, it’s highly infectious and as long as people refuse to take precautions then we can expect continuing spread.

We should incorporate permanent structural changes even after stay at home orders and quarantine containment are lifted. Social distancing should continue to be mandatory. Transportation systems should only handle capacity of fewer passengers with adequate distances. Thermal temperature scanners should be used at all public events by security officers when people enter. Work and home should be a permanent arrangement by many employers in telecommunications and the service sector. This helps mitigate traffic and infrastructure costs of new roads and transit networks. Restaurants should focus more heavily on take out foods and private delivery services than dine in.

For developed countries, the earliest that there will be full protection would be the end of 2021, simply due to the amount of time it takes for pharmaceutical companies to manufacture and distribute the vaccines or treatments.For developing countries, it would be well into 2022, because the logistic networks are poorer.But of course, this all depends on the idea that a successful vaccine would be available by early 2021, and that there would not be any new resistant strain of the coronavirus to emerge in the near future. The seasonal flu for example always comes back with a vaccine resistant strain annually. For this reason, global travel will not resume until the end of 2022. There will be limitations to border controls well into 2023, with only a few countries allowing travel within special travel bubbles. The Tokyo Olympics will not go ahead as planned, the Beijing Olympics would be affected, with the Paris Olympics being the first major world event to be tested after the world opens up (if the Olympics even remain relevant by then). A few vaccines are harder to distribute than others. The Pfizer vaccine would take far longer to distribute outside urban area in developed countries, let alone in developing countries, pushing back the end date by several months. The economic fallout would be far longer than the Great Recession. I suspect that the fact that tourism will remain suppressed until well into 2022 is a sign that the economic recovery will let start until 2023, which means than the downturn could last until 2028.

Most likely forever. The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. The most commonly implicated virus is a rhinovirus (30–80%), a type of picornavirus with 99 known serotypes. Other commonly implicated viruses include human coronaviruses (≈ 15%), influenza viruses (10–15%), adenoviruses (5%), human respiratory syncytial virus (orthopneumovirus), enteroviruses other than rhinoviruses, human parainfluenza viruses, and human metapneumovirus. Frequently more than one virus is present. COVID-19 will just be added to the current list.

I think COVID-19 will end either once everyone who can be infected is infected, or once a vaccine can be mass-produced and distributed. The first option means it will likely stretch out longer as it gets into more and more remote areas and small outbreaks keep happening, even after the major one subsides at some point next year or the year after. This option will definitely result in more deaths than the second one. The second option, on the other hand, will likely result in the virus ending sooner since we’ll be able to root it out before it infects everyone that can possibly be infected. This will also cause less deaths. Some people have expressed other options, such as just containing it and eliminating it through other treatments, but I don’t think that will be enough to eradicate it by the time a vaccine is developed sometime next year.

The best answer would be: When our immunologists finally find a vaccine and when our veterinary epidemiologists/biologists find the intermediate host(IH). But producing a vaccine takes a minimum of 6–8 months and right at the outset of the outbreak, cases of re-infection were reported, which made everything difficult, if not, impossible. Based on the recent scientific journals that I have read lately, the virus seems to show intra-host adaptation there have been certain amino acid deletions(Asp268del) when researchers compared 37 clusters of samples from Europe vs the originally sequenced sample from Wuhan. Which is why research modalities are veering towards druggable protein targets instead, meaning, people are just shifting towards the search of an antiviral, not a vaccine. So to answer your question, I don’t think quarantines and lockdowns will end this, It would just lessen the cases but not end it. This would only end when we finally have a vaccine and the IH has been found but at this rate, I don’t think we are anywhere near the resolution of this pandemic.

Because Joe Berah has blocked comments a new answer here can deal with what he wrote, which contains a slight mistake. Thus, he wrote “The Coronavirus as we know it has found a good host. And when a virus finds a good host, it is part of the host species’ existence forever.” Let me mention two exceptions to his rule, one of which is no longer infecting people and one which has been almost eliminated as a danger for sad reasons I will not discuss here. Small Pox is no longer a threat and polio could become “no longer a threat”. The reason why “, it is part of the host species’ existence forever.” does not apply is that these two viruses seem to only be able to multiply and spread in humans. Thus, development of an effective vaccine combined with very widespread vaccination has been able to eliminate small pox and “corner” polio to small regions where there is resistance to idea of being vaccinated against polio. With this corona virus, SARS-CoV-2, there is a not-human reservoir and maybe even multiple other animals able to give homes to the virus and in fact give homes without those animals themselves becoming sick. Thus, it is truely stamping this virus out completely is highly unlikely, like a number of other viruses for which we use vaccinations as protection.

OR sooner or later everyone will have developed immunities to it (either through having had it, or through vaccination), and it will only make its run among young children who have not yet been vaccinated. However, latest worries are that immunity may only be short-term (as with the flu - the vaccines are only good for one year), OR that we may not even be ABLE to develop a vaccine for it. As for immunity after having had it, they are now not sure you can develop immunity (or it may be that you are not catching it a second time, but that it is still in your body and reemerging within us). Things are indeed very difficult right now, and there is much suffering. But we have to find our footing anyway, and we have to discover how to work with our emotions or we suffer even more.

I believe nobody in the world can give you a correct answer. What can be said is that researchers have found flu to be seasonal. In temperate regions of the world flu usually lasts in the colder winter season when the atmospheric humidity is very low. In tropical and sub-tropical regions flu is more prevalent in the summer/rainy months when humidity is high. Also, the intensity of flu infection is severe in temperate regions than in hotter regions of the world. CDC estimates that flu season in the US usually peaks in December to March period. Rarely the peaks occur in the months of April and May. Therefore, only on the basis of this data we can expect that COVID-19 may subside by April or May. However, this is a new virus and nobody knows how will it behave.  [1] Centers for Disease Control United States. Footnotes[1] The Flu Season | CDC

Zhong Nanshan, head of the high-level expert group of the national health commission and an academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering, said the virus would not be active in the hot summer and the development of the global outbreak is expected to last at least until June, but the prediction is based on positive measures taken by all countries to give national attention. He said "If there are countries that don't take the magnitude of the epidemic very seriously, the end date is not very clear. In general, new coronaviruses are less active in summer, when the temperature is higher. But it still depends on how seriously each country takes it. As the emphasis in the most affected countries increases, I think the end of the outbreak in June is something to look forward to."

For other types of Corona Viruses, they’re not going to go away. Corona viruses have been circulating among animal populations forever, and they have adapted to the presence of these viruses. India COVID-19 Peak Expected In May, Lockdown Helped Cut Numbers: Sources States which implemented hard lockdowns earlier than others have fared better when it comes to the crisis and are seeing their overall numbers decline, the sources added. Highlights "India is going to ramp up testing": Home Ministry3.6 lakh people in isolation facilities or home quarantinedOver 13,000 infected with coronavirus, 437 deathsNew Delhi: An internal government assessment suggests that India may touch its peak of coronavirus cases in the first week of May after which the number will decline, sources in the Home Ministry have said. States which implemented hard lockdowns earlier than others have fared better when it comes to the crisis and are seeing their overall numbers decline, the sources added. A continued rise in coronavirus cases over the next few days. "The numbers will increase as we will test more and also as the number of people who are being isolated with symptoms is also increasing every day," he said. Since Prime Minister Narendra Modi extended the lockdown to May 3 earlier this week, India has added around 2,800 coronavirus positive cases taking the total well past 12,000. Some 36,000 people have been placed either in isolation in government facilities or have been home quarantined. As of Thursday, nearly 3.6 lakh people were in isolation facilities or home quarantined. "Most of these would be tested by the government," said an officer, adding that the major challenge before the government is not only to contain clusters but also the spread of sporadic cases."Clusters can be contained but it's very difficult to stop the spread of scattered cases,".

response.answer_text: Three months ago, no one knew that SARS-CoV-2 existed. Now the virus has spread to almost every country, infecting at least 446,000 people whom we know about, and many more whom we do not. It has crashed economies and broken health-care systems, field hospitals and emptied public spaces. It has separated people from their workplaces and their friends. It has disrupted modern society on a scale that most living people have never witnessed. Soon, almost everyone in the United States will know someone who has been infected. Like World War II or the 9/11 attacks, this pandemic has already imprinted itself upon the nation’s psyche.

No one knows. A semi-educated guess (Microbiologist, with minor in history in college, and have read multiple books on the Spanish Flu, though I am not an epidemiologist), would be it should/may be largely gone in late 2021 or early 2022. Why? Falls/winter is high season for flu, as people are together more for reasons of heat in the winter. Easier to spread. So this argues for a second peak this fall/winter. In other words, it is not going away soon.2. With any luck, a vaccine should emerge this winter, in other words late 2020 or early 2021. Assuming it is effective, this will start to knock down the virus starting then. 3. Evolution. Virus mutate/evolve like all living things. They almost always evolve to less dangerous forms. If they got more dangerous, they would simply be killing off the host the virus needs to reproduce, so milder forms predominate. 4. Patterns. This is similar as to what the Spanish flu did 100 years ago. Hit first, very mild in 1917. Hit hard in a second wave in the summer-to-fall of 1918, which argues for it to continue into 2021.

There are currently no antiviral drugs recommended or licensed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for COVID-19. Clinical management includes prompt implementation of recommended infection prevention and control measures in healthcare settings and supportive management of complications. See more information on CDC Clinical Guidance for COVID-19. Children and their family members should engage in usual preventive actions to prevent the spread of respiratory infections, including covering coughs, cleaning hands often with soap and water or alcohol-based hand sanitizer, and staying up to date on vaccinations, including influenza. Additional information on prevention measures can be found here (Prevention for 2019 Novel Coronavirus).

Only Donald Trump calls it that. He calls it that because he is widely acclaimed to be an idiot. COVID-19 is likely to undergo many more mutations and if it follows previous pandemics, become less lethal.

In practice, the world will probably not be “free” of COVID-19.* The original SARS, swine flu and avian flu are still around. Smallpox virus is alive in research labs somewhere. If the human race develops herd immunity, be it through enough people being infected and recovering, or a successful vaccine that the public actually uses, COVID-19 could fade into the background like major diseases of the past. People with weakened immune systems or existing conditions like the elderly, will probably continue to be at higher risk, as they are with “ordinary” respiratory infections like influenza. *I have a pessimistic view for the modern global economy. I reviewed a statisticians estimates. To make it as simple as possible, this is when you know you are half way through the worst of it. When the new cases per day do not increase day over day. For example if your area had 200 new cases yesterday and had the same 200 today you are likely at the halfway point. This would need to happen for at least a week with the new cases being the same or less day over day. If you have experienced 3000 cases total by this halfway point you can expect another 3000 cases before it levels out. This would also apply to time. If it took 40 days to get to this halfway point you have another 40 days to get to where there is only a few new cases a day.

Coronavirus update on UK government daily briefing: COVID-19 death toll hits 17,337 as Matt Hancock announces first doses of Britain's coronavirus vaccine will be given to human volunteers on Thursday. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said that a jab which has been developed by Oxford University will start being tested 'in people' next days.  The Oxford team – led by Professor Sarah Gilbert, is testing ChAdOx1 nCoV-19, a candidate based on a chimpanzee adenovirus modified to include the spike or ‘S’ protein on the surface of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19. The government funded the vaccine project with 20 million pounds to Oxford University and another 22 million pounds to a second vaccine project at Imperial College, London Health Secretary Matt Hancock said on Wednesday, adding the project will help support phase 2 trials and help prepare for a larger phase 3 study. vaccine is the "best way" to defeat the virus and the bring the number of cases down in the country. When you use “extinguished” what does that mean, exactly! Given my medical experience there are two answers that immediately come to my mind. First, the virus is exterminated in Sunlight. All Pandemics end when the virus doesn't have enough susceptible people to infect. If the virus comes into contact with another person but that person isn't susceptible to the disease, then that chain of transmission is snuffed out. If one person infects two, those people together infect four and so on, and eventually, the virus runs out of susceptible people to infect, said Joshua Epstein, a professor of epidemiology at New York University. "What happens typically is that enough people get the bug that there just aren't enough susceptible people to keep the chain going." LIVE SCIENCE.

There is no “the” corona virus or any virus in existence know as corona. There are 100+ known coronaviruses including SARS-CoV-2 which causes COVID-19. None of them can simply “disappear.” Viruses continue to spread as long as there are hosts that they can infect and they have a means to infect those hosts. COVID-19 will continue to spread until a vaccine becomes available and is widely distributed.

How long is a piece of string? How beautiful is a sunset? How good is the first mouthful of beer? “It depends!”, is the answer. If, and it is a BIG 'IF', we can develop a safe and effective vaccine, then SARS-COV-2, which is the virus which causes Covid-19, will cease to be a factor for most humans by mid-2021. If we can't develop a vaccine, then we need to look at history. The virus could behave like Spanish Flu, which devastated the planet in three waves between 1918 and 1922, then vanished. Or it could become a more lethal version of flu, with annual Covid-19 seasons… Or, it could mutate and become more lethal, more infectious, or both, and go on to burn a massive swathe through our species… No-one, repeat NO-ONE, actually knows.

That would depend on what you mean by “extinguished.” The pandemic will cease when the disease is no longer spreading across whole countries. At that point it will probably become endemic to the USA and Brazil. Covid-19 is probably not like smallpox or polio (this close!), where it will disappear completely when it is unable to spread to a new host. Covid-19 probably has a Natural reservoir - likely bats - and will probably keep coming back, like Ebola. We don’t even know if infection coneys immunity or if it does, for how long. Treatments will keep getting better, as they already have been and as with other diseases that don’t have a cure, like HIV-AIDS. More people will survive infection. But gone and largely forgotten, like smallpox? Probably never. Q: When will COVID-19 be extinguished?

Given the aggressiveness with which the virus spreads and the length for which it remains in your system (over a month) I do not see it being eradicated anytime soon (as long as a few people have it for a month at a time and they are moving about, they will pass it to others and keep in going for years). Most people expect the outbreaks to decrease when warm weather arrives, so we should get a breather, but unless it is pretty tightly controlled it will pick up in fall. I see better treatment options as being more promising in the immediate term than the availability of a vaccine

There is no currently available vaccine for COVID-19. However, many of the symptoms can be treated and getting early care from a healthcare provider can make the disease less dangerous. There are several clinical trials that are being conducted to evaluate potential therapeutics for COVID-19. As with other respiratory infections like the flu or the common cold, public health measures are critical to slow the spread of illnesses. Public health measures are everyday preventive actions that include: ✓ staying home when sick; ✓ covering mouth and nose with flexed elbow or tissue when coughing or sneezing. Dispose of used tissue immediately; ✓ washing hands often with soap and water; and ✓ cleaning frequently touched surfaces and objects.

If ALL of us strictly follow the rules about social distancing, wear masks and wash hands, stay home, eat at home, only hang out with immediate family or room mates - we can get this under control. I live in Ontario Canada - we had it down to 60 cases a day and dropping in August - and then university restarted and bars and restaurants reopened. Despite the rules, a lot of younger people started engaging in risky behaviors - big parties and gatherings full of unrelated people, going out to bars and restaurants, visiting friends, not wearing masks - and boom, now we are up to 400 cases a day and growing. Almost every new case is among the 35 and under crowd and can be traced to misbehaviour. It’s very discouraging - because so often one person gets it and passes it to others - such as vulnerable family. How could you live with yourself if your grandfather died because you selfishly went to a party? I understand that young people want to be with their friends. It’s a stage of life when that seems so important. But- we all have to be strong and think about the goal.
